text:
I think we need a few billion in research on thorium/liquid salt reactors which are incredibly safe. Chernobyl type accidents would be rendered impossible. A bunch of research has already been done. It's mostly figuring out what materials to use for the reactor core because liquid salt is very corrosive. Once that's done we can set up reams of thorium reactors across the nation and rapidly transition to electric cars (which is something that's happening already anyway). Cars, btw, are only some 28% of green house emissions. Electric heating and running all industry on electric where possible would cut another 30% or so. Add this to the 27% for electricity production and we get an 85% reduction in green house emissions by going thorium (or any nuclear, for that matter). Cows fart methane which is a very powerful greenhouse gas. Preventing methane from getting in the air would help a lot. I'm sure we can figure out a way to capture these farts with a cheap, reusable piece of gear we can fit to the cow. Simply lighting the methane on fire would help a lot. This device could be attached to the cows rear end, capture the methane and do a controlled burn, or it could be captured and stored for later burning (while using the energy).
We're only a few laws and some minor research away from having a clean world. A few dollars will fix this issue. Electric cars could be heavily subsidized so low income people could afford them. Tax increases to pay for these things would fall mostly on those who can bear the weight. A small price to pay for the continued livability of the only home we have, I'd say.

text:
KB, economics guy here, I would just like to address a few points that I think are not accurately presented in the video. 


Most greenhouse gases are short-lived, CO2 being a notable exception. Gases such as methane and HFCs are broken down by various reactions in the atmosphere with very little greenhouse effect overall. CO2 is estimated to have a hang time somewhere in the thousand year range, so once it's put in the air, it's there effectively permanently. This is why so little attention is paid to the greenhouse effects of HFCs, and so much attention is focused on CO2.


Forests are understood to not be particularly effective carbon sinks, as they are temporary in nature. They last only until a forest fire or flood or mass disease wipe out that forest and it has to start over again. This is compounded by warming effects which are killing off large tracts of forest in USA in Canada as conditions are made more favourable for parasites and fires.


The criticism that "Cap and Trade" cannot lower levels is incorrect, as the entire point of such a regime is that you know precisely how much total pollution is going to be created, if you can get your people/industries to comply with it. If you set the cap higher than the existing total, then your criticism is accurate, because the credits are nearly worthless and the sum total is unaffected. But if you set it at a lower level, such that the credits are undersupplied and desireable, they become expensive and incentives to lower emissions (or whatever else you're capping) become financially beneficial to the individuals who wish to buy or sell those credits. Thus, your output is known but your price is not. This is opposite of carbon taxation in which your price is known but your output is not.


Big thumbs up for the nuclear shout out, though.

text:
I am honestly a fan of your channel and videos. But your introductory comments are the heart of the problem with the climate "debate." Your statements leave no room for discussion, when there are many many scientists who ACCEPT the fact of climate change but who HONESTLY DISAGREE about whether it is a CRISIS or not. Of course global warming happens. 

DENIER is a political term, not a term for scientific discussion. Bjorn Lomborg (economist), Freeman Dyson, Christie, Curry, etc etc all have informed and persuasive views on the subject. 

Smug and dismissive aren't your normal modes. They don't serve you well. An open mind is the only kind of mind that belongs in a discussion of scientific matters. Science is not a democracy. Evidence. Evidence. Evidence.

Suggested starting point: what, exactly, is the "ideal" global temperature to which we need to aspire?

text:
¬†@John Salinas¬† The incredibly safe part is simple. If the reactor breaks, the radioactive stuff will just drip down, where a concrete bucket will catch it. It will then cool down rapidly and not explode. Since there's nothing under high pressure in a LFTR, explosions can't occur. Not can runaway reactions. A lot of research has already been done and research is very cheap provided there's a political will. This will has been missing since uranium/plutonium has been successful enough to make the financial investment into other tech not profitable enough. Of course, it is not a question of profitability at this point. It's a question of safety and the sustainability of our way of life as well as nature (with which we are still inextricably linked, btw: an ecosystem is a complex machine, case in point: bees are needed for pollination, which is needed for food). The government can and should fund the research. These decades can be shortened to years not because it is easy but because it is required, because that challenge is one that we are willing to accept, one we are unwilling to postpone, and one we intend to win. Lest we all live in a dystopia worse than one can imagine now, seeing as to how good we all have it and how unlikely it feels that things will rapidly go downhill.
We also have good, very very fast computers now that can aid in development, something they didn't have in the 60. Development should be fast, simple and straight forward, provided we pay the army of researchers we'd need to pull it off. Political will is all that stands between failure and success.

text:
The problem of overpopulation is not one of being able to feed 10 billion people - it's about the reduction of natural habitat that, on the present model, is directly associated with population increase. We have already reached a level of loss of "non human" land that is accelerating the decline and extinction of thousands if not hundreds of thousands of species of plant and animal all across the globe.
So while technically yes, I agree that we have the capacity to cope with a near doubling of hte present global population, it will come at a cost to the environment that just cannot be paid unless everyone reduces their own personal impact and a new paradigm concerning how much space we deem acceptable to exist within is reached.
I am of the opinion that the researchers who have settled on the 10-11 billion figure have done so based on misleading statistics - kind of like how if I was to treat an elephant as just a volume. If the elephant is 20 cubic metres, that doesn't mean an elephant can fit into a box with those dimensions, because in reality, there is 'empty space' between the elephant's legs that is not being considered as part of the elephants volume, but which the elephant cannot exist without. This is perhaps a rather simplistic example that uses the word elephant far too much - but I hope my point is made. I'm not for one instant claiming hte scientists haven't considered obvious examples like mine, but all evidence points to our current population having a detrimental effect that the globe cannot mitigate against, so at best, to sustain more people we will need a dramatic change in lifestyle. Personally, I think population limitation is an easier and more desirable target, because the real world will be very much bleaker if we all have to live in little pods with no gardens. Even a supposedly 'good' thing like walking in a natural park causes damage from erosion and disturbance to wildlife that is already placing a burden on nature that it is unable to cope with - and you want to double it?
Otherwise - very good video as per usual.

text:
YES! I'm really sick and tired of people thinking 'nuclear power bad' and 'let's just put solars and wind turbines everywhere'. Another point to add to what you've already said is cost and time to get a nuclear power plant going. To produce the same amount of power, you'd need sooo much more space, money, resources and workhours in completely reneweable solutions and we just don't have any of that, especially time. Switch to nuclear now and think about going full-wind/solar? Maybe, but we have to act now and act fast and there's just no way we can reduce fossil fuel plants to zero without building more nuclear ones, not quickly enough at least.
I've been an advocate for nuclear power for years now and I have to say, it drives me mad how one major incident and frankly ignorant mental connection to the atomic bomb keep our societies from embracing it. Chernobyl was one-of-a-kind design which failed mostly because soviets wanted to make some plutonium for a-bombs on the side (gross oversimplification, but that is what it boils down to). EVERY other plant just physically cannot do what happened there, by design. It's like air travel, it's much, much safer than the alternative, but the bad pr is killing it, a big explosion of a nuclear power plant is way more dramatic than thousands of dead coal miners, rafinery workers etc. By the way, you'll get more rads just flying a plane somewhere or having an x-ray than in majority of Chernobyl.
Also, if somehow you still don't know that, no, nuclear power plants physically cannot explode like an atomic bomb. Getting a nuclear explosion going is something way different and way too difficult to happen on its own. There's a reason why it took them sl long to figure it out, you know.
Sorry for the chaotic rant, it's just really disheartening to see no one in or near power doing the one single thing they should be doing now, especially where I live. We don't have a single nuclear power plant here in Poland yet (although we do have an experimental reactor for research) and majority of politicians, who do not want us to fall deeper and deeper into the authoritarian hellhole we're currently heading towards, are against building them for no reason other than populism or plain ignorance afaik. Feel free to correct me if I'm wrong, I have to admit I don't do nearly as much reading on the topic anymore for the sake of my mental health.

text: I started a master of science program in renewable engineering at Villanova University a few years ago. The problem we face as the human race goes far beyond climate change. The way we construct things, the ways we grow food and produce livestock, the way we process waste and fish the oceans. Almost every modern process is unsustainable with regard to having enough clean water, food, clean air and avoiding extinction. There are more than a half dozen real threats to human civilization that no is talking about that are likely to have tremendous impacts on us all within the next 50 years. My only hope is that AI and genetic engineering will save humanity through innovation. It's probably far more likely that our days are numbered. Either way I'm willing to bet that the next 50 years are going to be very exciting.

text: Man I like you channel, and this comment obviously won‚Äôt change much. However, I feel it‚Äôs a little disingenuous to lump us into a category of climate change denial. I have no doubt that the climate has changed, is changing and will continue to change. My problem is the percentage or fraction in which human life plays a role in it. There are certain scientific facts that you can‚Äôt argue. You cannot beat Newton‚Äôs laws. Dinosaurs did exist, the world is a sphere, and evolution is taught for a reason. My issue is when this theory becomes God. There is a psychologist would said the absence of religion makes people worship other ideas instead. Which again, more power to you. But believing in climate theory to the extent that is undeniably true takes the same leap of faith as someone who want to believe in a higher power. People like myself are not like being racist or homophobic. It is a different viewpoint as to how much of the problem is truly due to human involvement. Nuclear power is more efficient, less polluting and there is almost no drawbacks I could see. Which you cannot say about changing the cars in which people drive, the houses in which people live, the ways in which we choose to transport. When there is concrete evidence or an issue, and especially if China, India and Russia would get on board, I would be glad to see some government policy change. But as history may have shown you, and overreaching and overextended government never ends well. These people are the same people most often who will talk ill of the military industrial complex and police militarization. Well I riddle you a question. Who is to enforce the laws or sanctions when citizens or other countries don‚Äôt want to abide by these rules? Deregulate, decentralize, deactivate.

21:40 You might wanna do some research on that though. Even if waste is minimal and stored at the plant you have to store that for 10.000 years plus. Let's assume the small amount of waist accumulates over 10.000 years before some is not radioactive anymore. The tiny amount will grow quickly to unmanageable amounts.
There are no working breeding reactors on the grid and it will not save us, as waste can't be bred with 100 % efficiency back to fuel. Thorium will not save us either.
That long term storage isn't our forte and we don't have to extrapolate theoretical studies on that. The currently available sites prove that. 
The arguments are further somewhat flawed as nuclear isn't widely used. It only makes up like 10 % of worldwide energy production. Uranium is a limited resource too. If we would replace coal and gas with nuclear energy the uranium sources would be depleted in a couple of decades. Incicdences of "oopsies" with nuclear fusion increase as more plants get build.
I really don't see this as a future energy technology.

A nuclear solution would be fusion. Lithium needed to breed tritium needed for fusion is readily available in sea water and the amounts needed are tiny. ITER will run test blankets enriched with lithium to test this self sustaining fuel cycle.
For cars a fuel cell approach based on methanol might be a solution if we can produce it with green energy ofc. But the currently available infrastructure for gasoline can be used basically.

hey, i watch this video, is a really good analisis, and a deep exploration on the political side of the problem, not so complete on the science behind this and i want to make a few points that you need to know. Is part of the solution, and that is true, but is far from the only thing we need to cut. Meat, clothes, tecnology like phones, packaging, cars is part of the crisis, and we need to make changes now. Climate change is a big problem, the biggest to be fair, but the enviromental crisis is far worse than that. microplastics, deforestation, air pollution, water pollution, waste and trash. This problems are far less popular and they are usually put in the pile with climate change. The point with all this is simple, nuclear is not the solution, is just part of it. and the enviromental problem is far worse than you think thanks to this problems with proyections. We need a lot more, and we need to act faster than this, especially your country and the first world. text: Great video! But I do feel the need to point out one thing. The cap & trade policy does lower the total amount of emissions. In the EU's version of cap & trade, the amount of available carbon emission rights is lowered every year. This usually results in a price increase of the emission rights and forces companies to go greener. The great thing about this kind of regulation is that the companies that can lower their emissions the easiest and cheapest will be the first to do so, while still allowing room for industries that cannot reduce their footprint to zero.

text:
Want to know the real kicker about the tree major reactor meltdowns?

Simple safety was ignored

Chernobyl had the power to the coolant pumps lowered way beyond what the backup generators could output, and far beyond what would cause the generators to kick on.

Three mile island had coolant leak out because a pressure valve was left open, causing the meltdown.

TEPCO (the company in charge of the Fukushima reactors) admitted they failed to follow basic safety, the backup generators were stored BELOW the reactors and just above sea level, meaning once the tsunami flooded the plant, the generators became waterlogged.

Long story short, make sure you fallow all safety procedures, and your local nuclear reactor won‚Äôt blow up

text:
I'm definitely late to the game with this comment but their is an upcoming technology that I'm just not hearing enough of that would definitely help a lot with our current energy crisis and that technology is Small Modular Nuclear reactors. Whenever someone talks about establishing nuclear energy as a clean energy source, it has become more and more popular for people to mention thorium reactors and liquid salt reactors. There is just one huge problem, thorium reactors are still very much so in between experimental phases of development; that is if anyone is still researching it at all. If I'm not mistaken, there have been working experimental thorium reactors in the 60's but other than that, the technology would require at least another 3 to 5 years of development before we could confidently use it as a main source of clean energy. While thorium itself is a Molten salt reactor, MSR's as a whole don't have this problem. In fact the U.S., as well as other countries, have already used non-thorium based molten salt reactor power plants for public commercial use.  But MSR's still pose an issue that nuclear energy as a whole  faces, that being that the upfront cost of building a nuclear power plant is enormous, so much so that nuclear power has become infamous for bankrupting companies trying to build their own plants. They also cant take up to a decade to build, and even with all that time it is still super common for construction of nuclear power plants to go well over their predicted timelines. That being said, nuclear power is still so cheap in the long run that it is actually comparable to  coal in cost, but that still doesn't make the upfront cost of building a nuclear power plant any less intimidating for a country seeking to to replace its entire energy infrastructure with nuclear. This upfront cost, along with the time issue, is why countries are looking at renewables as apposed to nuclear.  Small modular reactors pose to solve both the issue of upfront costs/time and meltdown/safety concerns. SMR's (not to be confused with MSR's) have built in safety features very similar in concept to MSR's and extensive testing has proven these safety systems to be very effective, in other words SMR's will remove the concern of a meltdown just like MSR's would. The biggest advantage is that the "small modular" aspect of SMR's , in layman's terms, make them the nuclear equivalent of IKEA furniture, taking advantage of already existing infrastructure to make installation of the reactors very cheap, quick, and relatively simple. Best of all, SMR's have already been approved for use on the federal level and are actually already being used right now in Canada to power major cities. Long story short, if your looking for a fast and cheap source of energy to safely replace coal, SMR's fit the bill quite well. 

P.S. I think it is important to note that nuclear, as amazing as it sounds, will likely not be the end all of energy when it comes to combating climate change. Some countries, like Germany, have already successfully replaced most of their energy infrastructure with wind and have made the necessary changes to their grid to accommodate wind power as a reliable source. Solar energy, while not nearly as cheap as nuclear, may very well be the fastest developing energy technology. Literally every month or so their is a new major development or research in the field of solar that makes it even better, and within a decade it will almost certainly begin to rival both coal and nuclear in terms if cost. Much like solar, battery technology has also seen rapid advancement. All and all, no one piece of technology will be the end all solution to our current energy crisis and climate change, but we will likely end up with a diverse cocktail of energy solutions being used all at once depending on the needs of individual countries.

So the part you forget is all waste from nuclear is not just the fuel rods. every bit of waste has to be reprocessed later due to the effects of radiation on whatever containment vessel is used. There is a reason why the government had to insure nuclear energy and spend enormous amounts of infrastructure in the form of fuel manufacturing and waste disposal. Its because otherwise it would be less cost effective than any other form of energy. 

So your right to praise nuclear, but only because your ignoring most of the cost associated with it.

text:
I think you are underplaying the effect of overpopulation which is a thing. Every species in existence has a carrying capacity, and humans are from what I have been told a species. Can you feed that large of a population yeah, but it comes at a cost. The invasion of humans tearing down ecosystems for housing, commercial, and industrial bases has horrendous effects. If you kill off enough species eventually the ecosystem will collapse. Every human in existence requires a level of energy, so by capping population I am pretty sure that it adds up to less energy needed. Not to mention I have taken two courses regarding this exact subject and both professors preach the same thing of the effects of overpopulation. Just because you don't think its a problem doesnt mean it isnt. But there is another issue with what you have said, nuclear is not a renewable source of energy, only way I think it could be is if we somehow find it on some asteroid or other planet and bring it back to earth. Though nuclear power is an answer for today's energy crisis, its not a solid solution. I agree wind and solar arent great but there has to be more development into something that will be sustainable for the rest of human existence. 

I agree with most everything you said here, however I think that you are also underplaying some of your solutions and devaluing the expertise of people older than you and I who have 10 times more experience in the subject. text:
Overall, a very good video. You made a lot of salient points on nuclear energy, and various emission-limiting policies (such as cap-and-trade). I also appreciated your criticism of the "overpopulation" argument.

However, there is one point where you made a mistake, and that's on the viability of wind & solar. For one, those farms do not "only last a few years before they need to be replaced." The average lifespan of solar panels - and solar farms - that are in current production is around 20 to 30 years. Wind turbines do require more regular maintenance, but they, too, last quite a bit longer than "a few years." Similarly, they amount of toxic byproducts produced by them is negligible, and solar panels in particular are between 90 to 97% recyclable at end-of-life. 

And finally, about energy storage. We've already negated the "unreliability" of wind & solar with broad distributed energy storage methods. I'm surprised you've never touched on liquid air/cryogenic energy storage: it's scales extremely well, is cheap, and environmentally friendly, while relying on very well-founded technology, and no special materials. This more than makes up for on-demand energy needs. The problem here isn't a technological one, or even economic: it's a matter of political will.

text:
I feel like at least the original concept for cap and trade HAD to be to start with the reduced tonnage target and distribute from that total.  Like whether each person gets 5 or 3 or 100 carbon credits would be a simple division of total emissions by potential emitters with each credit representing whatever tonnage allows it to be most easily traded.  

So the mechanism of the system wouldn't directly cut down on emissions, the paramaters or "central banking/monetary policy" would and over a longer period the resulting market forces would act like a combination of fees and subsidies with minimal nominal taxation.  
But the whole shebang would have to start with a calculation of acceptable emissions and divide that.  If you tell me that isn't how it was proposed I'll strangle a cat.
author: Scout O'Brien

text:
@14:23
You imply that the ($44 T over 10 years; $4.4 T/annum) increase in wages won't be payed for by the taxpayer. Historically, increases in wages have resulted in an increased cost of goods and services, which ultimately results in an increase in tax-revenue as a byproduct of sales tax and income tax (where applicable).

Please explain where the money (and by money I mean monetary value or wealth) is actually coming from? I see that the implication implies that the market will pay for the increase in wages, but you can't force an increase in the perceived value of work - the market will just end up normalizing the difference, ultimately resulting in no (value based) increase in wages (and a subsequent increase in tax via income tax).

Also, how does this in any way, shape or form actually combat emissions?

There are some awesome breakdowns of why nuclear power is economically unviable; it takes about a decade to simply pay for the cost of a nuclear power plant in its three decade long life (a decade before return on investment... bruh). It never becomes as profitable as equivalent technologies.

It frustrates me that opposition to the "green new deal" is seen as climate change denial or tin-foil hatters. Perhaps those so called "skeptics" are just people trying to wrap their heads around how this convuluted, seemingly impossible method actually addresses climate change and greenhouse gas emissions.

While nuclear is a great short term option to help us to start dismantling the more immediate threat of fossil fuels, I think nuclear plants can be a issue regarding national security and nuclear waste storage could become an issue long term. When I think of Japan‚Äôs nuclear disaster in 2011, I‚Äôm wondering how increasingly worse extreme weather could affect the safety of those plants. There definitely is still a lot of misinformation and fear-mongering about nuclear power but I don‚Äôt believe this should be our long term solution. I think renewables with better industrial battery storage might be the best option if we find better ways of recycling old batteries. 
The nice thing about solar especially is that you can put panels pretty much anywhere
author: Jonas Br

text: I used to really be for nuclear power mostly because the exploration for uranium is really interesting. However, you misspresented the "waste" it produces and how difficult it is to store it. Because it is infact radioactive. But even if it weren't there is an other almost condeming factor. Nuclear plants are not eternal. Yeah, that might not seem that big of a deal but the cost and difficulty of neutralizing a power plant and closing shop is immence. We don't currently have the technology to do that in a large scale. There are many "expired" plants around the world working in minimum production simply for the fact that we can't really turn them off as fast as we can build them. Moreover, the more a plant passes its expiration date the more dangerous it becomes. Therefore, i still think that nuclear could be the future especially if we target towards fusion (yeah pretty difficult). I really don't know how to combat climate change. I tend to believe there needs to be a major change in the ways we consume, commute and think about energy. Transportation by car needs to be replaced by better, cleaner and faster* ways of mass commute. Consumption needs to be reduced and fast fashion abolished. When energy production works in abundance in order to gain profits there will always be waste that could of have been avoided. Also i was disappointed you just scraped carbon capture which has great potential but needs help regulating. For instance, olivine can be used for capturing CO2 and produce aggragates to be used in building road and/or houses. Climate change cannot be avoided it needs to be fought. We can't trade fossil fuels for something else it simply cannot be done. Even if through seer mass production of solar panels we managed to fuel our energy needs through renewables the extruction needed for such an intevor especially in rare earth minerals that showcase ppb, or ppt concentrations would require MASSIVE amount of fossil fuels. Unless the giant tracks are electric that would keep on pile pollution into an endless cycle. We can't escape climate change if we don't lose something (unless innovation saves us)

Wildlife Conservationist here, so yes I‚Äôm qualified to comment:
The fact that you moaned at wind and solar for producing waste products and then advocate for nuclear shows you haven‚Äôt truly done your research here. Nuclear is an atrocious waste of time and immense risk, as well as being the most costly form of energy. Additionally, the waste requires much more space than you alluded to due to the way you have to store it, as well as there only being VERY limited places on the planet where you can store it safely. Most countries have to export their nuclear waste. Small add on, uranium is also a limited recourse. Your documentaries aren‚Äôt enough research.

text:
I'm always appalled at the reactions people give to nuclear energy as an option. I had this class in high school called "contemporary global issues," where at the end of the class we were given options for a final project. Some of us made art things depicting major issues of the year... I made a ten plus page essay on nuclear energy. I might be a bit of a nerd for doing that, but it showed some solid support for nuclear. Oh, let me rephrase that: the cons of nuclear energy are grossly exacerbated by those in competition in the energy market, including by supporters of other green options.
Nuclear plants are literally made mostly out of concrete. The fuel is pretty much only hazardous if you try to swim in it, which in itself would require breaking open a protective casing (I'm being facetious, btw, don't do anything remotely close to swimming in spent nuclear fuel).
P.S. I like your vids, even though you probably won't see this comment as I'm incredibly late to the party. But keep it up! I know I just found the only political channel I can watch without having an aneurism.

text:
I will start with saying that this is a very good video, sumarising the history and evolution of the situation, making it clearer and understandable, and I agree with almost all it. I do, however, find that the simplifying process has left a few missrepresentation issues and, while I am sure you are aware of them, I'd like to address them nonetheless. 
While I do think nuclear power is demonized and missused, there are problems with it being THE solution to cleaner energy. The main one being that a nuclear power plant is always working with the same output, it does not alter its output, like a burning fuel one could. Meaning you cannot respond to different energy needs, peaks and so, without hugely overproducing. Of course, maybe we will have a way to store the excess energy, but as you said, this is more about what we can do now, and that tecnology may come, if ever, quite far into the future. Increased se of nuclear, however, could lead to enhanced innovation and research on it which can be an avenue to untold solutions, so not disagreeing with the need to capitalize on it.
The Carbon Trading is also quite missrepresented. I understand that you are addressing the core concept, but is called the "cap and trade" system: you can establish different emission limits for different countries, industries and even companies, the difficulty is on setting those limits. It has MANY problems, and its application so far has been plagued by misscalculations, overestimations due to lobbying and political preasure, as well as an overall lack of ambition. It has shown some progress recently in EU, however, recently, but the truth is that this "inetrnalisation" of emissions may always require someone to need to produce emissions and that kinda compromises it in the long run.
I'll also say that the simplification of Biomass energy is... understandable, and not technically incorrect, but runs teh risk of making a less informed individual that's all tehre is to it. While its current use and potential is minimal, the use of bio-energy (and I understand that you were probably working with a limited scope of the "biomass" term) can have some future. Biodiesel, while controversial for teh use of crops, works fine as a fuel substitute, and further research into what are called "third generation bio-fuels" can lead to ways to use vegetation or biological waste to produce fuel. There's more to it than just "burning wood". I do understand the simplification for the sake of time and because relying on this potential solution while tackling the current crisis is pretty much delusional right now.
Sorry for the long comment, if anyone reads it. Nice video though.

text: Fair enough, however, climate change also has costs associated with it. Increasingly extreme weather (stronger hurricanes, more frequent and longer lasting drougt etc. but also more extreme and longer lasting cold snaps/heat waves requiring more extensive use of heating/air conditioning respectively) are already costing governments and individuals around the world loads of money, which, if mitigated (partially via nuclear) is an indirect ROI for alternative (to fossil fuel) energy sources. Naturally, I don't know whether that would nullify the extra cost or whether there are more factors to consider that make nuclear more or less expensive (although I'd bet there are). I'd really like to see a proper study on this (an economic/climate science study that puts an estimated $ amount on the savings from greenhouse gasses not emitted), although the link might be too indirect for anything conclusive. Even disregarding all this, as countries start building more nuclear power plants and giving out subsidies for them, innovation is likely to come in and drive costs down quite a bit. In the end, while this is moreso my own stance on the matter, personally I wouldn't mind paying a bit more (within reason) per kWh for clearner energy, because dealing with climate change is just that important.

text:
The term "climate change" is whole-heartedly endorsed by environmentalists. It's use predates Frank Lutz's memos of the late nineties. In 1975 Wallace Broecker published the paper, "Climate Change: Are We on the Brink of a Pronounced Global Warming?" He is generally credited with popularizing the term "global warming." The Journal "Climate Change" was launched in 1977. In 2019 Frank Luntz apologized for promoting climate change skepticism not using the term.

An Inconvenient Truth used several unfair and misleading points. In displaying the graph on temperate and CO2 levels during ice ages, Gore makes the claim that the strongest CORRELATION in the data is temperature and CO2. When I showed this clip to seniors in high school, they all said this established that  the rise CO2 levels CAUSED the rise in temperature. But correlation does  not establish causation. What Gore does not point out is that on his graph temperature increase PRECEDES the rise in CO2 by several hundred years. This is NOT to say that CO2 levels affect temperature, but it does say the current situation is not the same.

At the end of this film, Gore show a graph that seems to indicate that employing certain measures will cause CO2 levels to slow and eventually drop. But the Y axis in this graph is not levels of CO2 but GIC - Growth in CO2 levels. Thus if we take all of the measures Gore recommends, we will slow the increase in CO2 levels but not stop or reverse them. This is propaganda pure and simple.

The left is just as willing to corrupt data to serve their ends as conservatives.

It seems to me that a true moderate would occasionally criticize the left.

text: Was 100% onside until Southpark got blamed for climate change denying. Unfortunately, like everything else, there isn't such a thing as good and bad. Right and wrong. Watch the Ghandi video. That video is bang on. This one? Not so much I'm afraid. His argument is just as wrong as climate denying. And just as correct. He uses the, age old trick at the beginning of linking pollution as the same thing. CO2 in the atmosphere isn't pollution. It's an increase of a natural process. While it isn't a good thing it's very much more complicated than simply reducing CO2 emissions. That, I'm afraid, isn't realistic. It's going to take a massive reduction in energy use. Ban social media. That'll help. But that isn't going to happen either. Nuclear. Brilliant. But wait a moment. It's very, very expensive. And it's total bollocks that there's very little waste. And visiting is regulated by the authorities.

"[Nuclear power is] very, very, expensive."
It just has a high capital. It produces so much energy that it surpasses it's capital in under 10 years. It's like the age old question: would you rather have $1,000 a day, or $1 that doubles every day. Gas/coal is like the $1,000 a day option where as nuclear is like the $1/day that doubles.

Chernobyl/Fukushima were very big accidents, but accidents on that scale happen very rarely. With modern technology, they'll happen at an even lower rate than previous decades.

Nuclear waste is a big problem, and one that needs to get fixed soon. If we fill Yucca mountain or export our waste to permanent storage facilities in Finland the problem could be easily solved.

-You have to recommission the plants every once in a while, or else you get radioactive steam venting, radiation leaks and at some point even nuclear meltdowns if left for too long. text:
Firstly I would like to object generally to your idea that humans can't change the earth drastically:
I think you greatly underestimate humanity's abilities, though we can't "Terraform" in the sense of turning our planet's environment to our will, we could destroy and horribly irradiate the earth's surface by letting off all our nukes. Life may survive but it would be pretty apocalyptic. I understand this is tangential but I think it's a good proof of concept that at a moment's notice, we could do this.

Secondly. I'll try to convince you that our effects are pretty significant.
It is known that CO2 is a greenhouse gas, I.e. that its presence in the atmosphere traps heat. While I agree that any 1 coal fire power station isn't gonna alter the earths climate, consider that we have been pumping this greenhouse into the atmosphere for hundreds of years, and a large amount of it stays in the atmosphere. Every coal fire power station, every petrol diesel and gas car, etc. for as long as they have been around all contributing to this one this, even without seeing the calculations, it's intuitively gonna have some major effects.

Additional Notes:
- Air Quality, with regards to pollution, is not related to CO2 and climate change. CO2 isn't toxic for humans, the issues are with its heat-trapping properties. Air pollution, while an important issue, is distinct from climate change.
- Climate change may not literally end the earth, I'm assuming that's what you meant by "biosphere ending super civilization", but mass extinctions aren't fun and crap tonnes of consequential human death isn't fun, our civilization may survive but I'd rather life not be super unpleasant in future.
author: David Capes

text: ¬†@VeryEvilPettingZoo¬† My skepticism comes from a lack of data. Climate changes are events measured in the millions of years and we only have the data from ~the last 100-150 years. We have too little data to make any judgement about current climate change
author: Merik Malhads

text:
¬†@David Capes¬† The data about greenhouse gases effecting global climates is shaky. There is indeed a correlation between atmospheric CO2 and periods of higher temperature in the earth's geologic history but I don't think we understand the atmosphere well enough to make such generalized statements on causation.

Also I know that air pollution is still a massive issue, I'm not at all saying that it is trivial or that our greenhouse gas emissions aren't worth investigating further cause mainly the way we figure out what we've done wrong is seeing the consequences too late. What I am rather annoyed with is that so much focus goes into the assumptive unproven sciences while we have very obvious and definitively proven problems like: a continent of garbage in the ocean; massive deforestation and habitat destruction; and, migration disruption due to impassible infrastructure like highways and shipping lanes. 

I'm not saying that human assisted climate change isn't a thing, I just think we need far more investigation before we conclude that we're the lions share of the problem. Besides, why should we dictate which direction the climate is heading in? It's possible this warming period is totally natural and that we're just not help or hurting things.

I also find it comical that just raising doubts about data and conclusions causes such a defensive response. Consensus is the single largest killer of good science these days.

text:
Hey, I studied physics, did a huge project on this stuff, and now I'm getting my master's in energy engineering. Here on my thoughts on what you said:

- A big criticism of Al Gore's movie is that Al Gore and his father come from big fossil fuel money. He is a bit hypocritical. Ya know who else comes from fossil fuel money? Gavin Newsom and former governors of CA Jerry Brown and his dad, Pat Brown. The Browns were able to prevent nuclear plants from being built in the state. Now Diablo Canyon is the only one left, and CA's emissions are not looking great. They also created a monopoly for Indonesian oil in CA. Jerry appointed Getty family trust administrator, William Newsom, to the state appeals court. Newsom was able to keep taxes low for oil. Now his son is in office as governor. Something to think about...

- Cap-and-trade and Emissions Trade Schemes (ETS) and carbon taxes have been proven not to work. They only hurt the everyday man, not the corporations they were aimed at, b/c the people end up paying higher prices and taxes. Take Europe, which has an ETS, it's facing an energy crisis and has been for some time. Europe is seeing more deaths b/c people cannot sufficiently heat their homes.

- No, developing nations are not "allowed to build coal plants." First, it depends on the country's resources. Second, when the US and Britain industrialized, we did not have the UN and the World Bank controlling our resources. Intl orgs control the resources in developing nations, effectively holding them back, so they don't make the same "mistakes" as the industrialized nations. Environmental and conservation groups like Greenpeace and the Sierra Club also have a long list of preventing the construction of plants and dams that could provide power to entire nations b/c they don't want to disrupt the ecosystems or they want the natl parks for tourists. In fact, the very existence of natl parks in many African countries hurts the people: they take away from their farmland, and thus, they impede on the people's ability to grow enough food for themselves and develop.

- The Green New Deal, AOC, Greta Thunberg, Bernie Sanders are explicitly anti-nuclear. They push and push for solar and wind, but that kind of energy will put us as modern nations back. Bernie Sanders had a nuclear plant in VT shut down, promising a 25% reduction in emissions, but the state had to rely on fossil-fueled energy from neighboring states and emissions rose 16%.

- Nations shift energies in a very clear pattern: biomass, coal, oil, natural gas, nuclear. It is unfair and impractical to force developing nations to leapfrog to renewable energy. Nuclear is the only clear solution, but so is allowing developing nations to industrialize free from the restrictions we, developed nations, have placed on them.

text:
You're missing the point on cap and trade. If my neighbor and I put out 10 units total, that puts a cap on emissions. It is assumed that the output before the cap and trade system was more than 10. And it can be lowered to less than 10 in the future.

If he has a bigger house, then he is kind of locked into a larger carbon footprint for years. He can reduce emissions by 10% and pay me for the credits. Maybe I can reduce my emissions by 20% and collect money for the credits. Forcing both of us to cap our individual emissions to the same level would be very difficult for him, and would mean I wouldn't have to reduce my emissions at all.

text:
Gotta be honest, you almost lost me at the beginning, but I do wholeheartedly support your conclusions. You didn't pull any punches when talking about nuclear, coal, wind, or solar, and while you did underplay just how big a step up natural gas is from coal (I mean, even petroleum products are a massive step up from coal, it's not a hard thing to top), you clearly understand the most important things about this debate. As an engineer, I can wholeheartedly support your message.

All that said I have serious reservations about climate science (whether we call it global warming or climate change), because while it is happening there are heaps of money being used by unscrupulous actors to influence the science. 'Carbon colonialism' isn't just an international thing, big companies in the US have a far easier time meeting emissions standards than small ones, and can effectively choke out competition by lobbying for more stringent regulations. Climate alarmism helps big businesses to get these standards passed, and not coincidentally many of these studies are sponsored by large companies. Combine this obvious money trail with the wildly disparate figures from so many of these studies, and I think it's fair to be skeptical.

You also have a very Eurocentric and deterministic view of industrialization, one that simply put does not conform to reality. Modern developing countries do not need to go through the same industrial revolution that the US and Europe did, because they have access to a far greater base of knowledge and technology that we did during our industrial revolution. More importantly, that's not what they're doing anyways. China and India aren't polluting to provide for the needs of their people, they're doing it to provide low cost consumer goods to Europe and the US. They won't stop ramping up production when their pollution level allows them to reach western standards of living, they'll stop when the demand in western countries for cheap goods is met.

This is actually the most insidious part of the 'carbon colonialism' you mentioned. People in China and India are suffering from the environmental and health effects of shouldering what would normally be OUR pollution, and the wealth generated from all this pollution remains mostly concentrated in the hands of the wealthy elite. I'm sure you don't support trickle down economics, so why you seem to think the best way to help the lower classes in China and India is to allow their corporations to pollute more so they can make more money is beyond me. Fact is that those carbon emissions are killing them in droves, and you should be just as worried about them polluting over there for their sake as you are about it for ours.


Good video, but you're missing some major parts of the puzzle. Follow the money.

text: I agree with you opinion of cap and trade as an international solution, but I think it would work at a national level. Cap and trade incentivizes companies to develop cleaner ways of producing their widgets because a) having to buy extra credits eats into the bottom line and b) selling excess credits can be a profitable revenue stream. Over time, the polluters will go out of business and the cleaner companies will gain market share. The keystone of cap and trade is setting the right initial cap and then reducing the cap over time.

text: I agree with you opinion of cap and trade as an international solution, but I think it would work at a national level. Cap and trade incentivizes companies to develop cleaner ways of producing their widgets because a) having to buy extra credits eats into the bottom line and b) selling excess credits can be a profitable revenue stream. Over time, the polluters will go out of business and the cleaner companies will gain market share. The keystone of cap and trade is setting the right initial cap and then reducing the cap over time.

text:
climate change did not used to be called global warming. climate change was the original name. to the best of my knowledge the earliest peer reviewed scientific papers with climate change in its title was published in 1896. and since then there have been many uses of the term climate change, many of them since before Al Gore first used the term global warming during his presidential campaign. in 1989 Margaret thatcher called for a global treaty on climate change and when she did she used the term climate change. the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change or IPCC for short was formed in 1988 and it was formed under that name.

climate change simply means that the climate, the temperature of the entire world, changes. if the temperature goes up then it's called global warming. if it goes down it's called global cooling. the widespread use of the term global warming in the early 21st century was something like a fad. once that fad died out most people just returned to calling it climate change.

text: "Pesticides are not safe for human consumption" is a gross generalization and an irresponsible comment.  As with all things, the dose makes the poison.  It would be nice if we lived in the Garden of Eden where there were zero pests, but we live in the real world and pesticides are needed if we want to have a safe, abundant food supply.  Even if pesticides cause a slight uptick in health issues for occupational exposure (and I am not conceding that they do), getting rid of pesticides is a good way to have a third of the world's population - mostly poor children - starve to death.

text:
They used to be not so safe, in the late 80s and early 90s. And not because the tecnology didnt exist, but because plants were build to be profitable. Depending on the type of reactor, you can actually get very little waste, but the first reactors were of the Light Water type. Simpler to build, they produced a lot of waste, and containment tecnology was not strong enough yet to withstand the Helium gas pressure from rupturing containers (when spent fuel decays it produces helium nucleai, which over a time produce enough gas pressure to fracture concrete)

Luckily now that's not a worry, but you have to understand, during the cold war and before the economic boom of the 90s, the US was not into building sustainable stuff. Back in the day, it was a reasonable fear. Over time, third and 4th generation reactors can feed from that waste, so now containment is not an issue either.

Regarding proliferation... well, diplomacy is key, indeed. Treaties, international banking and prestige are tools that help keeping agreements from collapsing. Trump kinda doesnt help to that point. When other countries dont look at you as a figure to be respected or as a relevant international actor, they tend to stop listening to you. The US has to work hard to stay relevant, because with the foreign policy you guys have been having during the last decades, its a miracle the world still respects your crazy policies. Maybe your armed forces are the key factor there, which is actually a sad thing.

author: Jon Smith

text:
Thanks, for another great, informative  and thought provoking video! There are some problems with nuclear that didn't get mentioned, such as proliferation. Uranium enrichment is a process that increases the relative amount of U-235 isotope that is useful in the fission process, however this same process can be used to create weapons grade material. An intentional attack using nuclear weapons is a scary thought which I think can put some people off the idea.

 Unfortunately, I believe some would take advantage and play on those fears for their own agenda and the threat can be exaggerated (eg check out John Oliver, Iran Deal). Weapons grade uranium must be enriched to a much higher level (>90% instead of 3-20%) which is a significant difference, international enrichment facilities can be used to supply fuel to nation states without allowing them access to the enrichment technology and since you were talking mainly about US climate policy and the US already has plenty of nukes, there's not as much of an argument here against more nuclear plants in the US.

 Another issue with nuclear power is the waste material, it is, in ways, much more hazardous than green house gases. Atmospheric CO2 levels have a bit to go before it become harmful for humans to breathe, but touching or just being near radioactive material can cause radiation sickness. Of course this ignores the larger impact of heightened CO2 levels in the atmosphere such as rising tides / displaced residents / fish etc, but where CO2 can be reduced from the atmosphere with forestation efforts, a small, but arguably significant, amount (~3%) of waste is deemed High Level Waste, and needs to be disposed underground for thousands of years.

 This is a very small amount by volume when bearing in mind nuclear already has a brilliantly low waste output rate, and, when handled properly with modern technology and effective storage and disposal techniques, the risk is substantially mitigated to the point that it is, as you say, significantly less dangerous that other forms of power generation. It is also true that other industries create dangerous pollutants that can last indefinitely such as cadmium and mercury.

 I think it definitely seems like Nuclear would be great for buying us a bunch more time at least, which is what we desperately need right now, but I'd be interested if anyone had any thoughts on these talking points and whether they hold water?

text:
To replace all of the existing carbon burning electricity producing plants in the world with nuclear power stations would require a new reactor coming online every day for the next 40 years! That is almost 15,000 new nuclear reactors. Does this guy (who ironically calls himself "Knowing Better") have any idea how hard it is to get just one reactor past regulations and inspections and up and running? And the cost?

Edit: Also, fissionable uranium is not a renewable resource. In fact, comparatively speaking, it is a scarce "heavy earth" element. It would run out fast if we started converting to a nuclear fission energy based world. There is the promise of nuclear fusion, but so far a sustainable fusion reaction has not been demonstrable. It is not a proven science. Sometimes science can't deliver on its promises.

author: agentst0ne

text:
I would like to see an expanded discussion of nuclear power as a solution to decarbonizing the American electricity grid. We should discuss the history and safety record of nuclear power. We should discuss the accidents that have happened and how passive cooling in modern reactor design addresses these scenarios. I‚Äôd like to specifically see explore the most immediate designs that are closest to being ready for rapid scaled deployment. One of these is the NuScale power module. We should talk about how many of these we need (I recon we need about 5500 NSPM units to replace fossil fuel). How many days would it take to manufacture these? What if the NRC granted site licenses to all existing coal and natural gas plants to convert the plant to use a NSPM? Could the existing electric generators be re-used? After all they merely turn steam into electricity. Why not just provide the steam in a different way?

Some in the pro-nuclear camp favor switching to Thorium. While I agree that continuing to research Thorium is a good idea, you underestimate the research necessary to bring Thorium reactors to market. Uranium plants already exist and are already plenty safe. Let‚Äôs deploy Uranium SMRs now. Thorium may catch up and be a better solution someday (and ultimately may be more profitable to operate) but we need to solve climate change now. Modern SMR designs are plenty safe. 

The main objections I hear about nuclear are:

1. We don‚Äôt need it (because solar is getting cheaper). 
This is false because you are talking about subsidized solar that is unreliable. The electricity is coming from natural gas a lot of the time. 

2. It is too expensive. 
The only form of electricity that is actually cheaper when not subsidized is natural gas from fracking. And even that is only true because you allow the waste to go into the atmosphere. To compare this fairly you need to add in the cost of climate change to the cost of natural gas, plus the other environmental costs from fracking. 

3. We don‚Äôt have a way to dispose of the waste. 
Again, this is both not really true AND holds nuclear to a higher standard than most other electricity sources AND overstates the problem of nuclear waste. Nuclear waste in this context is used fuel assemblies. After they have been cooled, They go into dry cask storage. We aren‚Äôt anywhere close to running out of space for them. The amount of material is tiny compared to waste from any other source except hydroelectric and it is contained. Second, there are many uses for this material such as reprocessing, or using it as fuel in an IFR reactor. 

4. Fear of accidents
The accidents that have happened in the west (Fukushima and Three Mile Island) are both addressed with passive cooling designs. Total fatalities in those two accidents: zero. Are there other accidents that could happen? Sure. But there are accidents that happen with any form of energy including wind and solar. I suggest you compare the deaths likely to be caused by nuclear energy to the deaths likely to be caused by climate change. It‚Äôs no contest that nuclear is preferable. 

We need to do use nuclear to decarbonize the electric grid right away so that we move onto the other challenges - what I would call the second tier of challenges. We produce a lot of carbon and green house gases from things besides making electricity. Electricity is just the biggest source. The second one is cars. After that comes cargo ships, home heating oil, jet planes, and industrial heat (like in blast furnaces). And if we stop using oil, we will stop having cheap plastic and we need to find sustainable substitutes for plastic in any case. Like I said. Lots more issues once we solve the grid. We need to go with a solution for the grid we KNOW will work - not spend the money on pie in the sky crap that will leave us reliant on natural gas.

text:
This was a VERY inaccurate assessment of "Clean Coal" (more accurately referred to as CCS). CCS can capture upwards of 90% of CO2 emissions from coal or oil plants, making it valuable for energy models like Germany's where they rely on fossil fuels to fill the gaps in renewable generation. The problem with CCS is NOT that it doesn't work, it's that it is expensive and therefore rarely an economic choice.

Edit: Nuclear is totally the way to go though whenever it is practical.

No really, why does no one ever talk about coal ash? When you burn a bunch of coal, it leaves ash behind. Yeah, that's right. Coal power plants produce slightly radioactive chemical waste. Ouch.

text:
Well, compared with the mean of CO2 concentrations on Earth for most of the history of life, we are still at a relatively low point. Yes, compared with 100,000 years ago, we have more GHGs but remember, climate data only stretches back that far. And if you know your paleontology, you'll know that was right around the last Ice Age. By contrast, in the time of dinosaurs, CO2 concentrations were several times higher than today and the mean temperature was still about 5 degrees centigrade higher.
My point is, yes the climate is changing, but it always will. We can decide whether it is our job to cling onto the static image of the world that we want it to be, or acknowledge and adapt to a new equilibrium.

text:
KB I agree that climate change is 100% happening and has massive catastrophic effects but in the first 30 seconds you belittle the deniers as literally ‚ÄúGo away, the adults are talking‚Äù. This does nothing to help anyone.

Like most issues, a large majority of people who are deniers/skeptics are normal people like you and me and have the opinion because of gradual influences from the Internet, TV, and media in general, or because it‚Äôs what their friends think (who were influenced by the media themselves). 

People become more and more echo chambery and hostile to new opinions because of the insults thrown around casually. If someone or some group constantly insulted you for liking X over Y, you‚Äôre ingrained to dislike anything they say, especially related to Y.

It‚Äôs a self fulfilling prophecy where the initial few people start calling the other side stupid, then the other side responds that you need a high IQ to be in line with their ideology, and it goes on and on and on. *The initial drops of toxicity evolves into a two-way tsunami*.

Look at the current US political climate. It‚Äôs almost impossible to do actual research on President A‚Äôs opinion on regulating the kitty litter industry or that rumor that Governor B secretly supports increasing the budget for state-drawn cartoon pron. Everything is completely toxic and sensationalized.

The only proven working way to even attempt to fight mass misinformation, is to tell them (without insulting them directly) that they are incorrect and presenting the facts from a verified, reputable source and explaining the reasons of it. This is how the CDC is dealing with the ‚ÄúBackstreet Boys Reunion Tour‚Äù misinformation right now.

TLDR: Insulting people who oppose your opinion hurts your argument to them. Not being mean means you actually have a chance at convincing them.

text:
@knowing better I don't know if you read these or not, but I just want to point out to you that the issue with over population is NOT the number of people. The issue is consumption of energy and materials. Let me put it this way, do you think a poor farmer in China consumes the same amount of energy and resources as an average American? So what happens when the economy of China improves, the poor farmer becomes middle class and wants the same level of comfort and luxury as western people?

Do you see the issue now? Even with the same number of people on earth, if everyone adopts a western lifestyle (food, travel, comfort, transportation, etc) there would not be enough resources on earth to sustainably satisfy this demand.
And you can't tell other people to live in their huts or shouldn't improve their living standards (with the associated increase in energy and resource consumption). That's why the only real alternative is population control and reducing our own consumption. 
You might still disagree with this statement but give it a few years and we shall see then.

text: Hey so I have a degree in chemical engineering, studied the energy sector as my concentration, and have a minor in economics. I'm not an expert, but I generally have a good understanding of most American federal policies that affect the energy sector. The explanation of the cap and trade system is quite terrible in this video. For example, the cap and trade system actually did cause a net reduction in pollution. The video overlooked that the amount of caps in the market were actually reduced annually. This meant that the total amount of pollution companies could commit did decrease and the amount of cap tradeable were limited. This also caused the caps to gain a price as determined by the markets supply and demand interaction. This price meant that high polluters would see a reduction in profits (from buying caps), while low polluters would see an increase in profit (from selling caps). This incentives companies to find methods to reduce pollution and the incentive increases as the supply of caps reduces causing higher cap prices. Also, the system gave low polluters extra funds which they could hopefully use to further pollution reduction methods. All without the introduction of any new taxes. However, the system didn't feel strong for many environmentalist which caused them to not support, reform, or protect it, while corporatist were lobbied into trying to sabotage the programming by messing with the planned cap supply reductions.

text:
Nuclear has another issue that is bot addressed in this video, it is inelastic. That means that it can barely change its energy output without shutting down. On the other hand the energy consumption is very variable, at 3am there is much less consumption than at 8am for example. This means we have peaks (more than average) and valleys (less than average), if we had all of our generation throughout the day in nuclear we would need something to fill the peak and something to absorb the energy in the valley (otherwise you destroy the grid)

We cannot have just nuclear, its not the holy grail of energy, we need a combination of sources such as nuclear(rigid and cheap) + renewable (more flexible) + storage like pumping hidro stations (extremely flexible and can absorb over production). Even then we might need something even more flexible like diesel engines or batteries.

Tldr, just nuclear is not good, we need a combo

text:
Your argument shouldn't depend on subscribing to climate change. 

First you dismiss whatever percent the climate-deniers are, then argue that the U.S. has succeeded in previous clear objectives, and despite efforts to undermine this agenda, climate change is real so we need to. 

It starts out conceding that the "deniers" are a lost cause, spend 80% of the video persuading people who already agree and only then do you spring upon them the N word (which I'd first been annoyed that you might scoff at nuclear, then 2/3 through began hoping you would and 3/4ths was relieved that I knew you had to support nuclear). 

But WHY spend so much time on the things you don't have to persuade them on, so little on the part so many people are irrational about (nuclear). And accept as foregone conclusion that everyone who's a conservative rejects climate change. (Hint: Many have come around, they just don't think it's practical WITHOUT nuclear now). 

To that point, you also bifurcated between a "FACT or a THEORY' as though a theory graduates to become a fact or vice versa. There's no path for either to become the other. A Theory is the highest status for claims, as it's comprised of facts which yield explanatory statements to describe all the evidence. I.e. The... Theory of Evolution..? Another frustration of mine is when people treat the term Theory as though it's a pejorative in opposition to a claim's veracity when it's the exact opposite.

In fact, IF we actually had a THEORY to describe the FACT of Global Warming ....in the same way that we have a Theory (called Natural Selection in this case..?) to describe the FACT of Evolution (that organisms change over time and those changes accumulate) ... the 'deniers' would be unable to. Achieving the exalted status of Theory would have provide attributes as yet lacking in GW or Climate Change which would allow predictions. When you can predict things it's impossible to refute them. The only reason Evolution fails to persuade them is because it's in direct conflict with their religious tenants and bc Evolution involves retrodiction, not prediction. Or at least not in the way Religious people would want ... (like telling them which species something will become).

FEATURES OF A SCIENTIFIC THEORY: 
- Explanatory statement that fit ALL of the evidence
- No extraneous parts.
- Falsifiable statements (see: Carl Popper & Falsification // Testability)
- Tendency towards Parsimony- Enable hi-fidelity Predictions.

Specifically, Climate Science lacks the clarity to be FALSIFIABLE, as they have no model WHATSOEVER describing the changes we can expect without being wrong thus far by massive margins. All validation attempts with models have been wildly ridiculous. (Look in to Bayesian Statistical Models for Climate Predictions). 

To be a theory, you'd be able to make PREDICTIONS which have error margins that are quantifiable without being laughable. Accurate predictions makes denying very difficult. Take evolution: The Religious Right rejects it bc it rejects deep time (ostensibly). As they appear to accept change (like antibiotics which stop working, which cannot be refuted) the most basic meaning of evolution, change over time. But they reject sufficient time for the kinds of changes and argue it could only have been the Still-Deistic-Process ... directed change. But in fact, we can predict the evolutionary developmental stage of earlier // basal species would be at, proportionate to the age strata the fossils are located. And because all sciences are INTEGRATED ... they'll totally coincide with one another without either having collaborated (as the religious would likely argue).

While Religious-based skeptics or deniers don't know those words? This level of proof and accuracy are what we're accustomed to when something is demonstrably (scientifically) true. And subconsciously, people appear to recognize when it's lacking.

But that doesn't matter; because Nuclear is so good, that no one should have to prove climate science to justify that transition. 

It's lawsuits which presently make Civilian Reactors such a risky endeavor. If those potential suits could be preemptively resolved say, via a case before SCOTUS -- maybe the primary risk (10 year lawsuits delaying multi-billion-dollar investments and the interest associated which eventually forces them to declare bankruptcy, and completely foregoing the opportunities due to that very uncertainty) could be mitigated before ever needing to decide the interest rates. 
Maybe talk about U.S. and Global death rates from each source of energy, and also focus on the practical application problems of Solar ... or mention that Solar really is just Nuclear, and if they want it, they want Nuclear. Same with Geo-Thermal. 

Use those unfalsifiable arguments of Climate Change for the Left (irrespective whether it's a dogmatic belief or eventually becomes a Theory). And ... use whatever rational or irrational argument the Right will respond to: Fiscal conservatism or capitalistic advantage ... there are MANY. This is something we can all agree on ... even if the reasons differ.

text:
We literally started the problem when we could have easily developed ethanol fueled or electric cars, yes even back in the early 1900‚Äôs. It is HILARIOUS that people pretend that we just can‚Äôt figure out how to make electric or ethanol powered cars work in our society, when they already existed before most people even had electricity in their homes. However, a greedy maniacal business man, who had a kerosene business, decided we should run engines with refined oil, because he had a lot of it, and kerosene lamps only used a little.  Never mind that the engines were louder and produced foul smelling black smoke......because ethanol was about to become illegal in America, as it was inconvenient for his business, and some women were blaming alcohol for the ills of society. 

Money > environment
Money > human rights 

And yes, sadly all Americans are victims of corporate propaganda....its just that some can easily see that the oil companies have lied for decades, because they stand to lose the most, even more than the entire scientific community who stand to lose their $80K per year jobs. Its honestly laughable how dense some people are. In fact, a lot of the pro-solar and wind farm advertising done, is payed for by fossil fuel companies and their think tanks, because they KNOW that solar and wind can‚Äôt come even close to matching the power created by coal and nuclear. So they bash nuclear as scary, while simultaneously pretending to support a non-solution. People are really easy to manipulate....all of us. Unfortunately, those that think that they are less likely to be manipulated, are the most easily manipulatable. 

HBO Chernobyl, while a well made show, was filled with almost constant inaccuracies and fabrications. 

One can no longer claim environmentalism, and be anti-nuclear. We should have had an entirely nuclear grid by the 1980‚Äôs, and really clean air. Well meaning ignorance is just as much a problem as poor/middle-class people who so oddly go to bat for giant corporations.

text: Here is the take on overpopulation. The more people that are on the planet the more resources they will need and more pollution they will produce. Now if the 12 billion people are living in huts and growing their own food then their planetary impact is not as negative. But if 12 billion people expect to be traveling in cars, flying in planes and living in nice homes then the impact on the planet will be great. For one, people have to realize that the planet is running out of resources to make things. Sand has to be dredged from ocean because it is needed for construction. The idea of mining on asteroids comes from the reality we don't too many places on the planet left to mine. So the danger of overpopulation comes from the standard of living and also the very fact that humans needlessly violent and wasteful. The fact is the planet is a system.  And like all systems, it has its limits. Like we don't know the limitation of how much C02 gas we can put in the atmosphere before we overload the safety nets, we also do not know how many people the planet can rationally sustain. But the likely outcome for humans is that we will push everything to the limits until we create our own destruction.

text: I can agree on some of these points but I‚Äôm definitely agreeing with trump on the Paris accord. Counties like China aren‚Äôt ‚Äúdeveloping,‚Äù they are blatantly abusing the status in order to have an unfair advantage in energy production. We need to reach an actual agreement here with those nations and have them actually follow through with the agreements we already have on the books before we even attempt to add on more. The China issue as I call it is far more important to the environment than anything America or the west in general need to do. Can we improve here? Yes and we are seeing it already happen here, the process is a bit slow and we could certainly try to speed it up ourselves but let‚Äôs stop pretending that we are the only thing standing in the way of a green/environmentally friendly future. China and India going more green is absolutely vital in the process of reducing pollution, to write that off by saying ‚Äúwell they are still developing,‚Äù doesn‚Äôt take into account that much of this information is already there and researched and accessible to everyone via Internet, it‚Äôs not exactly hard for nations with a large tax base to build nuclear or alternative power (ie: India and China), if Iran and other much less advanced nations can build basic nuclear power (though usually as a way to hide their nuclear weapons programs) then the worst offenders who both compete for largest population in the world can do more themselves. They need to step their game up to match or even exceed our efforts seeing as they are the largest polluters by far. If we were talking about Nigeria and the Congo then yeah the whole ‚Äúdeveloping‚Äù argument makes sense but China and India getting a pass is simply ridiculous, these countries have nothing standing in the way of them developing the needed infrastructure to reduce emissions. The potential manufacturing base is there already, the resources are readily available, but their desire to change isn‚Äôt. They aren‚Äôt getting off of coal power and whatnot not because they can‚Äôt but because they don‚Äôt want to.

text: ¬†@Shae Smith¬† that would the part of the cap part of cap and trade. Say for example as a nation we produce 100 tons of carbon every (just an example) we could say next year we are only going to produce 90 and any over will be taxed. If you produced less you could actually get a rebate. If you produced more you would be taxed even more until at a certain point you are literally taxed out of existence. The whole idea is to lower the amount of greenhouse gases over time by using the carrot and stick approach. Basically behave you can get money or not have to pay taxes be bad you'll pay. With cap and trade nobody would be able to just pollute endlessly.

text: I disagree that nuclear power is the energy source of the future. I mean modern day nuclear power plants in the western world are reasonably safe under normal circumstances that would be no problem. But if the world's only energy source would nuclear, you would need a crap ton of plants, let's just say like 500 only in Europe. Now modern day power networks are only capable of working above a frequency of 50 Megahertz. If it goes below that, every single generator in every single power plant in the network will break down. That means all those plants don't have any power anymore and need to be repaired, which takes about 6 Weeks on an average generator. Every nuclear power plant has a couple of diesel generators that mechanically turn on if the power goes off to provide electricity to the water pumps in the reactor. Now, if all of a sudden the network frequency goes below 50Mhz and all the 500 Nuclear plants in Europe have to run their diesel engines for six weeks there will be at least one out of 100 whose engines get cloaked up, they run out of fuel or just overheat. That will be 5 nuclear explosions in Europe (I'm referring to Europe because it has a community network so every plant in Europe is connected). Almost every nuclear plant lies next to a river so a huge part of Europe's water will be contaminated, the air will be full of Caesium, Strontium 90, all that good stuff, millions of deaths. It's not possible to run the world with Uranium. By the way Im in Germany, next to me is a forest in which its forbidden to collect mushrooms from because of Chernobyl radiation. In Western Germany. Just say in.
