text:
I propose a Green Reconstruction as an ethical alternative to both the Green New Deal and the denialist Status Quo:
1. Enact a new Homestead Act- for every 15 square miles of preserved natural habitat, there should be 80 acres of town or city, 240 acres of mining or quarry land, and 14.5 square miles of farmland; of which there are 4 square miles of open-field farm, 12 'carucates' of 160 acres each, and divide the rest into 40-acre 'virgates'. Self-sufficiency and eating locally are not only ethical but reduce your carbon footprint.
2. Provide actual incentives to adopt solar and wind instead of using force or government coercion- allow power companies to buy excess electricity from private homes with solar panels and wind turbines, and build solar panels and wind turbines that are as decorative as they are practical and functional.
3. More Geothermal and Hydroelectric power.
4. 1-5 Thorium reactors per State; Thorium reactors are more abundant and safer Uranium reactors, and spent Thorium is less radioactive than spent Uranium.
5. Since soy is unfit for human consumption (it has too much estrogen), 100% of soy grown or imported into the country should be refined into biodiesel.
6. Torrefication of biomass for combustible energy that isn't fossil fuels.
7. Replace suburban sprawl and urban sprawl with more dense cities (~50,000 to 60,000 people per square mile, comparable in density to Paris, France) that incentivize walking and public transportation rather than wanton car culture.
8. Replace buses and taxis with trolleys, streetcars, elevated railways, and subways.
9. More rail infrastructure, either privatized like in the robber-baron era or semi-privatized like public utilities.
10. tax big businesses (ie. operates in multiple states and has more than 10,000 employees) to subsidize small businesses (ie. family-owned, operates in only one location, and/or has less than 1,000 employees); small businesses have a lower carbon footprint per capita than big business.
11. More National Parks, game reserves, and other forms of preserved natural habitat, and subsidize or otherwise encourage outdoor recreation (eg. hiking, camping, hunting, fishing, etc.).
12. Bring back the Civilian Conservation Corps.

text:
Sorry, Nuclear does sound like a good proposition; but two things hold it back.

The first is, obviously, the storage. Storing that much radioactive waste at the same site is dangerous. How likely is it that the radioactive waste will remain undisturbed for close to a million years? What if a future earthquake starts a chain reaction of the buried material? What if a foreign state or terrorist organisation in war with the US finds this site and detonates a bomb in there? These issues remain largely unsolved. The best bet I've seen so far is to use a Gen IV plant to burn the used fuel, however that still means end storage for at least a couple of hundred years. One option could  also be to melt the rods in volcanoes or send the waste to the sun, one rocket at a time. Perhaps this could even be accomplished with a pressurized air cannon mounted to the surface of the moon, or something like that.

The second is the cost. Current nuclear plants require a gigantic leap of faith with a projected ROI of at least 50 years, with a high possibility of the ROI never appearing to start with. No sane company wants to touch such a risky proposition, and neither will governments.

author: M J

text: Easy: support nuclear, everything else is bullshit. Also climate change may be a real issue, but America is contributing effectively nothing globally, it is of course important to have things like dumping in the ocean or rivers be illegal (it already is) and massive destruction of the ozone layer. Global warming is almost certainly happening and is probably made far more severe by humans (I don‚Äôt say that with certainty because, i mean, look at the papers they are all used for political reasons, mostly just due to the fact that there is a political opinion in basically every direction) from what I can tell it has been sped up drastically by humans and our hydrocarbons. The current problem is that it is simply impossible for wind and solar to take the majority of the power production. The problem is solar requires a massive amount of batteries and solar panels, both requiring massive amounts of mining for lithium and other seriously environmentally harmful substances. Wind is simply too infrequent and unpredictable to be used on a large scale. Currently the best option is clearly nuclear fission. The end goal is clearly nuclear fusion, which will take a while, likely 40 years to be economically viable. Population will cap out at 9-11 billion, people start caring about the climate when their country hits about 5000 dollars in gdp per capita, in my opinion we simply do what we are doing, and move to nuclear fission, the developing countries will do the same, though by that time we will likely have fission. I appreciate that you actually talked about nuclear, politicians are against it because it scares people, but they are ridiculously safe. I am somewhat disappointed by your insults to those who don‚Äôt believe climate change, as someone who has read the literature it is all over the place, with wildly different conclusions study to study, what I could get out of it with reasonable certainty was that it isn‚Äôt something we need to end immediately but simply a problem we should strive to solve over time (30-70 years). Generally I am just not a fan of insulting people for disagreeing on an incredibly decisive and confusing topic to research, it does no good to exclude those you wish to convince. (Also electric cars are full of shit, run a car on biodiesel or a similar net zero substance)
author: M J

text:
The issue with nuclear power is what to do with the spent fuel rods. As of now the United States doesn't really have a plan to store them. Back in the 70's they were stuck into oil barrels which were filled with cement and then dumped off the coast of New Jersey. In the 1980's there was talk about building a permanent dump for them but as of yet that has not been built.
As John Oliver said, it's basically pooping in paper bags and leaving them around your house and hoping you don't accidently step on them. Sure it's contained but it'll only take one mishap for there to be a huge mess. But I do agree nuclear is far cleaner than coal, gas and oil.

author: s45gr32

text:
¬†@s45gr32¬† Oh, I get vertical farming.
I¬¥m very excited how that will move forward. 
Highly interesting technology.
.
But until now nearly none of those firms can turn profit, almost all of them are somewhat subsidized as "experimental".
And if they can, its only because they smartly decided to deal in high-paying specialty crops, microgreens, decorative herbs,  medicinal herbs.
.
Point in vertical farming is: its simple  physiscs.
You will never, never ever get as much energy out as you put in. 
Cannot be done! 
Even only in lighs, fans, pumps and fertilizer, never mention the production of all the neccessary hardware, the energy cost will always be higher than the output.
.
It is basically turning energy into edibles via light and plant growth, and there are losses that cannot be completely cut.
So growing energy plants, as you propose, would be the cycle of putting a lot of energy in, to grow less energy in plant matter, to convert that to usable energy taking further losses  - the loss of power on that way is massive.
.
I¬¥m all for it, because as you said, its low on water use, low on chemical use and far easier to control than on the field.
And with better lights and more mass production of parts the prices will surely fall further.
.
It might get competitive to traditional farming in food production some time - If all the material cost of keeping thos lighthouse systems running drops lower than the cost of working the field.
Although that is far off given all I know.

But it will never solve any energy problem. 
Cannot, on account of the laws of thermodynamics.

So the problem of "where do we get the energy for 12 billion people wanting their living standard to rise" 
is not in the least solved by vertical farming - that just ups energy use again.

text:
¬†@joey dk¬† 
Are you simple or something?
.
The kilowatt hour price is, as the word says, per kilowatt hour.
Every unit of renewable energy produced is cheaper than any unit produced by a nuclear plant. 

Nuclear in 2019 produced 4.3% of worldwide electricity production, solar about 6, wind about 7, water near 9 - combined about five times the energy produced by nuclear. 
In nations like sweden and germany renewable is up to 40-50% of all used/produced energy. 
Much, much more than nuclear.

Solar panels - decentralized on houses, are never cleaned with water, rain does that ( i have one, I know, never cleaned it in 17 years, and the efficiency is still good, 12% down since construction which is expected.) 

And no fucking solar panel EVER gets to temperatures of 900 degrees centigrade (you didnt specify the unit there) - its dark glass, in full sunlight it can rarely reach about 90-110 C¬∞, and birds arent stupid enough to fly into a shiny hot wall. 
900¬∞C would melt glass, you schmuck!

Wind turbines do in fact hit some birds - about 0,3% of what cars kill every year at an extended study in austrial 2014-2018.

Oh - and photovoltaic panels can be - and are already - recycled, most of the rare materials that are used are much to expensive to go on a landfill, and the recycled stuff is ceaper than mining and refining new material.

Deconstruction of nuclear facilities and long-term waste storage are neither sufficiently solved at this point, and are immensely expensive. 
And that cost is not even included in the kilowatt hour price, since the industry simply ignores that problem and hopes it will be paid by the taxpayer in the future.

Showing that you either have no basic undestanding of the topic or are intentionally lying.

author: Noah Reynolds

text:
¬†@Noah Reynolds¬† Thorium always sounds nice. 
But for now its a technology that does not practically, usably exist. 
There is not thorium mining or refining network to feed hundreds of reactors.
There is no running, economically viable reactor putting out power anywhere on earth.
All there is are 60-year-old lab-notes of one test reactor that was generating some surplus, but was shut down because the engineers were not able to control salt-corrosion issues in the LSR.
Japan started reproducing the tech for the first time in 50 years  in 2016 - havent heard a peep of that process since then.

Maybe it can be a solution
But not for the next 10-20 years, until a mass-high-tech industry is built up.
Rather longer if the sole japanese reproduction project is not a success so incredibly smashing and super, that investors  intantly flood  billions into erecting such an industry.
A working science project from the 60s does not a running-ready modern mass industry make.
author: Niles Butler

text:
I mean it's no holy grail, but there are some very good reasons to grow more hemp. It takes less resources than cotton to grow, and works as a great carbon sync because of the speed at which it grows. Hemp cloth if produced the way we make cotton now would actually be a pretty decent step in the right direction, obviously it's not a replacement for all things, it makes a pretty rough fabric but in applications where rough fabric is fine like those jeans or whatever other article of clothing, car seats, rope. The primary reasons your hemp jeans are more expensive is it takes a permitting process to set up a hemp farm and you get none of the subsidies like corn or cotton.

To add to the cotton thing being able to function as a replacement for other plant based industries can offset the costs dramatically. Yes it can make good cooking oil, cooking oils are the primary reason we grow rapeseed, another reason for rapeseed is biodiesel something else hemp oils can be used to produce, and it doesn't require engine modification. So that's 2 plants we could at least mitigate the use of with hemp, can I find one more?

Trees, hemp could be used to help with deforestation. Hemp pulp can be used to create paper in the same way wood pulp is, and it's properties actually lead to stronger paper, think not only office paper but shopping bags and the like. It can also be pressed and bound into boards similar to MDF.

I mean I wouldn't be making cars out of the stuff, this isn't the Cheech and Chong movie, nor using it for biomass energy, because that's not how physics works, but for cloth, paper, cooking oil, boards, and vehicle fuel, why not? And if some people wanna smoke its spicier cousin, whatever, who honestly cares, I'm sure even the pot farms could produce some of the other stuff as a byproduct of their main operation. The question of reversing some of the effects we currently have is going to be finding a way to reduce the resources we use, and if we can grow one type of high yield plant to replace multiple plants even if some have a better individual yield that's pretty good, eh?

author: Johan

text:
¬†@Johan¬† Pure Sophistry.
Future energy needs are not defined by anybody or somehow divined , they are calculated. 
By the needs we have now, figuring in the growing world population, the rising living standard of parts of that population, the fade-out of energy ressources we use now, needs of developing industry  ect.

Is there some insecurity, some spread  in those calculations? Sure. 
Have those types of calculations been quite on point for the last decades, Yes, they where.
At the very least for the next 20-50 years we have solid data on what will be needed and what will be/can be produced. And thus we can plan accordingly so a young kindergardener now alive and learning to go potty in Cape Town or New Dheli can drive a car or a public bus in 10 years, build a house or buy a flat in 20, feed his children in 30 years.

author: Johan

text:
¬†@Johan¬† Nah, reason is :  
I really dont get what you want to discuss here. 
And while my time is not worth much, I¬¥m bored by discussions where people are not even able to make their point succinctly.

Energy need is what we (the world population) need/consume now, plus what will be needed in the coming years and decades. 
A number which cannot be known down to the tee, but can be estimated on basis of facts like pop growth and rising living standard.

So: what exactly do you want to discuss?
You spout long, complex sentences with a lot of "smart" words, but basically say nothing.
And dont really point to what is the "interesting question" you allude to.
That limitless growth isnt possible? I agree, but for now we have to deal with growth of humans and their needs.
That the calculations/estimations might be off? Possibly, I¬¥m no specialist in that field, but I¬¥m sure there will be some unclear factors. Better to work on known numbers than to claim no planning is possible at all.



If you are able and willing to clarify what you want, I might be inclined to discuss - as for now you just seem to practice vague sophistry.
author: Niles Butler

text: ¬†@Niles Butler¬† I have no ‚Äùpoint‚Äù to present, other than the one you mentioned yourself: limitless increase isn‚Äôt possible. It‚Äôs equally important, like in private economics, to be aware not only of income(energy production), but also of expenses/(energy consumption) Furthermore: reducing excessive energy consumption and outright waste is much faster than hoping for advanced technology that can save us, but only until the unharnessed ‚Äùneeds‚Äù at some point again exceeds the current production.
author: Johan

text:
¬†@Johan¬† Sure.
All those billions of people using up less energy sure sounds like the preferable option at the moment. Lets get back into the mud-huts, then?

If you either ask the people in the rich cultures to reduce their living standards, use less light, warmth, mobility, internet ect - or ask the billions in developing nations to never raise theirs, you might find that hard to do. 
Nobody likes to give up things that make life more bearable - or have no hope to better theirs.
Without massively repressive-non-democratic governance I¬¥m pretty sure that will be wholly unfeasible.

Which leaves wastage reduction.
Which is already done widely , think of smaller cars at lower speeds, more efficient heating systems, low-energy lighting systems, better isolated living quarters ect. 
There is still a lot of waste going on, and a lot of  that can be cut by upgrading infrastructure. 
But in the end waste is not that big a number of the whole need.

And all said and done - it will not be possibel to reduce or freeze energy usage for the foreseable future. 
As long as people freeze, starve, or miss any other essentials, the use of power will rise. Because people want to live better than they are.
Not to mention we get more and more people, a progression that might slow down within the next 30-50 years, but not for now.

So, energy use will rise. 
Wether you and me, sitting in a warm, light  room in front of running computer, like it or not.
Is it possible to raise the living standard of billions without energy expendage? Hardly.
We might have ways to raise them less wasteful than the west did in the last 100 years, but people moving, living, hospitals running, information networks expanding , all that needs power.

But I¬¥m not that worried there.
The amount of energy hitting earth from the sun alone is enourmous, and not even a thousandth of a percent oft that is utilized in power production for now.
There is geothermic power production, in the longer run we can go to solar sattelites.
Maybe a safe and clean variant of fission will come along extending the potential even further.

You basically asking "where does it end" is about as sensible as people claiming that gays marrying will lead to a slip-and slide so in the future there will be people marrying  five dogs.

Energy use will stagnate at the earliest when we reach post-scarcety in essential living conditions for all of humanity, not before. And that goal is reacheable by renewable means, no problem.
But that is so far from where we are now, and there is so extremely much energy availeable to harvest, that its really not important for now.
For now, making sure that growth in energy production is as low-impact as possible is the thing to do. 
Not preemptively thinking about "wehere will it end". That always only leads to "those people" who are poor now should not get a better deal.

There is exactly one hard limit to power consumption, which is how much energy  the earth surface can dissipate via infrared radiation.
But that number is so far away we dont really need to think about it now. 
Maybe the 500 billion people living here in 3000 years will have to confront that problem, but not us.

For now, we have means to get everybody on this planet fed, warm and mobile, we just have to choose the means that wont ruin the liveability of the planet.

author: KAMILA REEDER

text:
¬†@Eric Ma¬† This is an old comment, but it's still worth correcting a few misconceptions.  Black lung and similar respiratory ailments are not the result of radioactivity.  Black lung, specifically, results when tiny particles of coal dust lodge deep in a person's lungs and cause an inflammatory reaction.  Basically, certain white blood cells can't remove the particles, so the particles are engulfed in place to keep them separate.  This results in scar tissue formation (fibrosis) and the loss of lung capacity.  In severe and progressive cases, lung tissue actually dies and breaks apart (necrosis).

Again, radioactivity is something else completely!

You may be mixing up coal dust and black lung with issues surrounding coal ash.  Like every other mined product, there are trace amounts of naturally-occurring radioactive elements mixed in with coal.  When the coal is burned, these elements remain in the leftover waste, called coal ash.  After long enough, this can build up, but it's generally less of an issue than the coal ash waste itself, which is challenging to store and dispose of.  Energy companies have done an absolutely terrible job of keeping coal ash from polluting both ground and surface waters in my state, North Carolina.  From what I can tell, it's a common problem with coal-fired plants.

text:
I'm going to have to disagree on a few things about the economics of cap and trade. It does create an incentive to become more efficient, as it costs more to pollute more. 
Additionally, someone under the cap will want to reduce their emissions, as then they can sell their credits to someone else. Rather than the original ten pollutants emitted, say seven are instead.
It's not perfect, obviously, but it does work fairly well, especially in industries with disparate companies.
When there are more homogeneous companies a simple cap is typically better, at least in terms of reducing emissions.

Nuclear energy still sounds like the best option for an energy source for long term.
Hopefully that proposed fusion plant in the UK works out well.
author: Tosin

text:
So what we have here is 25 minutes of pontificating on regulations and government cram-downs and authoritarian attempts to compel this or that action or action cessation. 25 minutes of science says this and science says that. 25 minutes of some government got together to impose cram downs and regulation, then they didn't and then some other governments got together and said they would do some things then they didn't. You know what's missing? PEOPLE. Why is this important? Because if PEOPLE make better choices, then it doesn't matter what governments do or what businesses want.

It doesn't matter how much corporations twirl their mustaches plotting how they can rape the environment and steal and cheat ... if PEOPLE just don't buy products they produce. If PEOPLE don't buy those products, then no mater how much they want to rape the environment for profit, they can't if there is no profit to be obtained when people don't buy such products. Problem solved, no need to force business to do or not do things by force, nor to convince government to cram down such edicts. No need to convince governments to deny people the ability to buy products they want nor compel people to buy products they don't want. Wouldn't it be better if PEOPLE made better choices than trying to force them do do as you wish?

And, not only that, what do you call it when people want something they are not being provided? A PROFIT opportunity. If PEOPLE WANT products that are environmentally friendly, then businesses will do THAT because there is a PROFIT opportunity to do THAT instead. Think about it - when you need people to CHOOSE to buy your product, what are you going to produce? A product people will want to choose? or a product they would not like? And this goes to the real problem. Why do businesses "want to rape the environment for profit"? Because that's what PEOPLE want. People want CHEAP products not expensive products, however that happens. So when people want CHEAP MORE than they want clean, what would you expect businesses to do, especially when those two things are at odds? If PEOPLE put a preference on environmentally friendly over cost, what do you think businesses would do?

The point here is that to deal with the problem STOP obsessing over what is NOT the problem and focus on what CAUSES the problem, That is businesses for the former and PEOPLE for the latter. I know, people want to blame something else, it's not PC to put the blame on the PEOPLE. But just like you say people need to accept the truth about climate change - well, I say you have to accept what is actually the motivating force driving that problem. It you refuse to admit that motive force, you are going to have a tough time solving the problem. Witness, the heretofore inability to get much accomplished.

The problem is some people trying to convince other people in government to impose cram downs on other people to compel them to do or to not to do this or that. Wouldn't it be better to try to convince those people to make better choices? To have different values? Then you wouldn't have to try herding cats of government to do your authoritarian bidding. It wouldn't even matter.

But here's the good news. Just look at the popularity of the Prius, for example. Why is it that Toyota makes it in such high volume and variations and now pretty much all makers have at least one hybrid offering if not a number and also EVs? Why is Tesla so popular and has a market cap greater than GM and Ford combined? Is it because of regulatory cram down? No, it's because PEOPLE WANT them and are willing to pay the premium to get them. Why is it that people are proactively replacing light bulbs with LED bulbs? PEOPLE WANT them and are willing to pay the premium to get them. Why are hundreds of billions of dollars being invested on developing green tech and EVs? Because there is a profit opportunity for that because PEOPLE WANT it and are willing to pay for. And, more good news - turns out a lot of those investors and business creators are doing all for that is because, are you ready for this, they BELIEVE in the principle of green tech and products.

Maybe results would be better if people tried convincing PEOPLE to make better choices that trying to convince government to cram down on people. Just a thought. I know it's not as much fun and satisfying for virtue signaling and authoritarian statist cramming down on "businesses" (which means actually cramming down on people as described above.) It's a lot more effective and efficient if people want what you would like them to want rather than trying to force people to accept what you want to force them to accept but do not want.


And yes, nuclear. Seems obvious. But again, not PC.

text:
It's still not known whether glyphosate Is carcinogenic. Like actually not known, not denialist not known. If it is it's only weakly so. EPA and other agencies say it is not, and that's where the preponderance of evidence still points. Miles Power did a good video series on the topic. Because it was from a couple years ago it misses some significant recent studies, but it's still essentially sound.

It's important to remember that organic herbicides and pesticides are often as bad or worse than conventional alternatives. Also, their use can lead to lower yields, which means more water and land use for agriculture and even less for ecosystems. (Human water use restrictions tend to make headlines, but the other story is birds are truly fd by the time lake Mead is drying up.)

Many pests are also hazardous to human health. And pests and "weeds" can be a complete disaster for the environment (when concentrated through human activities like farming).

Obviously it's a tangle of issues and I haven't even mentioned GMOs.  There are those who have been pushing agricultural chemicals with all the criminal indifference of the drug companies that caused the opioid crisis. But just as the right reaction in that case was not to ban all opioid medications, the right one in this case is not to demand a return to pre-modern farming.

You can't cut the knot with ideological reflex responses. We have to take it case by case, just like a good doctor in prescribing medications. Almost all drugs are capable of causing serious harm when used incorrectly, but the potential benefits are often remarkable. Just like amoxicillin or SSRIs, glyphosate shouldn't be written off because it's widely misused or because you wouldn't want to drink a glass of it.

text:
Great video, my one comment is that Cap and Trade, although I agree it is less effective than a carbon tax or other method, can be set at a lower level than present emissions. Most plans like the Environmental Defense Fund's set Carbon emissions at a goal and then from there you can trade them. The first major issue with this is that it stymies innovation for cleaner practices because once you buy up enough credits there is no reason to change your practices. Another issue with this is that you generate increasing inequalities and a concentration of pollution that would be harmful socially and to local environments. Much akin to the issues with the EDF's tradable quota system for fisheries in Iceland. So although cap and trade is not ideal it is not necessarily quite as bad as you make it sound here. What you describe is actually a lot like the original plan for the Kyoto proticol where Ukraine traded its credits to Japan and the countries actually saw a net increase in pollution because under-developed countries were allocated an excess allowance in the interests of allowing future development but they traded them and so the developed big polluters were allowed to increase their pollution while the poor countries polluted in similar amounts. A very shoddy plan as you say.
Just a friendly neighborhood Environmental Science student. I love your videos and am a huge fan!!!

text:
Pretty disingenuous way to describe Cap and Trade.  The implication is that the per capita emissions "cap" would fall below the current average per capita emissions and optimistically as low as the carbon neutral threshold.  The theory is basically just equivalent to how country emissions are described in this video but on a per person/business scale.  It's supposed to efficiently allocate carbon credits to those who can best use them.  Some industries just fundamentally need to produce more carbon than others, at least in the short term.  So this would allow these industries to stay afloat while still incentivizing them to innovate and reduce emissions to avoid paying for carbon credits.

Also carbon taxes which function similarly to cap and trade but lean more on incentives than mandates at least deserves a mention.  Especially since taxes are typically more efficient than subsidies.  There's plenty of alternatives and mediations and figuring out which to subsidize is a tricky dilemma.  A tax is much more simple.  Carbon emissions are bad.  People dislike taxes.  Tax the bad thing and people will figure out the best way to avoid those taxes.

text:
I think there's another battle underneath the surface, centralised vs. decentralised energy generation. Some left wing greens see renewables like wind and solar as an opportunity to "democratise" energy generation, where the microgrids we see in developing countries become the future for everyone, and ideologically that fits in with their left wing views, energy generation can be owned by small cooperatives not huge corporations. Yes, of course you can build really enormous solar and wind arrays and keep a centralised power grid, but you don't have to like you do with large scale hydro and nuclear.

It would be interesting to see if small modular reactors change anyone's minds, but likely I don't think it will sway them. Even a small SMR complex would likely output a hundred MW or so, so it would still be too centralised for their taste.

text: I assume Knowing Better was throwing VA's budget into military spending (which is another $216 billion). Veteran's Affairs are part of the cost of having a military and many other nations include veteran's benefits in their defense spending, so it can be sensible to include it (but it should be noted that it is included, to avoid misunderstandings). Further, research, production, and maintenance of US nuclear weapons and nuclear power for aircraft carriers and submarines is housed under the Department of Energy, not DoD, so there is another ~$24 billion in that program. It's debatable whether or not that should be included, but in my opinion it should be. And finally, we have the Coast Guard. Which is technically a branch of the armed forces, but its budget comes out of Homeland Security and not the DoD, so its ~$11 billion could be added too. If you include all of those other items, you're at $983 billion or 76% or the 1.3 trillion. Now, I wouldn't call 1.3 trillion 'barely' larger than 0.983 trillion, but it's a lot closer.

text: Wasn't too sure what I was in for with this video, but at least we got to nuclear energy and how it's presently one of the best solutions we have for climate change. I don't consider myself a "denier", and "skeptic" doesn't truly cover my position on the matter. More aptly, I'd consider myself a "pragmatist" who's mostly just "skeptical" of proposed and popular solutions to the problem. Wind, solar, and hydro all garner a fair amount of popular support but without much consideration for the complete picture. To use a related comparison, electric vehicles fall into a similar category with most people only considering the daily emissions of them without taking into consideration the lifetime emissions of the vehicle. While they run cleaner, they have heavier costs up front and at end of life, as such it takes several years for it to become a net benefit. That might still sound worth it, but it's usually going to be better to continue using whatever your current vehicle is longer rather than replacing it. If it's actually time to get a new vehicle (and not just you want a new one) an EV is a fair consideration but as with most technology, it's best to hold off on upgrades until required. By doing such, you reduce overall waste, both on production and disposal, and benefit from the additional advancements that will take place given the additional time. In this regard, between us being aware of the problem and seeking more efficient forms of energy (as we have been for hundreds of years) our advancement will continue in the direction we want, even if not necessarily at quite the desired accelerated pace. Taking a look back at most technology from even the past few decades, and there is a clear trend towards being more efficient.

It's a disgrace that other EU countries are imitating it.
author: Will X

text:
¬†@Jakob Schulze¬† 7 months is not accurate. I'm guessing you only included U-235 in your estimate, however it only makes up 0.7% of Uranium on earth. Modern breeder reactors are capable of using fertile isotopes such as U-238 (99.3% of natural uranium on earth) and Th-232 (which has comparable amounts available to U-238). Then you have to consider that modern breeder reactors are far more efficient in their use of fuel. If you ignore seawater extraction, we could get several hundred years of 100% energy reliance on nuclear fission. But no one is advocating 100% reliance. Hydro, geothermal, solar, and wind should all be used where they individually make sense in conjunction with nuclear to meet energy needs. Think more like 50-80% on average. 

All in all it is more than sufficient as a mid to long term solution while we work on more sustainable sources of energy. Ideally hundreds of years would be more than enough time to get fusion working if it ever will, and if not we can probably find some other solution in that time.

author: Cullen Burke

text: ¬†@Jakob Schulze¬† very late to this discussion but this is completely incorrect. Along with your other comments. Currently we only use (USA) about 20% of the energy in uranium rods, and even then they last 1 to 2 years. Nuclear energy has a ridiculously high up front short term cost of building the plant, but afterward the price of the electricity is pennies as compared to any other source of power.in the US at least, nuclear plants cost a fortune, in part due to politicians and lobbyist trying to shit them down. The last nuclear plant built in the US I believe, was from 1970 something and finished in about 2017. Politics plays a huge part of the problem with nuclear. Get rid of the useless regulations and costs would shrink dramatically. Obv keep the necessary regulations. OK wind and solar time! Wind is really only useful off shore, it tanks local housing prices that fall in its shadows, and they're super expensive to repair when they break, which they do often. Solar is the most bull shit thing of them all. Everyone points out the toxic waste produced by nuclear as a huge problem, which it's really not, but seems to forget that solar panels are created with toxic materials! I've read two conflicting articles, one from 2018 says we'll have 250,000 metric tons of TOXIC waste from solar panels by 2050, the other from 2020 says 78 million metric tons. By the way, currently we have no idea how to take care of that toxic waste because the materials that can be reused are way more expensive to get out than it's worth. Let's not forget the biggest problem with solar panels, there's on average only 12 hours of sunlight per day per year. Most places have clouds. Clouds = no power. Guess what has to over compensate in the event a cloud goes over some solar panels. You got it, your local plants have to produce more electricity just in case those solar panels stop producing! So how much good are they doing? When you add up all the problems and energy needed to create them ect ect, solar panels are pretty much only good in deserts. How do you get that power back to people. Good question, we don't. In the US there has been a hugeeee push for solar panels. They produce less than 1% of the electricity. That's really really really useless. To conclude my rant on a topic of passion of mine, the only future that exists where all humans can have electricity at the current exponential rate of increasing population, is with a fuck ton of nuclear. Renewables are cool theoretically, but really only hydro and geothermal are good. Solar is ass outside of deserts or something similar, and wind is only good off shore. Nuclear is the best and only green option, eventually hopefully we can do fusion, until then fission is the best option without any debate. Also should mention nuclear has less deaths attributed to it than any other source except for wind solar and hydroelectric. And don't give me but radiation... Bull shit, no one counts the co2 deaths from coal or petroleum or anything else, so that's not a valid argument. Go nuclear! Also, for fucks sake. Germany is literally building more coal plants because of Fukushima. On a different note, some dumbass decided that wood is a renewable source of energy, (I can see where they are coming from but it's so backwards) and half the renewable energy in the US is wood - biomass, I imagine the same is true for Germany but I'm not positive by how much.
author: Axel Weber

text:
¬†@Jakob Schulze¬† the german government published a study in 2011 claiming 100% renewables was possible...

But you neglected to tell everyone why the government slowed on the implementation of this plan.

Nuclear plants were closed, power shortages and increased electricity prices ensued and now new coal fired plants are to be opened, Germany is a perfect example of how not to transition to green energy.

Demonstrating the need for reliable base power.

Demonstrating knee jerk decisions will normally have a negative effect even if the intention is positive.

And finally demonstrating that you are either disingenuous or very badly informed.
author: Jimbo Dooley

text:
¬†@Jimbo Dooley¬† 
sorry but that is absurdly wrong.

"U neglect to tell everyone why the gov. slowed on the implementation"
Because Germany had a coal and nuclear power loving conservative government since 2005.
Getting rid of nuclear was like allowing same sex marriage just politics, as the green party was polling so well that the conservatives were afraid to lose to hippies.

So the reason is a conservative gov. that hates change and prefers big companies and polluting ways of doing things.
They even supported tariffs on solar panels to artificially increase the cost of solar in Europe.

"power shortages"
This claim is as dishonest as they come. It's a lie.
Germany has a black out rate of 13min vs 46min in France and over 240min in the US.
Germany was the biggest exporter of electricity a couple years ago and had to support the French grid multiple times over the year.
Germany has a power demand of 45 to 85GW and an installed capacity of 229GW.

"Now new coal fired plants will be opened"
2019 and 2020 there was a steap decline in coal use and in January alone over 5GW of coal power went offline.

"baseload"
Is an absurd talking point which is either disingenuous or based on false information.
All load, base and peak load has to be provided for a stable grid. Still ppl use baseload as a talking point and if you actually read the 2011 paper, it would be clear why it is so absurd.
Baseload isn't needed for a grid, but has economic reasons. Coal(lignite) and nuclear are cheaper if they run 24/7 and that's where baseload came into the discussion.

We have to get rid of baseload to transition as baseload power plants increase the price of electricity.

"Increased electricity prices"
This is again either ilinformed or disingenuous.
Germany has some of the cheapest production cost but most expensive private consumer cost. That sounds paradox but is a fact and there are good reasons for it.
Germany has the highest taxes/fees on electricity to artificially make electricity more expensive to make ppl safe energy. Then there is a hidden subsidy in that price that increases the price for privat consumers but lowers the price for business consumers (especially big ones like aluminium mills).
Then there is the fee for the grid, which is unusually big as Germany puts most of the grid underground, which decreases blackout times but increases cost(So higher price, but more security).
I could go into more detail on this, but I hope I get the point across.

author: Will Erwin

text:
¬†@Niles Butler¬†  1. What risk? Nuclear Energy is by far one of the safest ways to produce energy, especially considering today‚Äôs technology. Add that to the fact that new tech such as small modular reactors are available (just not licensed) which effectively reduce any operational hazards to extremely minimal risk. In practice, nuclear power holds almost no risk at all.
2. The only cost that can‚Äôt be resolved is proper government support. If the government were to provide the type of support (and hopefully much more at that in the near future) that wind and solar are getting you‚Äôd see money rolling into the industry as investors realize its promise. With proper RnD not only will we see tech improvements but also dramatic cost reductions from efficiency and economies of scale. 
3. First of all, nuclear is only part of the solution, suitable for complementing a complex system of sustainable energy sources. Maybe only 50% energy will be nuclear, while water solar and wind make up the other 50%. Fuel is not a question, uranium is abundant, and you don‚Äôt need that much in volume for it to work. New tech have even allowed for parts of the nuclear waste to be reused as fuel. A long term (as in several tens of years) could even center around extracting uranium from oceans. The opportunities are truly endless, but only if ur willing to think bigger.
4. Ur arguement of ‚Äúit‚Äôs a dying industry‚Äù is based off of surface level observation and not underlying realities. The reality is, plants are closing bc the government refuses to extend contracts on perfectly safe plants. The government refuses to provide the right support or even the right regulation for companies to even think about upgrading or updating their existing plants. Often the owners would rather leave now with profits than to pursue more investment without proper gov support, not because the application of nuclear itself isn‚Äôt promising and beneficial to society environmentally and economically. Nuclear already makes up 20% of the US‚Äô power production. Would phasing it out be productive in our efforts to achieve sustainable energy? (No it wouldn‚Äôt it would be irresponsible and entirely counter productive). Frankly nuclear energy is indefinitely a piece of the puzzle when it comes to solving the climate crisis and ignoring would be a disservice to society and future generations

author: Nafiul Shelim

text:
¬†@Nafiul Shelim¬† ¬† I found a good article in which it is being said that around 23000 die per year in Europe because of air pollution etc. caused by coal power stations. Of course this number of deaths is more than the ones related to nuclear power plants, however in the theoretical case of an accident, perhaps an explosion, of a nuclear power plant, whole country sides and cities could get inhospitable, causing extreme damage to the nearby environment. Another thing is that agriculture in the contaminated areas would get almost impossible. So that there would be major damage to this area's economy, environment and people. Especially quite small countries, or regions, could theoretically destroy themselves economically for many years to come in the very (!) rare case of such an accident. The conclusion is, that there is a very important potential risk, which every country's people should decide themselves if they are willing to risk it or not.

Or, to be quick: Of course more people die per year because of coal power stations, however in the theoretical case of an accident with a nuclear power plant, the (long term) damage would be much higher than the (short term) one, caused by coal power stations.

text:
The reality of the situation is that climate change is not nearly as bad as some people paint it to be but it‚Äôs certainly something to be aware of and try to address.

Al Gore‚Äôs predictions of there being no ice in the Arctic in 10 years and all the polar bears dying have been totally wrong. Many of the UN‚Äôs climate models in the 1990s have greatly over predicted the extent of climate change. Now there are people who claim climate change will be an existential threat in 12 years unless we support their policies.

Ultimately neither the deniers or alarmists are right. The proper way to address this issue is through pragmatic and reasonable steps like promoting nuclear energy, and applying renewables where it makes sense (instead of madly subsidizing it where it is unprofitable and where there isn‚Äôt the proper storage infrastructure in place... looking at you Germany)
author: Eyeborg314

text: ¬†@Eyeborg314¬† The arctic ice is still melting, and it's still possible it could all be gone in a few years.  And polar bears are extremely endangered right now, so Al Gore wasn't "totally wrong" as you said, though his timescales might have been inaccurate.

text:
I definitely noticed the conspicuous absence of nuclear in Planet of the Humans and I wish they wouldn't have skipped it, but it wasn't some big push for population control at all; it's about consumption. We don't have to find a way to kill off so many people, we can modify our behaviors to live more within the natural means of the planet. They even referenced that Covid-19 has done more for our climate effort than all of our actual push toward "green energy," and as unfortunate as the number of deaths has been, the much bigger change was in human behavior.


I thought it was a totally valid and useful retrospective; there are two fronts to attack the problem from, one has basically failed for 40 years and the other goes largely ignored day-to-day. Maybe with nuclear factored in to their calculus the conclusions wouldn't be nearly as dire since nuclear does have that "exponential" capacity to match the exponential demand, but still there's no reason to keep ignoring what we can do to demand less.

text:
My whole issue with the modern green energy movement is as follows.
Eco groups: "We have to develop a method of producing carbon neutral energy and we have to do it as soon as possible, this is vital!"
Me: "How about nuclear?"
Eco Groups: "...um no it's not that vital we can afford to dick around with solar and wind for a few centuries more..."


Modern nuclear plants can produce the amounts of energy necessary for modern civilization without adding to c02 emissions, and if we can switch over coal and petrol based energy plants over to nuclear plants we can significantly reduce the emission rates we are already producing.


Yes solar may one day be the ideal source of energy for the world but as of right now it simply is not efficient enough to meet energy demands and produces tons of pollution to build.
And yet the vast majority of the green energy crowd continue to look down their nose at nuclear.


I typed this before I finished watching this video....I'm actually somewhat surprised we are on the same page on this, having watched a lot of your other videos I was honestly expecting you to take an anti-nuclear stance... I was pleasantly surprised and happy to be wrong.
author: Turkey Cannon

text: Obligatory I'm commenting before I've finished the video, and I will go back up to finish it, but on the South Park retraction, kindly piss off my dude. They weren't saying climate change is inevitable and there's nothing we can do about it, it was saying that older generations were ignorant and selfish when they ignored it and thus the next generations had to suffer for their ignorance, and the ending stood as a warning that we could just as easily do the same thing to our next of kin if we don't wise up and be better. It wasn't just a throw your hands up in the air and saying "Welp! too late now!". It does stand as a condemnation of people, implying we might still be yet too selfish, but that's what appeals to emotion often do; they try to shame people into proving the doomer entertainment wrong. To say the South Park episode didn't apologize is like saying Dr. Seuss' The Lorax didn't have a poignant point about climate change because the story is told in flashback in a world already without trees. To say the takeaway of that book is that darkest timeline climate change is inevitable is to completely ignore the message of hope that tells young kids change is possible if they really, truly care about the earth and want to make a change. As far as I'm concerned, imo they did apologize. Now, whether it's too late and the damage is done there, like with Bush in the segment of the video before, now that's a totally different topic I might be more inclined to agree with.

text:
The main thing I don't agree with is that developing countries should be allowed to develop more fossil fuel power just because they're developing; if global warming/climate change/whatever is really as bad as people say then this kind of solution should be completely unacceptable. Literally nothing is gained by doing this even if developed countries do progress to cleaner energy sources.

I won't even get into the loans vs handouts thing, but just say that money sent to developing countries should be used to develop sustainable energy sources instead like maybe, hmm NUCLEAR POWER. It doesn't make a lick of sense to me that every nation in the world has to go through the same exact process we did in the western world by and large; we're all human beings, why shouldn't we be trying to get the rest of the planet up to pace technologically if it benefits every one of us?? Even if you don't give a rats ass about anyone outside your own country, the fact this would be better for everyone INCLUDING YOUR OWN should be all the motivation you need.

Also geothermal energy is another potential source no one ever talks about for some reason, I don't know why no one looks into it except maybe just cost, but there's enough potential energy in our planet's crust to outstrip even nuclear if we could figure out a way to tap into it. Not to mention it wouldn't interfere with wildlife and the environment (looking at you wind and hydro) and the primary way it extracts the energy is via steam, also like nuclear power.
author: Devil Fist

text:
I‚Äôd love more info about hydro power if you have the chance. My home province is 91% hydropower, but I haven‚Äôt gotten a lot of good information about it. Most of what I hear is about land rights, and the people I talk to usually,y think it should be replaced with wind and solar which I know for a fact is not possible, usually it‚Äôs coming from a misunderstanding between use and peak use, and how energy production works.

On another note my primary issue with nuclear is that we‚Äôve created them with military and low cost as priorities above safety. Nuclear power is safer, but could be more so if we were using better technology. And it feels like every discussion is if nuclear power is ¬´¬†safe¬†¬ª or ¬´¬†unsafe¬†¬ª when implementing large scale nuclear reactors require us to make it safer/er/ or at least it should.

My family is from the area with the Sellafield nuclear site. And I have family who worked there. And it pisses me off knowing how much stuff happened that didn‚Äôt have to, like most of the things that made Sellafield dangerous were either because they only cared about weapons, or because the government was negligent in their safety protocols. But if I say something about how it affected the Irish Sea, or how workers there had their organs removed without permission of the families, (post mortem) it becomes yeah nuclear is bad. We have better technology than the plants we‚Äôve been using since the 50s we can have safer nuclear power, and I will not accept the cheapest option as a solution but that doesn‚Äôt mean I think nuclear is a lost cause, and it‚Äôs so frustrating because no matter what people want to simplify the conversation into pro and con.

I think the solution is more on the "kinetic storage" part of the story. Which you are not assessing correctly, as normally that's a term used for Flywheel Energy Storage and it's not efficient in a large scale.

Solution passes through non- battery energy storage, profiting from the massive output of solar energy in the central parts of the day,  by, for example pumping river water upstream into reservoirs and then producing hydroelectric energy during peak demands. There are many more, if you are curious about it please let me know. I'm an academic researcher in this field

text:
While I agree with the general tone of you video I do not think we should move to Nuclear.

Nuclear power is the perfect source of power... until something goes wrong.
Fukushima cleanup costs were around $190 Billion up to 2016 and some guesstimates are totaling near $1 Trillion (to the economy) when it's all said and done.
This is "fine" for countries like US, China, Japan, Russia that have huge amounts of money. Smaller countries have no hope of dealing with something like this if it were to happen.
You might say "Well that was a natural disaster", but that doesn't matter, what matters is it happened despite all the safe guards.

In terms of the left over waste from Nuclear, yes it's small. however storing it is not as easy as putting it into a football field. 
Checkout the Sellafield Nuclear site, there was a Documentary about it a few years ago. To say it was shocking is an understatement.

Perhaps if thorium reactors ever make it out of the experimental stage, small countries can look at Nuclear power, but the only country looking at those kind of reactors at the moment is China
So for now, it's something for just the big guys.

Hydro power is renewable in that it it will never run out (however it's is very destructive to the local Eco system). 
With hydro, geothermal, solar, wind and possibly wave and tidal, close to 100% renewable is possible for smaller countries, but it will take a very long time.

And finally to overpopulation, it most certainly is a thing. I take your point that Western countries had a baby boom and populations increased dramatically.
However it dwarfs in comparison to the population growth of China and India in the last 20 years.
So bad was the issue that in China they introduced population control (poorly) basically because they feared another famine would occur.
Quite simply there are to many humans on this planet. We're rapidly destroying Eco systems all over it, in our expansion/growth and resulting demands for food production.

text: Let‚Äôs be clear about something - the theory of climate change is not the same category as global warming, nor were they confounded by the republicans. text:
Unfortunately, in developed nations, Political Will is the last hurdle to access these changes. 

And it kinda gets sucked back when we're put off by grand standing politicians who either pretend or genuinely strive to transition to clean tech.

And ffs, yes we need nuclear now that incremental change is too late. But it's become glaringly obvious of the ignorance people of the internet have of the 2010-2020 progression that electric cars, solar, wind, grid patterns, and storage has made.

If every car in a country were electric, which on average use up 5.5kWh per day, most electricity grids can support millions of cars off the basis of their 5pm peak capacity. 

Neither is it said that industry average solar panels are 37% efficient with 25 year warranties. Or how electric batteries in cars can reduce the grid's efficiency loss at night, but also export electricity during the 7am and 5pm demand peaks.

These are the details we run away without. Ignorance is running rife after Moore's big stirr.

text:
On cap and trade: I think the point is to set the global cap at an amount lower than what would be released, absent of the cap. It's like rationing, but with a legalised version of a black market.

There are holes in it to be sure, but I don't think you're being entirely fair with your analysis of it. Your point about a developing economy being swallowed up by a rich one assumes that the developing country would have no choice over whether to sell their credits. They could choose not to. Maybe if they kept doing that, and developed countries were so desperate to buy, the price of credits would rise. If the evil west was so desperate to get a hold of those carbon credits, a smart developing country could sell them way above their reasonable market price and use the money to develop carbon-efficiently.

It's certainly not "carbon colonialism." Buying stuff is not the same as stealing it.

Great video!
I live in Germany where most of the population is strongly opposed to nuclear. I think it's a viable and much better option than fossil fuels. I know you didn't go into much detail with the various renewable energy sources, but I disagree with your assessment of wind and solar.
They are not without problems but you are making it look as if they are not an option at all.

Storage technology is still in its early stages, but we are getting there with  many different approaches.

Personally, I hope for a good mix of wind, solar and modern nuclear sources combined with decentralised energy storage infrastructure. 
And more fusion research.

text:
Dude. I have some of your hard facts right here! üçÜ

These are all reactionary assumptions, as if we finally found the hypocritical fallacies of Greta Thunberg or Elon Musk or something. In that camp, a camp I saw grown from near nothing that are for wind and solar, no one deeply denies the need for nuclear. Rather the gross concentration that makes it inflexible to grid demand, as well as corporate accountability. And indeed dense hydrogen grid storage is now needed, despite using 70% of its energy used to split water, pressurise, cool, store and release.

It's about decarbonization at all costs. And after 10 years of grind, all of the sudden everyone gives a shit that it's a PR hoax. Instead of tangible change, instead of homes and communities being able to generate and sell their own electricity: a huge unearthing of confirmation bias is in everyone's minds. Especially the US and Australian far right.

 It's disheartening to see so much divide when we're all just workers who have nothing more than our collective pressure to enact political will.

PoTH was starved of data and information, strawmannning tech and idiots from 2010. Sad do say, this excellent dude here only glossed over solar and wind farms. Dissed for short working lives but which have 25 year working life spans. 

You know RealEngineering, right?
No one gives a toss about how our grids lose efficiency every night. And efficiency is key. In the EU where I live, member states that once had isolated grids can trade up to 10% of their while capacity between each other. Sharing and packaging GWhs of Nuclear, wind, solar etc from Spain to Findland, from Ireland to Poland.
author: Be Low Below

text:
¬†@Be Low Below¬† There are many in the "decarbonization at all costs" camp that oppose nuclear outright. The Green New Deal, which has been lauded by so many, leaves nuclear out of the conversation. This is mostly political/societal, and has little to do with the engineering/scientific problems of nuclear, which I admit do exist. The biggest problem with nuclear power is that the technology has been left high-and-dry by the government, and no company wants to take the economic risk to build a plant by themselves. The main reason nuclear is "risky" is that corporations want short-term profits which nuclear doesn't provide, not because of potential health and safety risks. 
If environmentalists really cared about waste products and the health of the populace, they would admit that while wind/solar are better than fossil fuels, nuclear/hydro is even better in pretty much every regard. But they don't care, otherwise they would talk about the amount of waste that wind/solar produce. Unfortunately, nuclear receives fearmongering from both sides (renewable and fossil fuel) because they both know that the best solution for decarbonization in the next century, the most critical time to avoid climate catastrophe, is nuclear.

text: The population issue is a valid point though. The population of Africa was 170 million at the turn of the 20th century, its now over a billion and is predicted to hit 4 billion by the end of the century. This isn't simply a matter of "they haven't had their industrial revolution yet". If the developing world reaches even a 3rd of the average consumption and carbon emmissions as the developed world does, then it will NOT matter what percentage reduction in emissions the developed world makes. Every single American could get rid of our cars and start riding bicycles, and it won't  stop climate change, unless the developing world stops doubling its population every quarter centery. Anyone who denies this and claims to be an environmentalist, is totally insincere, or misinformed, and is more motivated by politics than science.

text:
Nuclear is a good idea but it needs to be fiercely independently regulated. Not pretending to be an expert by any means, but a lot of nuclear disasters seem to stem from people cutting corners on safety, with devastating consequences.


Disclaimer that my personal trepidation about nuclear power might come from the fact that a lot of my family has been poisoned by the Hanford site. One of my aunts died as a child, my grandma died from cancer, my dad and another aunt of mine don't have functioning thyroids all because of radioactive iodine they were exposed to while living in Kennewick. I understand that Hanford was a site for weapons, not power, but it's still hard to shake the association. Not logical, maybe, but companies definitely seem to put profit over lives, and the government sometimes does a bad job of protecting regular people from those bad decisions. I understand that there are risks with every type of fuel we could use, and that climate change is an urgent problem.

text: My dad helped construct multiple nuclear plants in the south, with one of them coming online on my 10th birthday.  My whole life I‚Äôve known that nuclear is safe but that there was a huge stigma against it.  People are scared about what they don‚Äôt understand and radiation, nuclear fission and even just turbine generators are like magic to most people.  It pained me when Chernobyl and Fukushima happened, because I knew the industry would take decades to recover, if ever.  It‚Äôs been over 40 years since three mile island, which was not a meltdown.  The US has safe reactors, but we aren‚Äôt building more and the ones that are aging out of their certifications will be shut down with no replacements.  And fusion is still 20-40 years away.

text: Your description of cap and trade is frankly wrong. It would incentivize people to reduce emissions because their is a direct financial impact of not doing so, resulting in a similar outcome as an excise tax on emissions. In a cap and trade system, the caps are gradually reduced over time, which also reduces the total greenhouse gas emissions. When it comes to a global cap and trade program, you could still structure it in a way that allows developing countries to increase energy production. It doesn‚Äôt necessarily have to be equal on a per capita basis between countries.

text: 21:40 you oversimplified the very real problems people have with current nuclear fission based nuclear power. Beyond the admittedly low risk of nuclear accidents, nuclear fissile material is hard to make and requires harmful strip mining of uranium ore of which only a small fraction is the u-238 isotope needed in the highly refined form to make fissile material. To meet a substantial amount of energy demand of the US would need a level of new mining operations to be approved that we have rarely seen in our history and could be harmful to the environment in other ways besides co2. the reason the co2 impact is so low is because it is relative to per kwh produced which is large in the case of nuclear especially as there is no direct emission of co2. However there are other international non-proliferation policy challenges with regards to enriching a large amount of fissile material to just under weapons-grade required to for reactors. Right now we're using existing plants to slowly drawdown our national stockpile. Re enriching a ton more uranium especially in the current geopolitical situation with various non-prolif treaties being violated by us and russia is asking for another "cold" arms race where countries build stockpiles of material that is only days away from being enriched to weapons grade and thus out of current purview of non-prolif treaties. Next the problem with nuclear waste is a lot bigger than you make it. While an annual production of nuclear waste right now is a football field, meeting the necessary demand will need a lot more. Furthermore there is no currently known way of well storing nuclear waste for the long term. Yes current nuclear waste is stored on-site but that is a huge problem as nuclear plants are not able to move it anywhere else due to a whole host of regulatory restrictions! Power plants have to pay disposal companies to take care of it and even then their only solution is to bury it in a desert. With many of the current generation nuclear reactors several decades past their designated operation lifespan, it is unclear whether we have a home for all of this waste because we cant just leave it there. Radioactive waste itself does not have a large radiative zone that is dangerous however it is susceptible to causing a whole host of issues if accidently released to the environment because it easily gets incorporated into the water cycle due to runoff. Only a small amount of nuclear waste is necessary to irrevocably poison entire ecosystems. Look at the effects of depleted uranium coated bullets used as part of tank rounds in the middle east. (NSFW Google search depleted uranium bullets you've been warned against nightmares) We caused untold birth defects for generations and poisoned the land with the small amount of munitions used then. Even worse the half life of the stuff is millions of years which is a debt I'm not sure our children/childrens-children for the rest of time will be able to pay or maintain proper vigilance of wherever we decide to dump it! Imagine if we were doing archeology of a roman site and uncovered a stockpile of nuclear waste and didn't know what radioactivity was, the runnoff would kill hundreds of thousands before we were any wiser. And that is only 2000 years!!! Civilizations will rise and crumble many times before that material is ever going to be safe. We simply cannot rely on current nuclear technology to solve our energy demand. We should be heavily investing in new technology either through fusion or safer fission processes with much shorter half-lifes but until they are viable our main goal is to capture as much of the energy demand as feasible with the economics of scale of efficient-solar photovolatics which are getting better the more we use them and new wind/hydro systems. Theres much more reading to be done on this subject though than I can write in a comment, I hope you do a different video on nuclear and talk about these flaws and need for moonshot level research/investment.

text:
Wow, you really have a beef with people who have alternative opinions on the nature of climate change, don't you?

For the record, most people who have a problem with the science of climate change don't think it is completely nonexistent, but rather that so many people talk about it without even coming close to understanding the real science behind it, let alone the fact that there is alot of incomplete information on the subject.  Yes, climate change is real (nobody calls it global warming anymore, I'm sure that fact is relevant), but 90% of the time someone brings it up, their agenda for doing so is 100% bogus.

THAT is the problem people like me have with it, and being hostile towards your subscribers before you even roll your intro is NOT going to help anything, certainly not your credibility.

Edit:  got 13 minutes in, and then you had to bring up PragerU.  I like your videos, I really do.  But i cannot understand the vitriol you hurl at this one specific channel.

Frankly, i just sick of hearing you whine about them.  I don't even watch their videos, or care about who they are, or what their message is.  But every time you bring them up your unreasoning hatred for them just ruins any sense of moderate nonbias you might have had.

Find someone else to pick on, or better yet, stop bullying other channels, no matter how wrong they might be.

text:
I am part of the generation that was indoctrinated by global warming doctrine.  It was not thought as a science, it was tought as fact that you have to blindly accept.  I started looking deeper into it in my late 20s. After listening to scientists of many different disciplines I have come to the conclusion  that warming is currently happening and that man's contribution is insufficient.  Science is not a consensus,  it only takes 1 experiment to prove the falsehood of a Scientific Law. If you had 100 scientists telling you something and an experiment proving them wrong, they are wrong.  Even though there was a consensus that they were right. Not all scientist agree with man made catastrophic climate change. I have watched both sides, the alarmists and the sceptics, present their findings. The alarmists tend to only present computer models. The skeptics tend to present only history, and explanations as to how the climate works. This generally proves that the models are flawed to begin with.  

First off. Co2 is plant food.  Plants are very much starved for the stuff.  If you are against co2 emissions you are against global greening.

Second. If you expect planting trees to be a significant co2 sink you dont know what you are talking about.  I think most people's view on the carbon cycle is flawed. The biggest carbon producer are volcanoes, and the largest sink is the ocean. If you think that man can compete with valcanos for producing or planting trees can compete with the ocean you are dead wrong.  To those that say "well it was in balance before the industrial revelation" I say ok show me where.  It wasnt in balance, look at a chart of co2 in the air for the past billion years and you will see it goes all over the place. 

Third there is no such thing as a green house gas. The earth does not act like a green house. There is no hot spot in the atmosphere that you should expect to see were it the case.  The atmosphere acts like a jacket not a greenhouse. Its insulation that keeps the planet warm. Carbon has almost no effect on this.  Water vapor appears to be the biggest contributor.  Ever noticed how clouds over head keep the heat in on a cold night, or how they keep the heat out on a hot day?  Ever felt the heat outside and come to the conclusion that it's because of the carbon in the air?  My point is that it's far weaker at insulating us that other gasses.

Fourth, I look at the model of physics and I can accurately predict what is going to happen when I do just about anything.  This is what established science does.  Where is this with climate change? Every model ever produced is wrong.  They didn't accurately predict anything.  Climate happens over the course of 30 years. No climate model has come close to predicting anything close to reality over that time span. Why should I believe a model predicting disaster in 100 years if they cant even get 30 right.

Fifth, the climate is determined by cycles, upon cycles, upon cycles, upon cycles. These range from the very small local areas to very large solar system wide areas. Knowing this it makes no sense that you can control all of that by just controlling carbon in the air of the planet.   We are talking about a molecule in our atmosphere that is measured in parts per million.

It is very egocentric to suppose Man has any influence on climate.  Suppose that we did have influence over it, the real question becomes what is the ideal temperature? Should we not be shooting for that? It would seem that life would thrive more with warmer temperatures. There is a good portion of our planet that is barley inhabitable.  The only thing it seems that we can accurately predict about climate is that it will change regardless of what we do. It always has changed it always will.  Reguarding an inconvenient truth. You do realize that predictions were made in that show. And that they didn't happen.  This is the very essence of the scientific method. The hypothesis made in that film was wrong. The conclusion must be that the science was bad. Proof first, then policy.

text:
I did actually work in the nuclear power industry for a time. I was only on a year placement as a student. But I was responsible for installing the cooling system (you thought I was going to say reactor didn't you) for the third level of back up generators used for safe nuclear shutdown incase either the electric grid went down or the primary diesel generators went down. This was in the UK, which had fairly recently been privatized at the time. 



A whole wave of new safety standards were being rolled in (I think the government partly just didn't want to pay for it, so they privatized everything) - everything had to be earthquake proof, flood proof and so on (everything essential had to withstand 1 in 100,000 year events while none essential was 1,000 year events). These were international standards...   I guess we can see how well they were met. And honestly, I thought the approach where I was working was a joke. I didn't even do any nuclear safety training despite being on nuclear plants multiple times. I don't think you can talk about nuclear power without how it is shaped by incentives through capitalism. 



The situation onthe UK is complicated -a new generation of pressurized water reactors (modelled in French reactors) were to be built but met with a lot of public anti-nuclear protests. Plus the government has been dragging it's feet on new reactors. And basically any UK private companies went bust due to over-exposure to the market in the 2008 financial crash (there was a sealed office where I worked with by far all the best computers and office equipment and decoration that only those working in finance/trading could use). 



As such we now have aging nuclear reactors in the UK with actual cracks in their reators that were due to be decommissioned but are still running (like they have made control rod manipulators that can steer around the cracks now - I don't need to tell you what role control rods have and how bad it would be if they got stuck). And also what can't be ignored is the connection between nuclear power industries and arms industries. 



Last year the UK produced more power from 'clean' sources than from fussel fuels - producing just more than half from clean sources (which was split evenly between wind/solar ect and nuclear).


I probably shouldn't bother with such a long comment, as it feels a waste of time on YouTube (plus you never know if you'll be censored anyway), and there are always masses of comments under videos, but I guess I felt some sense of duty I suppose. Thanks. I barely even watch YouTube these days - it's a bit of a let down.

text: I'm actually a huge proponent of nuclear power.  It has the highest energy density of any fuel source we know of yet, and we have, last I checked, roughly 5 billion years worth of viable uranium fuel on Earth.  That's enough uranium to last until we run out of sun.  On top of that, thorium breeder reactors are another option, and they're even cleaner than uranium reactors.  Plus, we're about 10-20 years away from unlocking nuclear fusion power as well, further improving our ability to generate energy.  Suffice to say, I think nuclear is very likely to be the future once people get over the propaganda.

text:
Former navy nuclear operator on the USS Carl Vinson. I 100% agree with the nuclear statements. The public is grossly uneducated or even mislead about all things nuclear.
TMI the technology was still in its infancy and we've learned a lot since then. Chernobyl was littered with issues from the start, all the way down to the design of the core. Fukushima was essentially a freak accident of nature and I think it's a little understandable that the planners didn't expect an earthquake and two tsunamis, but even now plants will be designed to sustain even that and more.
And all of that isn't even to mention the vast amount of oversight and regulation these plants go through. I opted to forego a six-digit career in nuclear power when leaving the navy because of the stress of constantly having drills ran and people looking over your shoulder. A modern nuclear plant is designed in a way that even the stupidest operator can't break it and, barring an asteroid from landing on the core, will not melt down.
Period.
