text:
Not exactly a moderate's guide when you entirely blame one side on the topic when both sides have been at fault for various issues. Yeah, the right has been the one mostly reported on for their gaffs. Doesn't mean they're the only ones.

Those "loans" as you called them to developing countries are not loans. The word "loan" implies those countries will be able to pay them back in the future. While I'd love for that to be the case, if we just feed them money to sort their issues then it leads to three possible situations: Handouts where we just shovel money at the problem and hope it goes away, Aggressively loan-sharking and basically re-colonizing them, or actually winding up owning the country as collateral. Even when not accounting for the fact that china (one of the leading industrial powers in the world currently, even with the pandemic) would be basically given free-reign while we're expected to sit on our hands and not expand or try to save our own failing local industry would obliterate the US as a world power. You actually bring up a similar argument in your talk about the "cap and trade" suggestion in regards to less developed countries. Just because the US has industrialized doesn't exempt us from suffering a similar fate if we gimp ourselves while our neighbors are provided free reign.

In addition, a lot of the stuff in the green new deal were insane projections being marketed as gospel which to live and work to follow as closely as possible going forward. That's not even to mention the extremely restrictive policies that were attempting to be snuck through with it. I personally didn't mind the idea behind it, but I didn't particularly care for the extra stuff. if there was a re-write focused solely on combating climate change in a way that would not cripple ourselves then there would have been more support for it.

Lastly: Yes, dear sweet christ yes. Nuclear power is being fought against tooth and nail by the established power companies to kill it off in it's crib. It's by all metrics far cleaner and more efficient than anything they can produce. If these facts were taught and accepted by the common people as opposed to propaganda or constant focusing on only the drawbacks, then there would be calls for nuclear plants to be built far more often.

text:
As I understand it, the real problem with nuclear power is that it is EXTREMELY expensive on a per-kilowatt-hour basis. Some of this may be due to excessive regulation (due to the "radiation, icky!" fears that the video, for the most part rightly, characterizes as unfounded), but a lot of it is just baked into the medium. Significant increases in use of nuclear power are, bluntly put, going to decrease standard of living because they are going to raise people's electric bills. That's not to say we shouldn't use it-- I don't see any realistic alternative, frankly. But it's like energy chemotherapy-- it messes you up even when it's essential to your survival.

Renewables, by contrast, are quite INexpensive, so we need to be tapping them for all we've got. And carbon capture-- while not the panacea that Big Oil and Big Coal want to make it out to be-- remains a crucial part of the puzzle that deserves research funding.

The other big part of climate change that isn't widely known or discussed is deforestation-- if one thinks of climate change in economic terms as an overSUPPLY of carbon dioxide, deforestation is like massacreing the consumers who DEMAND the carbon dioxide. Rainforests in particular are enormous carbon sinks; destroying them is an act of ecological insanity that not only guts biodiversity but also hugely increases the greenhouse-gas problem. We'd do well to simply buy all of the surviving rainforests from the countries that hold sovereignty over them (many of which, like Brazil, have shown themselves perfectly willing to indulge in long-term insanity for the sake of some pissant short-term profits) and declare them off-limits to human development; the costs of purchasing the land now are tiny compared with the costs of deforestation in ten or twenty years.

Bottom line, we're facing a calamitous problem here, and no one magic bullet or weird trick is going to solve it for us. We need to throw every strand of spaghetti we have at this wall and hope like hell that enough of it sticks.

The physical hurdles to do it with simple hydrogen are so high that I can't see it working on earth in man made conditions.

Even in a hydrogen bombs we don't actually use hydrogen, but tritium, deuterium or lithium-deuteride.

The tritium used in current fusion experiments is created from special lithium isotopes.

text:
Pausing mid video to comment here on the slight oversimplification on cap and trade.

The example would be more apt if both factories produced 6 tons to begin with, but for the second one was far more expensive to reduce emissions.

So the first factory/person benefits from selling one of its "credits" and reducing 2 tons per year, while the second doesn't reduce because it would be more expensive to do so, preferring then to buy the credits.

Next year there are only, maybe 8 credits to go around, and the process repeats, targeting efficient reduction.

Now, that is in principle. The effective implementation is another thing.

Even the principle though, has certain issues. A big one to solve is the inicial allocation, as well as the progression in the availability of these "credits" :)

text:
So if i don't believe that their will be a climate catastrophe in 12 years if we don't reduce carbon emissions to zero and get rid of planes, cars, and "cow farts" am I a climate denier?
In 2009 Al Gore predicted there was a 75% chance the north and south poles would be completed ice free in the next "five to seven years". He was against cap and trade, and was in favor of a carbon tax. Funny how you left that out. I absolutely believe in climate change. I just don't trust politicians like AOC or Al Gore with taxpayer money. I don't believe we will be in dramatic trouble if in 12 years we don't reduce carbon emissions to zero.
Here is my main problem with this video. How can you completely disregard overpopulation as an issue?? You say as nations develop, birth rate drops, and i agree with you. But it seems like you think the entire world is developed. There are lots of big developed nations in africa, but particularly in south Africa as the rate of infant mortality dropped, people keep having the same number of kids. Yes we waste a large amount of food, but to stop that you would need to go into the home of every consumer and stop tgem from wasting food. I doubt that can be done in a way thats not authoritarian in nature. Thats all i will say about this subject to keep the comment short but to say overpopulation is not an issue is the same as saying climate change dosen't exist.
Ending on a good note, i completely agree with you on nuclear power, it seems like a no brainer. In the cold war russia ran a propaganda campaign in the US to make nuclear power look realy bad, to disuade the American population from seeking this new power source, while at the same time heavily funding their own research programs on nuclear power. 
Anyway climate change is real but politicians cant be trusted to deal with the issue. Overpopulation is real and pollution from all our trash in the future will be a worse problem than climate change. Nuclear power will benifit our nation if we can only convince people to adopt it.
I think calling yourself a moderate is an absolute stretch, especially when you agree with the green new deal. You left alot out about al gore in the video and victimized him, you talk crap about south parks portrayal of Gore but they did literally the same thing with trump and many more public figures. (I think both portrayals are hilarious. ) anyway, thats it from this climate denier

text:
love your channel...
great work against climate denial...


but regarding nuclear, you are wrong, far more important question:
how hard is it to realize, that 'nuclear' is currently as strongly pushed by interest groups as never before (which means a lot), because climate change finally gave them the argument that works on people able to be concerned based on an actually fact informed basis? (like you)


it's not like someone would keep private industry from building, or running reactors, thorium included, its just that this time private industry would have to actually invest money into their super safe, cheap to run, safes the world, business model and eventually even have to take the cost of risk into regard... which is exactly, when nuclear stops being 'to cheap to meter' and get's 'to cost prohibitive for even super powers to run', which is when the business clown gets into the picture... or even worse the communist version of it, to remove all redundancy & safety in order to safe cost... what could possibly go wrong?



i am a big proponent for building more science reactors to generate heavy elements for all the purposes we need them for. all my main concerns still apply to those, but the scale of 'the energy industry of the planet', plays an important role in the argument and while its impossible to 'just make' a complex argument,  (and i am sick and tired of trying from back around in the 90's), but just for the view interested capable of using google in a non hysteria based way, it goes along the line of: residual risk, lots of stuff ignored as a factor, like most accidents happening in fuel preparation... supercriticality accidents... etc. and ends in: not a question of if, but when everyone gets their cancer and at what age.... whereby the timeline can be anything between within the next generation, to a three figure number of generations. also no one except humans would mind much, anyone else is quite O.K., with often having lifespans well under what it takes to get cancer and all their reproducing is long done before even if.


also we don't need 'nucular energy', since the only reason 'bio mass' currently indeed means wood & corn, due to farming and other subsidies. lots of perfectly usable biomass ends up in landfills. lots more could be produced by algae, on land unusable for agriculture, while cleaning the waste water you feed it... it has all been calculated through during the oil crisis and shortly there after.... one of the many things the processes developed around it yields is (as in already exists) would be fiaa approved plain fuel, viable for perfectly normal plains... only issue: 15% - 30% more cost in production (not corrected for technical progress and rising price of drilling) and the final show stopper: all the money currently bound to fossile and nuclear would have to be reinvested, with little to no risk... but still... so it want ever happen, get over it!


i stopped caring long ago, i am not depressive or a cynical but i rather invest time into things like boat building, knowledge  preservation, icelandic culture and language... all the things smart people did anytime between 300-900 in northern europe, back when civilization ended the last time. (and yes, its not the religion, you are right about that one, which took me forever to see) and you know what? turns out to be much more fun and leaves next to no co2 footprint as well.

text: I'm super glad you brought up nuclear power. It's honestly the best energy source a major industrialized country could have. I remember there was a really good TED Talk about it a few years ago made by an Environmentalist. A great example of how much more efficient it is against every other source, just compare France and Germany. France uses way way more nuclear energy while Germany uses a lot more solar, wind, etc. Between both countries, Germany actually has to use more fossil fuels in order to sustain their energy system still, while France is able to phase out a larger chunk of their fossil fuel burning, so Germany's pollution is currently much worse than France's. Also it's worth noting how exponentially more efficient Uranium-burning is to coal-burning. It takes far far far FAR longer to burn a piece of Uranium-235 than a piece of coal of the same size.

text:
You end up in a good place, but your understanding of why the climate change debate will be lost by allowing China and India to continue to ramp up CO2 production (creating an explosion of CO2 over the next decade rather than reductions even if the rest of the world reduced to 0) and lack of understanding how cap and trade would both incentive-ize reduction in CO2 in the largest polluters while boosting the economies of less wealthy nations (paid not to pollute, and re invest in clean energy which would be in turn be sold to polluting economies trying to reduce their carbon costs) needs some work.

The India and China thing is an economic fairness issue, not an environmental issue. If you care about the environment, we absolutely cannot allow them to ramp up their production when clean nuclear is available.

Nuclear Fission and possibly Fusion are the way forward, but as long as the narrative has this nonsensical blather about letting China and India pollute 10 times more than the rest of the world combined as part of the solution to global warming, no progress will be made. 

Nature doesn't care about "fair" that's a human delusion. Either global warming is a problem or it isn't, it doesn't give a fuck about fair. Fair is what we make it by helping them skip the polluting steps of their industrial revolution, not encourage them to make the same mistakes our forefathers made.

text:
Nuclear Power can be incredibly dangerous if not handled with the proper care. Chernobyl was a product of the broken Soviet system and a need to generate large amounts of power cheaply. Fukushima though, shows that not even ostensibly well regulated nuclear sectors are immune to similar issues of getting things done quickly and a little bit cheaper. Nuclear power will be critical in moving the world towards carbon neutrality, and hopefully net negative carbon emissions, but if it isn't done with proper care and oversight, then we could be inviting additional disasters. 
Chernobyl brought the Soviet Union down, both politically and economically. The cost of cleanup in rubles and manpower was immense and it is really difficult to know the true human cost in lives because of the efforts to blur the line. Also cancer rates in the Soviet Union and former soviet states were already markedly higher, that Chernobyl's impact could have reasonably had little noticeable impact on local cancer rates and deaths due to cancer.

text: Saying "Pesticides are not safe for human consumption" fails to address what actually matters: the type, quantity, and concentration of the pesticide you're consuming. Drinking a quart of Round-Up would be disgusting and bad for you. Ingesting trace amounts days after a farmer applies standard concentrations/amounts to his crop does no harm. The goal of policies shouldn't be to eliminate or minimize pesticide use, but to keep food/water safe and balance the efficiency of farms with their environmental impacts.

text:
Oh, there are plenty of reasons why nuclear power sucks. To name the worst offenders:


No final storage solution has been found, and until then we are producing something we can't really deal with. Neat. But surely you have a better idea than all the scientists and engineers since you like nuclear so much and presumably aren't stupid enough to promote a tech with sideeffects we can't deal with? Yes?


The technology has been proven to be difficult to control. Fukushima and Chernobyl are still in rather recent memory, and for good reason. While the latter could be attributed to human failure, who are you to say this would never happen again? Man is fallible by nature, as are our creations. The latter had a shitty spot on the map, but that was accounted for during its construction. Won't happen ever again.... riiiiiight? 


And the worst offender of them all: Costs. Nuclear is incredibly expensive compared to renewables. We are talking ~14 euro cent(without almost eternal storage costs) vs 4,5 (solar) and 3-4 (wind) per kwh. And yes, renewables need a lengthy and somewhat expensive system change (less than you think tho), but its still faster than rolling out thorium based plants (and cheaper too). And we are running out of time here.


There is just no need to use an inferior tech when we have something far less dangerous on our hands which also happens to be considerably cheaper.
author: Max Mustermann

author: swanpride

text:
¬†@Max Mustermann¬† Good morning from the capital of Finland. You have good points, but in the Olkiluoto powerplant (yes, in Finland) is a long-term nuclear waste storage. It's underground in the bedrock and it will be operational on this decade. So there are solutions. The storage place has room for all nuclear waste produced in Finland's 4 running reactors and 2 that are being built right now.

Also wind and solar might be a little cheeper, but you have to also consider the pricier fossil-based means of needed energy when talking about solar or wind. Right now we don't have good ways to storage big amounts of energy, so in case of a cloudy or windless day (or night) we have to have and maintain older powerplants (fossile, not eco-friendly) so the electric grid can keep up with the demand.

In Finland at least, nuclear "base block" of electricity is needed to have a working grid, and our political views prefer nuclear over fossil fuels.

Also nuclear powerplants are one of the safest means of energy production. They are heavily regulated, and even tho accidents have happened, the amount of people affected by them is nothing compared to the amount of people killed each year by air pollution made by fossil-based energy production.
author: Olli

text:
Max Mustermann let me try to address the problems you named

Nuclear waste:
Currently there are a few sites for waste storage currently under construction, the most prominent being in Finland, while the U.S. has had considerable trouble getting its long term storage site constructed because of political bullshit. I mean, the U.S. could do what France is doing and go through the process of recycling nuclear waste, which lets you extract leftover uranium from nuclear waste and could reduce the amount of waste while also reducing the amount of uranium that we need to mine and the subsequent emissions created from the process of mining that uranium, but it‚Äôs been banned by congress and there really isn‚Äôt a good reason for it to be banned. Using Thorium as fuel for reactors could also cut down on the amount of waste as it is much more efficient than uranium while also being less radioactive than uranium. So we have the ability to handle the waste problem, but politicians have their heads up their asses and aren‚Äôt doing anything to fix the problem

Nuclear meltdowns:
Chernobyl and Fukushima were horrible accidents. Not a lot of people actually died because of them, but the long lasting radiation and exclusion zones set up around the sites is still significant. But they were both reactors from the 1960s. Nuclear reactors were new at the time, and are nowhere near as safe as modern reactors. It‚Äôs like any new technology. At first, cars didn‚Äôt have seatbelts, airbags, or any other safety devices in them, but modern cars are extremely safe and will only continue to get safer. Same with practically anything else. As time goes on new technology is developed that makes nuclear safer. 

Cost: 
Nuclear power plants are expensive to build because the way they are currently build requires them to be custom designed and built for the area they are built in. But new Small Modular Reactors solve that problem. A building would be made to house multiple reactors, and then the reactors themselves would be produced in a streamlined, factory like setting, loaded onto the back of a truck, driven out to the housing unit and installed. This will significantly cut down production costs, and reduce the amount of time it takes to build a nuclear power plant. 

Fusion:
If you‚Äôre still opposed to nuclear fission, then take a look at fusion power. Don‚Äôt like how nuclear fission uses radioactive materials like uranium and leaves behind deadly waste? Fusion uses hydrogen, you know, the most abundant material in the universe, as its fuel, and the waste product is helium. Are you scared about a fission reactor having a catastrophic meltdown? The specific conditions needed to sustain a fusion reaction mean that if anything goes wrong, inside of blowing up and releasing tons of radiation into the surrounding area, it will just turn off. Sounds great, right? Well it also will be able to produce more energy than fission. And it‚Äôs right around the corner as well. ITER, a project founded by multiple countries like France, The UK, and the U.S. is scheduled to be turned on by 2025, and a multitude of companies are also racing to be the first to achieve positive energy gains from fusion. So yeah, nuclear is not inferior compared to renewables

What happens when whole groups of staff of a nuclear-power-station are unable to come to work , eg. because of a pandemic/ disease? That nuclear powerstation can go into meltdown after a few days, when the cooling-water boils off. 
What happens when multiple nuce/ power-stations have to shut down in series, because of low &/or too warm cooling-water-supplies from rivers? Ditto. 
What happens from 2050 onwards when nuce-power-stations are flooded, owed to storm-surges above normal levels, owed to sea-level-rise (because of the worsening climate-crisis)? I am sure, you know the answer to this question already: #Fukushima 
Let alone the safety- & security-points of protection from terrorism & the UNSOLVED problem of radioactive waste-storage! 
The issue with Nuclear Power is not whether it is clean or not; but its risk!!!

text:
¬†@Adam Smith¬† You're assuming that the plant would still run while it's unstaffed or understaffed. Maybe they'd do something like, I don't know, *turn the damned thing off*?

Too warm water? Because we have no way of cooling down water. None whatsoever. What we take from the river is what we get. Use some of the power generated by the plant to cool down the water.

For the flooding part, do you really think it'd flood without warning? Fukushima had warning. That's why nobody died. Not a single person. And if a reactor older than a lot of politicians can get hit by a large disaster and not kill a single person, I think a modern one would fare quite well.

A nuclear power plant is not a target for terrorism. You're assuming the terrorists would:

Get past the security
Know how to handle fissile and radioactive materials
Know how to use them in a bomb
The plant has illegal isotopes (because weapon's grade uranium is illegal, and cannot be on site)
The terrorists evade capture
The government doesn't track them by their radioactive trail

Unsolved problem of radioactive waste storage? We're solving it. Hell, we've already almost solved it already. Fusion reactors produce very little waste, and what's left can just be put in a heavily fortified hole in the ground. We've been doing that for years.

Tell me, how many people died in nuclear accidents in the US? I looked it up. 8 people, in the entire history of nuclear power, all 70 or so years. 8. Hydroelectric killed 15, also in the US. But nuclear is demonized because the big bad atom is so scary, when in reality it's one of the safest forms of energy production there is. The only safer ones are solar and wind, but they produce so little energy compared to nuclear. You can't power a city with solar, you can't power a city with wind. Only the atom is powerful and safe enough to be our future. It's the future. Either accept progress, or be left behind in the dust.

text:
¬†@Max Mustermann¬† People have already covered Chernobyl and Fukushima, as well as cost and waste, so I will add my own point:
safety.

There are nuclear reactors that are passively safe, meaning they shut themselves down in the event of a potential meltdown. The very physics of the reactor make that happen. In other words...*these reactors cannot melt down*--the runaway temperature increase will not cause one because it's designed to, again, shut itself down (I feel I need to emphasize that). The only reason these reactors are not in widespread use is because the U.S, government terminated the project in 1994. But the technology exists. And those same types of reactors can recycle old uranium. So an extremely safe reactor plus recyclable fuel, which arguably counts as a *renewable resource*? Sounds excellent to me.
If you want further clarification on this and more, check out the film "Pandora's Promise".

author: Koios Damocles

text:
¬†@Max Mustermann¬† in order,

Nuclear waste permanent storage spots do exist. There‚Äôs one in NV that the politicians have been trying to slam the brakes on for decades, but it‚Äôs a prime spot because it‚Äôs a natural salt deposit and eventually over the next thousand years, the salt will creep into every square inch of the facility and hopefully render it useless forever. We also will have signs in 7 different languages surrounding the facility just in case any civilization down the line finds it, doesn‚Äôt know the context, and tries to open it. Second, chernobyl was a string of freak accidents that led to disaster in the 70s, and Fukushima was a literal act of god scenario. You can‚Äôt guess when a tsunami is suddenly going to hit your nuclear plant, but even in that situation there are options to make it safer. 
Plutonium, uranium-235 and uranium-233 are the most common now, but thorium reactors have been gaining a lot of traction lately which is really exciting to me. 
Thorium is infinitely safer, cheaper to mine, much more common, less work intensive to purify, and also since it is a fissile element, it is a lot more stable as an element as well. A meltdown like 3 mile island, Fukushima or chernobyl could almost never happen in a thorium reactor, and the only part that would be unstable is a tiny amount of plutonium that you‚Äôd have to use to start the fission process, which means by cutting off the access to plutonium-239 in the event of a meltdown, you would effectively be stopping it in its tracks. 
Stop trying to scare people, nuclear energy can be safe, whether that is something you agree with or not. People are just terrified of it because when things go wrong in a nuclear reactor, despite the scale you can look at the consequences and say ‚ÄúOh god, the horrors! Look at what wrath god hath wrought!‚Äù Despite that, in oil and coal refineries like Port Arthur, when a refinery is slowly poisoning an entire city with a median household income of 15k, it‚Äôs just business casual. Nuclear isn‚Äôt any more terrifying than oil or coal, it‚Äôs just about putting towards the effort and funds required to build the permanent containment facility, and capitalize on the sheer gold mine of thorium that we are sitting on.

author: Roland Scherer

text:
[TL;DR - Carbon Capture and Nuclear are the way to go for now, with cap and trade as the incentive to push governments forward in this direction.]

Few things - pretty much the only few things I can agree with in this video are the statements about nuclear and about the poor state of renewables (as someone studying Renewable Energy Sources, I can quite safely confirm that)




HOWEVER:
Climate change is a theory. It's not a fact. It is a theory in scientific terms - it's backed by evidence, confirmed using the scientific method, there's no currently known evidence that would contradict it, but it's still not a set-in-stone fact. There could still be discovered new evidence that flips it upside down. 

Climate change is a better term than global worming. It sounds less scary and less pressing on paper, but is more adequate to what we're experiencing. Yes, the Earth is warming up, but it's not the only effect (though granted - most of other side effects, like increased severity of violent storms, seem to be a direct consequence of rising temperatures themselves).  Climate change is a broader term, suggesting it will affect a bigger portion of our lives than just "it'll be a bit warmer". "Global warming" also makes it seem like it's Earth's problem, not ours, which is a bit of a pet peeve of mine, that climate activists focus their activism on polar ice caps and poor little animals, something most people don't really care about. The main problem, the main reason for concern is the concern on human lives. That's where the activism focus should be, that's what more people care about. 

Industrial revolution happening in different parts of the world at different times... Yes. That is true. But what if we extend that line of thinking further? What if we extend that line of thinking to colonialism? I mean - those countries didn't have their colonial times when some European powers had theirs! Should we close our eyes to that, and allow those countries to invade and colonise other nations? Maybe we should allow slave trade? Maybe we should allow for the existence of Chinese concentration camps of Uyghur Muslims, because Nazi Germany had their concentration camps for Jews and Soviet Russia had Gulags for everybody who dared to oppose the great leader? 
As you can see - just because they didn't experience something when other nations did, doesn't mean we should allow it to happen. There are other ways of achieving industrialisation without allowing for more pollution and greenhouse gas emission. 

Green New Deal would be nice, if it would focus on climate, without diving into topics unrelated to it (granted - some economic stuff is needed, as to address the loss of jobs resulting from implementing technologies making fossil fuels obsolete, but what in the name of all that's holy does  high-quality health care and affordable, safe, and adequate housing have to do with it?). Also - better people in charge, someone who can take it seriously, act without panic-baiting, and actually work on the issue, respectfully educating sceptics and people without knowledge that have questions, without resorting to angrily shouting at them and calling them "fascists", and people able to work with governments on the solutions, not screetching "orange man bad" all day and not doing anything for the climate. 

Trees aren't a great source of greenhouse gas storage long term. Fossil fuels, as the name implies, are fossilised remains, that have been buried deep inside the Earth. Those trees would offset the carbon emissions for some time, but after they die, they decay, releasing a lot of what's stored back into the atmosphere. It's a band-aid on a wound that needs stitches, a would that without them, opens back up every now and again. 

Overpopulation argument doesn't take into account just the food, but the entire carbon footprint of a person - a place to live, work, necessities like clothes, work equipment.

Carbon capture (and storage) - it's more than a cigarette filter. Yes, it captures "some" (quite a lot, actually), but not all of the emissions. That's why development in this area, to capture even more, as much as it's possible. It's effective and cheap, requiring a relatively inexpensive  modification of existing infrastructure, while working on long term goals. Harm reduction. A bandage you put on the wound on your way to a hospital. 

Cap and Trade - it's a financial incentive to lower emissions, and a financial burden on those exceeding the limits. A cap is usually set at a level that allows for relatively normal operation, assuming proper development, but lower than regular use, leaving emitters at a choice - either switch to cleaner energy (with the cap set at a limit that allows for it in a proper amount of time) or continue to pay more and more. This makes switching to cleaner energy sources more financially viable option. And money rules the world. 

One thing I'll also add about renewables is their impact on the environment - the benefit of fossil fuels (that includes nuclear) is that it's energy dense. It allows to relatively small operation both on the mine side as well as power plant side. Renewables often require a lot of area to produce the same amount of energy, and even more to store it, for when it's dark and not windy. Currently, renewables are very inefficient, produce power ad hoc and don't provide sufficient power continuously, requiring proper _"random"_conditions to be just right, can't work in a lot of places and due to their nature - are very localised. There is work on making wind farms start at slower wind speeds and be able to safely operate at higher wind speeds, solar panels are getting denser and thinner, their efficiency is rising, but right now it's not sustainable. It's a very long term solution, that's still in it's infancy. Maybe by the end of this centaury we'll reach 100% renewables, but probably not 2050, and definitely not 2030. 

Carbon Capture and Nuclear are the way to go for now, with cap and trade as the incentive to push governments forward in this direction.

text:
The oil industry itself might not produce very much greenhouse gas, but the combustion of their fuel products most certainly does.  A hell of a lot of the greenhouse gases emitted by agrobusiness are emitted by things like tractors and product transportation -- by the burning of those same fossil fuels.  (Yes, the burning of crop waste after harvest emits CO2, but this was carbon that was taken out of the air by those plants while they were growing in the first place.)

The only area where agribusiness creates greenhouse emissions in an entirely different category than all the rest is with cattle farming.  Cow burps are loaded with methane, which is about 10-20 times as potent a greenhouse gas, pound-for-pound, as CO2 is -- but there are a hell of a lot fewer cows than cars and trucks.

I totally share your feeling about nuclear power, I was anti-nuclear for my first 25 years and now I feel stupid ! :/
And I'm french, so we have an average of 75% nuclear in our power mix, we have the lowest carbon intensity of the G20, we use recycled MOX fuel to reach 6gCO2e/kWh (half of the average nuclear carbon intensity given by the IPCC) and decades ago, we had protoype of 4th gen nuclear reactor. (SuperPhenix, which projected to take used fuel and make power form it, reducing dangerous lifespan of the waste from 100 000 years to 300 years) So you would think french environmentalist are proud of their country and focus their work on the rest of our emissions ? Nope, they want to close nuclear power plant, ignoring the fact that it would do nothing for climate, for them energy transition only means "electricity production transition"... They admire the solar and wind of Germany, ignoring their coal (and their carbon intensity that is always 4 times higher than us...electricitymap.org) SuperPhenix got bombarded by a rocket attack during construction (by an ecologist activist group) and the project was abandonned because of public pressure and also the fact that uranium was too cheap and too plentiful to recycle it.

60% of french think nuclear power contribute to climate change, more like 80% in the youth. So on social media, when I defend nuclear power I'm seen as a corporate shill, it's depressing. I end up arguing more with other environmentalist than with rigth wing climate denialist (we don't have too much of those). üò¢

text:
In reference to the bad rep nuclear energy receives... MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) machines used to be called NMRI. The 'N' stood for 'nuclear' because the image is produced due to various isotopes and their ability to be polarized base off of magnetic field fluctuations. It's more complicated than that, but...

The name was changed because people became scared of the word 'nuclear.'

Also, lets talk about fail-safes. Chernobyl did not have a proper fail-safe. A fail-safe is when, if a system fails, it fails into a safe condition. In theory they're easy, in practice on a complex system... not so much. If your system requires input from a human, for example, it's NOT a fail-safe. 3-Mile Island did not either. That's why, aver 3-Mile Island, no reactor could be built in the United States without more rigorous safety measures. Many reactors that were to be installed in the US could no longer be. Many of those reactors were sold off to foreign entities... including the GE reactor at Fukushima.

 Just thought I'd share. I majored in physics, and we learned a lot of this stuff in my undergrad classes.

text:
Overall, pretty fair summation of the situation. Though the "Overpopulation isn't a thing" thing is spectacularly misleading and the portrayal in this video was hugely misleading. You're avoiding the fact that this is all caused by there being so many humans on the planet. Yes, you are factually correct in WHAT YOU SAID. But what you chose NOT to communicate, is the graphs of global temperature, CO2 Production, Energy consumption, and population, over time. Exponential growth that tracks over each other. Overpopulation is the current problem. Renewable energy and responsible reproduction, are the solution.

Yes, some countries populations have already boomed and are now starting to stabilise, others are still rising or "yet to rise" and it isn't fair for more developed countries to impose limits on less developed ones that hold them back in a way the developed ones weren't. But who they hell thinks it's completely reasonable and acceptable to have five kids and each of their kids to have  five kids in the USA or Europe?! Health care is good enough that you're most likely going to end up with five adult children. It's exponential growth and it's unsustainable. Each one of those people require resources to survive. Yes, it's technically possible to provide for the current existing population in a responsible way. And even if we don't, the Earth will change and adapt without us. It's ourselves and a lot of other unfortunate species that we are screwing over. Nuclear is better than burning fossil fuels, the problem is that the danger hype around it makes every conceivable safety feature a social requirement, which drives the cost up and makes the time to build and commission prohibitive. Renewable's have come a long way and are now potentially faster and cheaper. There are other issues with intermittency and base load. There are  potential solutions like pumped hydro. Nuclear seems like a terrible long term idea, but it's a hell of a lot better than burning more fossil fuels in the short term. 

Die now, die later, die never. We get to chose. Fossil fuels are die now, nuclear is die later, renewable is die never... This is all caused by there being so many humans on the planet though.

I do agree that we shouldn't be building fossil fuel power plants and should be building Nuclear in the short term, with renewable as the long term goal. But I'm not an expert in power plants or sustainability. I just know from basic logic that exponential change cannot be indefinitely sustainable.

text:
Loved the first part of the video, but I think you missed a lot of talking points here, specially when comparing nuclear to renewables. 

1. Nuclear is not renewable and Uran extraction creates also tons of toxic waste.
2. In the entire world there is literally only one long-term storage facility for nuclear waste (in Finland). We are creating tons of toxic waste, not knowing how to deal with it in the  long-term.
3. Nuclear is the least cost-efficient of all energy-production when you calculate the total lifespan/post-lifespan cost of the construction of the powerplants and waste-treatment. I don't know how things are in the US, but in Germany those things are mainly paid for by the government and is heavily subsidised to keep the price competitive.
4. It's not all about the source but also the consumption, which we need to reduce massively. 
5. Renewables (especially wind and solar) are getting better and more efficient by the year and their lifespan is much longer now. In the future they keep getting better.
6. One problem with nuclear is the centralisation. You need extensive power line systems, where you loose a lot of energy. The future of energy is decentralised.


Right now we don't have a perfect solution to our power demand and you are right to say that right now we can't produce 100% of our energy with renewables. But renewables is the main horse we should be betting on, in total environmental impact they are the best. While I do see some advantages of nuclear compared to fossil fuels and they have reduced some of the greenhouse-gas emissions, I think the cost-benefit of nuclear (at least in it's current form) is worse than renewables. The story will be different if we're talking fusion-power of course. 

I think Hank Green did a good comentary on the issue, but in your video I missed the nuance, which you normally are really good at. Hope you take this as constructive criticism.

text:
Hi Valentin,

Interesting points, and many of the things you say are true but, in my view, they lack a comparative perspective. When comparing renewables and nuclear, one has to (i) take the viewpoint of the electricity system as a whole and (ii) factor in the fact that to extract power from wind or solar (or water), one has to build the extractors (i.e. wind turbine, the panel, the dam,...). The production of these extractors relies on materials et metals, some.of which are not at all renewables. For example, neodyme heavily used in wind turbines (especially offshore) is a rare earth element.

1- Uranium is not renewables, but not metal is and "renewables" used metals a lot (more than nuclear on a per MWh basis). All metals extraction create tons of toxic wastes, it's the same for uranium and renewables

2- The problematic nuclear waste (high radioactivity and long lifespan) can be safely stored underground. We know that because there has been nuclear waste for millions of years in Africa (created by natural reactors billions of years ago) and the heavy dangerous elements have stayed exactly where they had been produced. This is the conclusion of the French nuclear authority, which is one of the strictest in the world on safety. I can cit√© r√©f√©rence if needed.

3- Cost efficiency of nuclear is only unfavorable when one look at it from the point of view of the capacity unit. When looking from the point of view of the electricity system as a whole, one must take into account the storage systems and additional network line required for a 100% solar/wind system to work. Once this is taken into account, nuclear comes out on top.

4- agreed ! Energy efficiency and sobriety is always the best solution.

5 - That could be true for the future. But there are also much better nuclear technology that only waiting to be developed, so if one wants to taken into account future possibilities, one needs to do so for both technology.

6 - Centralisation is much more efficient from a systems perspective than decentralization. Losses in transmission lines is only about 2-3%, but for only this loss, you get to spread you capacity over the entire network. If you want a decentralised power system, the peak power of your decentralised unit must be equal to your peak consumption. With centralised systems, since people don't use all of the country's power at the same time, you can power 200 GW of theoretical peak power with only 50 GW of production capacity.

I hope this was useful.

text:
The problem is, that climate politics got highjacked by the left to promote socialism.

You can't talk about reducing emissions without taking into account the overpopulation. According to the earth overshoot day project, we can - with our current technology - supply over 2 billion people world wide and maintain western standards of living. But we have significantly more and that's why we use up more than "one earth". And instead of reducing the population, it is still growing - thereby the consumption is increasing, not decreasing - despite advancements in technology.

 In most countries, "green" means that the the average joe is going to be taxed to death by making mobility a thing that only the rich can afford. But on the other hand, a CO2 tax is never pushed for immigration or children.

And "Climate neutral" is a thing to be achieved. But "they" don't want hydrogen fuel cells, biofuels, synfuels, nuclear fission power, R&D into nuclear fusion, updated building codes (which means increased housing prices) - it should mostly be achieved by not going to work, not having hobbies, not visiting your families and friends and eating vegan.

And this, of course, will be rejected. Climate politics hasn't been about climate for a long time.

text:
Also, allow me to indulge in some scifi fantasizing for a moment on the nuclear point: nuclear doesn't just mean fission. Well, it does if you only count currently working energy production. But the idea that fusion energy is and always will be 20 years away, even as a joke, is just false and honestly kind of harmful. We do have net-positive fusion, and have had it since the 50s. It's just that it's in bombs rather than power plants, because 1) it's hard to contain that reaction and 2) haha tiny big boom machine go brrrrr. But the research on fusion power is much further along now than then, and it is possible. The idea that it's always just "far off in the future" hurts attempts made toward getting there.
Oh and also not only do people think "fission" when they hear "nuclear", they also associate fission with older fission tech, and no one realizes that stuff like LFTRs are an option.
Also, "merge left sign" heh, nice.

text: ¬†@Jakob Schulze¬† You are talking out of your ass. The composition of the nuclear waste is everything from manganese to uranium. And when I say everything i mean it. Every single element is represented in some extent, even the noble gases. There exist various isotopes of the different elements in the waste and elements such as nyodemium and cerium are very usefull. The main reason we don't use the waste is due to regulations and the irrational fear of people and because the waste isn't all that abundant. If there was so much waste why not use it. text:

Nuclear is still one of the more expensive ways of electricity production (which is a key factor) and isn't really efficient either (depending on your definition) and good for base load but awful for peak power, which makes it the worst partner for wind/solar.

And in regard to nuclear waste, sure you don't have to shield and cool low radioactive waste, but it is still waste that you have to store and take care of. In Germany we just had the case a couple years ago where a storage cave for low radioactive waste started filling up with ground water and now they have to dig it all out again.
I was a fan of nuclear once, but I've lost all trust in the industry and the more I learn the less sense it makes.

Just like every other fascist, you always feel the need to put yourself above anybody who disagrees with you.
Climate change is real, I don't deny that. There are people that do deny it, but that's because they can see that it's being politicized  for someones benefit. And that's understandable, I can't blame them for not trusting our politicians, when they exploit climate change, push on legislation for clean energy, while investing in solar, wind and renewable energy companies. They're not idiots, and the fact that they are aware of politicians doing thing like this says otherwise.  
On the other hand, these "climate change deniers" would also say climate hange believers are too naive, and gullible and they will believe anything their government tells them. In in a sense they're not entirely wrong. 

Climate change is real, but human activity is not what causing it, or helping it either.
Climate change is simply a natural thing that happens with time, and with the distance, position, and angle of the Earth to the Sun.
The Earth doesn't spin perfectly, and ends up in the exact same spot every year. The Earth spins at a wobble, and ends up at a different angle to the Sun. The angle tilts the Earth towards the sun closer each year, untill it starts to tilt away from the sun, and so on, and so on.
The planet needs CO'2 for our trees and plats, it's how oxygen is created for living creatures to be able to breath.
The climate is going to change, and there's probably nothing much we can do about it, because it's not humane activity what's causing.

Think about it. How much CO'2 were humans producing to help jumpstart ice ages in the passed? I believe the answer is ZERO. But it happened anyways, more than once. So why get all worked up about it. All we're doing is letting these politicians propagated for their own self benefit.

text:
The major problem with nuclear is that it is ridiculously expensive (and slow to get going). When everyone wanted bombs they had huge amounts of government funding just poured into them. Now with a deregulated (neo-liberal) economy renewables are straight up a better private investment. You need to pump billions of government money into building nuclear but you only need the right incentives and renewables will build themselves. You can reach 60-70% renewable power right now without any issue, getting that last 40-30% is super hard though (and yeah will need better storage options). Now for China, nuclear is appropriate, especially since they have a different economy able to generate that kind of big infrastructure project.

I consider Hyrdo as renewable and pumped hydro is the best storage option atm.

In Europe, there is France with heavily nuclear-powered electricity and Germany with a heavily renewable-based power together with interconnected power grid they are able to run huge economies at low emissions. To get the most out of renewables you need to be able to interconnect power across a large geographical area.

I don't hate nuclear and I don't think it's dangerous. I think it is too expensive and too slow, when we can make deep cuts very fast with renewable investment.

text:
3:20 Actually, no you can't say that. It's true that some pesticides are not safe, but pesticides are actually tested for their safety. And it is also necessary to consider the quantity, thanks to our kidneys a small enough quantity of pesticide can be completely safe while a big quantity can be dangerous (so drinking a whole glass of glyphosate is still a bad idea).


In my country, in France (I don't know for the US), the law says that the maximum amount of pesticide which is allowed to be found in food must be inferior to 100 (sometimes 1000) time the quantity which has been shown to start having health consequences in studies.
And they always take the smallest quantity found by studies which have been found to start causing health problems. That is to say, they usually consider the quantity of pesticides which has health consequences in mice (and as we all know, you need more to poison a human than a mouse).
So, as long as people respect the law (and even if you don't respect the law, you would need to use 100 times too much pesticide. That's why the law is so strict, so that you can't accidentally poison people if you use too much pesticides), at least in my country, you are perfectly safe eating food which has been cultivated with pesticides.
And even though the law may not be as strict in the US, it is probably strict enough not to cause problems for the consumers and probably for the farmer too.


Although, that does not change the fact that pesticides have a bad impact on biodiversity and the fertility of grounds.

author: Kwazy FX2

text:
I fully agree with you that nuclear energy is a promising option that nobody wants to talk about, but you're also underestimating the potential for renewable energy. You say the technology "isn't there yet", but it is. Perhaps some more development in smart grids would be necessary for a 100% renewable grid, but we already have good enough power storage technology (battery technology may still be suboptimal, but pumped hydro has been around for almost a century and works amazingly well). It isn't a technology problem, it's an infrastructure problem. We need to build more power storage facilities and HVDC lines (to connect solar and wind resources to population centers), but we absolutely have the technology. Also, by the way, even when you factor in the cost of these infrastructure projects, renewable is still cheaper than coal and nuclear.


Also, nuclear power requires power storage technology to function just like renewables do, and on-site storage of nuclear waste is TERRIBLE. We need long-term storage facilities, and we've been struggling for the last half century to find a site that won't get shut down from NIMBY issues. In an ideal world, yes, we would use nuclear as a stopgap between fossil fuels and renewable, but in practice it just doesn't seem likely that we'll be able to overcome the NIMBY issues related to nuclear. I applaud you for trying to dispel the toxic myths about nuclear energy, but you shouldn't be so quick to dismiss renewables as a valid option.

2. Population control is not a bad idea in principle. It's about how it's implemented and how it is set up. It doesn't need to be the eugenic death cult fascist bullshit. Slowing the population growth means slowing the growth of emissions and that can't be a bad idea.

text:
I agree that nuclear is a reliable, clean source of energy (at least at the sight of an reactor, we would have to talk about uranium mining) ... the only question is, is there enough reaction mass? In university we had an exercise where we calculated the number of fusion (not fission) reactors we would have to build each year in order to meet the energy needs of a growing population. Although we didn't consider platoing of population the number was in the dozens ... and you would still need to run those reactors for a number of years. I just don't think there is enough usable uranium or any other fissionble isotopes on this planet. 
We woukd need a mix of renewable and nuclear where we produce most energy from renewables and only fell back on nuclear during winter. But then you'd also have to consider that nuclear reactors can't be easily switched on and of and that a background decay is always happening, therefore you would still loose usable uranium when you don't need it.
Coming from these assumptions (because that's what they are but good ones) I think we will need nuclear to react to climate change but only in the mid-term until a more permanent solution like orbital solar panels are found (sounds sci-fi and it still is right now but the moment asteroid mining becomes viable this is a project governments will pursue.)

text: At approximately 17:12 , whoa whoa whoa. no. you're totally forgetting the "cap" part of cap and trade, a pretty damn important part of it. Let's say, currently, in a hypothetical society, you are emitting 20 of whatever-unit-you-want of carbon. Then you pass cap-and-trade capping it at 10. The cap is not "still" 20, it's now *10*. Altogether, industries can emit up to 10; if you want a higher share of that 10, you must pay the companies who are "doing their part" for the privilege of that emission. It effectively reduces supply to the cap on emissions, decreasing demand substantially because of the significant added costs. I love this channel, but am supremely disappointed on this one point in the video. If you're not serious about implementing cap-and-trade, then you're simply not serious about addressing climate change. (The rest of the video is great; but man, disappointed about the dig on cap and trade and the clear misunderstanding of how it works).

text:
@Knowing Better: Re: Nuclear Power - You chose to overlook a number of points:
(1) The world is not "America". Nuclear power plants in Venezuela, Iran, Iraq, North Korea, Afghanistan, Sudan, South Sudan, Somalia, Libya, Syria? (Just to name a few obvious ones.)
(2) Nuclear fuel is a limited resource. Uranium at current levels of consumption will last quite a while, but this is with nuclear power plants producing just about 14% of global electricity at current consumption levels, with projections being that total electricity consumption might double until 2050. At 100% Nuclear Uranium reserves would last for about 10 years without using breeder reactors. About these I refer back to (1) ... global proliferation of Plutonium production sounds like a rather bad idea to me.
(3) The oft proposed solution for (2) of using Thorium has never even seen a successful prototype. In fact the only few prototypes I know of all failed spectacularly after spending billions on them. Taking into account the lessons learned then, getting from the draft stage to a working plant will still take at best ten years.
(4) Building nuclear power plants takes an average of ~10 years from first concrete to first power, and that is including China that is more efficient at building these by nature of being a dictatorship. On top to number excludes the planning stage, so you'd have to add another five years or so, at the least.
(5) No company in the world would currently be able to build enough reactors in parallel. The companies that historically built most of the existing plants (GE, Siemens, Areva) have more or less shut down the relevant divisions. Not sure about Russian companies, but Soviet tech doesn't sound like a good idea. And the Chinese? Well, for once they are quite busy with projects in their own country, and then there's the matter of geopolitics, again ... 

Ramping that back up to the necessary capacity would probably take another ten years or so ... nuclear engineers don't grow on trees.

(6) Running nuclear plants would be a problem in at least half the world. It requires qualified personnel, supply chains, expensive maintenance etc. Someone once suggested to me that this could be solved by the companies building the plants contracting to run them, too, but this kind of Neo-colonialism wouldn't go down too well nowadays, either.



I agree, fifteen or twenty years ago nuclear (fission) might have been an option from a tech point of view, at least as a bridge technology, but the fact is it wouldn't have been feasible politically. Now is simply too late.

text:
Going carbon free is NOT the goal. Remember! The goal is to keep the planet at the right temperature. We wouldn't need to add carbon to the air, if there was a way to introduce completely new heat energy into the environment directly. We would be heating the planet without adding carbon to the air.
And what a coincidence, nuclear does exactly that. It introduces energy from nuclear bonds directly into the environment, energy that would have stayed trapped there forever. In this sense, nuclear is worse than coil/oil, because at least fossil fuel plants can have carbon capture machines, or new trees can be planted, or the carbon could be stored in basalt, etc.
But there is no option for recapturing the energy released by nuclear plants.

Meaning that the US has the economy to invest into new tech while the smaller countries don't. So while the US is busy investing, smaller countries can gain economic power while still relying on low cost electricity. If they were forced to develop these technologies on their own (US pulling out of the agreement) , it would hinder their economic growth. 

I dont know how feasible that is, but it did get me thinking about how we are constantly in a power struggle with other countries.  So things that are good for humanity might not be the best thing for a particular country. Keep in mind, that the USA is not a super power bc they play fair.
author: supremancy

text:
As an Energy Engineer who works in the Nuclear industry I really appreciate this video; I felt the same about being lied to by political groups about Nuclear when I learned about it.

However, I don't think you should discount Carbon Capture and Storage; and more rigorous cap and trade. If you put that cap low, the developed country needs to reduce its emissions somehow, CCS works quite well in conjunction with that and overall allows approaching closer to net zero.

C&T I think works better when restricted to necessary industries that can't avoid a lot of their emissions, particularly heavy industry: concrete and steel production for example... Even a 10% (a low estimate) capture of their emissions would significantly affect countries totals.

Renewables also obviously play a very important role, especially alternative storage technologies; solar heat storage (using a salt based steam cycle) and pumped water storage paired with wind; both already exist and are fairly effective at reducing the huge power variations. 

Older technologies factor into that as well, like tidal barrages and hydroelectric which was touched on briefly, if it goes towards reducing dependence on fossil fuel emissions go for it; same goes for hydrogen electrolysis and fuel cells.

Overall the goal is in the future to have the vast majority of power come from renewable sources; wind farms, solar plants and hydroelectric dams, (hydrogen and tidal/wave power too maybe); but as you mention a strong base will be needed to support that and Nuclear can fill that niche and provide that...

The net emissions from nuclear are astonishingly low (including the whole mining to disposing fuel cycle) and Fusion and GenIV reactors show a lot of promise for deployment in 10-20 years... It also has one of the best work-in:work-out ratios of any energy source.

author: Lawrence

text:
‚Äã¬†@Lawrence¬† Depleted uranium is not nuclear waste. It is a (somewhat) valuable byproduct. The radioactive waste comes from the products of uranium fission, and it is genuinely dangerous and hard to deal with. There is no known physical mechanism to make radioactive nuclei safe except to wait for them to decay, which can take tens or hundreds of thousands of years. That's why finding permanent storage locations for nuclear waste has been a difficult problem.

Except, we had a solution for the U.S. in Yucca Mountain. Unfortunately, that closed, because unsurprisingly, nobody wants to live near a nuclear waste repository, and there was no way to maintain political support for long enough to complete the project, or, more importantly, ensure it could continue operating in the long term. If we could reassure people of its safety and be believed, we wouldn't have to store nuclear waste in dry casks near cities. We had the choice between burying nuclear waste deep in a mountain in a desert where nobody lives and leaving it in shielded containers on the surface all over the country, and because environmentalists got their way, we're going with the latter.

There is no reason to avoid them just because they can't literally solve everything. In many parts of the country, and of the world, they are already cost-competitive with other sources of energy except natural gas (and at the moment, oil), and if there were any way of charging companies for their emissions (e.g. cap and trade, tax incentives, whatever), they would be even cheaper. 

But at the end of the day, we will still need consistent supplies of power, such as nuclear.
author: EebstertheGreat

text:
¬†@Anastasiya S.¬† Compared to the stores of oil, there is an effectively infinite amount of uranium. Using only reserves that can already be extracted cheaply and used in existing, common reactors, we will reach "peak uranium" in 135 years. That gives us well over a century to improve the designs of breeder reactors, fast reactors, thorium reactors, light water reactors, or hopefully someday even fusion reactors. 135 years is a long time to be allowed to begin the process of transitioning to another fuel.

Peak oil on the other hand may be literally just a few years away.

text: Nuclear is outdated tech and an utter waste of money and resources. We could throw away half of the renewable energy we produce and it would still beat nuclear by quite a margin. Nuclear power might be worth it again once fusion comes around. Until then we should rush renewables and get rid of everything else as we have the capacity to do so.
author: Max Mustermann

text:
Renewables are cheap to build but require expensive support to integrate them into the grid, Nuclear is basically the opposite, you can pretty much just plug them straight in as if they were a coal power station. Hydro has the best of both worlds, sort of, but sites are limited and there are other environmental issues with big dams. I think it's going to depend on the cost, if nuclear, (fission or fusion) becomes a lot cheaper, there's not a whole lot of reasons to bother with lots of wind, solar or even hydro.

Having the vast majority of energy generation be renewable should not be the goal, that doesn't help carbon emissions by itself. The goal should be whatever mix of clean energy is the cheapest while also being as reliable and robust as possible. If that happens to be a complex dance of renewables, storage and intensive grid management, so be it. But if nuclear becomes cheaper that may no longer be the case. Certainly the former looks more likely right now, but we can't say for sure. Certainly I think nuclear has the potential to be a lot more affordable, but progress is slower than in other generation industries for a variety of reasons.

text:
I think your portrayal of cap and trade is a little over simplified. Three reasons:

1) if I buy 5 credits from my neighbor, to cover my 10 tons of emissions, the kn my 10 tons of emissions suddenly start costing me $$$ that hits my bottom line. This means there is suddenly a financial incentive for me to reduce my emissions and we have successfully (at least partially) internalized an externality.

2) of I can sell my 5 credits to my neighbor I now have $$$ that I can use to  increase my competitive advantage. Don‚Äôt forget, we are talking about companies here, not cute neighborhood communities. I can effectively make my green business more economical compared to my polluting competitors.

3) If I can‚Äôt buy credits on the open market to cover my emissions, I will have to pay penalties. This creates a very strong incentive for the overall becoming to not exceed the total amount of credits available to the market. Since the amount of credits available is defined by legislators, it creates a strong economic incentive for the overall market to not exceed the amount of emissions defined by the legislators. Legislators now have a strong tool to effectively regulate emissions. Not to mention that such penalty payments can flow back into governmental ecology and global warming programs.

text: I think its the "cap and trade" part is a bit incomplete as the program aims to hand out these "carbon credits" based on a given limit. For example given the limit is 10 tons of gas globally where only country A and B exists only. Country A produces 4 ton while county B produces 8 there would be an excess demand of these carbon credits by 2 as such given that each country has 5 carbon credit each, country B will be penalized for having excess production of gas which is implemented in the cap and trade program. As such companies and corporations will be incentivized to produce less carbon as the taxes (is intended to) penalize these companies more than the gain they get by producing these gases. Although I do agree that a cap and trade can be too lenient and governments may as well set the limits too high for any actual change. However in light of the previous argument, this video is inaccurate to say that it wouldn't change the carbon levels at all if done effectively.

¬†@S Clair¬† That's not the issue. The issue is the amount of extra energy being trapped by greenhouse gases. Right now, greenhouse gases trap 600TWh per hour, and if you multiply that by the number of hours in a year, that goes to about 5 million TWh. The world currently uses only 165,000-ish per year. So, no big deal, right? For now, that is correct. But when the population goes to 11 billion, and each person is using 5 times the energy that each of us (in the US) currently uses, then we will be using about 5million TWh per year.
It won't matter that it's from nuclear. It will still be adding the same amount of heat that is currently being trapped by greenhouse gases.

text: Isn‚Äôt the idea of cap and trade to put the cap at a lower amount than is currently being emitted? And in this supposedly international cap and trade, if a developing country sells their carbon credits to an industrialized nation, then that developing country still gets extra money out of this deal, which they could use to develop. They would get more carbon credits the next year, but maybe they wouldn‚Äôt sell as many of them now because they used the money from last year to build some energy plants. Now, the industrialized country would have to either buy their extra credits elsewhere, or (and here‚Äôs the kick) they would be incentivized to reduce their own emissions. As a caveat, in my Environmental Econ class, we didn‚Äôt talk about cap and trade on an international scale, and I imagine such a policy would be really difficult to enact. We only talked about it on a state/national level, which is really what the policy is designed for. By setting the cap lower than current emissions, the price of trade would increase, and people would be more incentivized to reduce their emissions than to buy credits off someone else, depending on the cost of reducing emissions. And, people who emit less and sell their remaining credits would have a bigger reward for doing so. The idea is also to decrease the cap over time, so this process continues.

text:
Sure, the planet could hold 10 billion, 50 billion, maybe 150 billion.  But how?  And why?



We overproduce food by a lot .  I've heard estimates of 50% of food is wasted between initial production and the end consumer. And on top of actual food production, there are an estimated 40 MILLION acres of land just in lawns.  So yeah, we could easily feed all that are here and more with increased efficiency.  But, if you drive through an area where we are heavily engaged in crop production, you'll notice that there isn't much area for "wilderness".  If the ground looks like it could produce corn, and the landowner is a corn grower, it will see a bulldozer and then a planter...


But how about water?  Well, sure we could get more efficient with water.  We consume and pollute it much faster than it can be replenished.  We build cities in the desert with little plans on where the water is gonna come from.  We water that millions of acres of lawn just to mow it off and throw it away.



And how about shelter? Does each family get to live in a 4 bedroom house on a quarter acre?  Do they each deserve multiple vehicles? Would you consider life good if you're stacked in tiny boxes like people are in the Pacific Rim countries?  There are apartments in South Korea that are literally smaller than a typical American bathroom.  How would you like to quarantine in your bathroom?


I think the population would naturally self regulate lower with a few tweaks to governmental policies (like tax codes).  Nothing drastic has to be "done".  Family size is going down. My dad is one of five kids and my mom is one of nine kids.  I have many friends who have one, two, or no kids.  I know a very few people who have 5 or 6 young kids.   I would much rather see a couple billion healthy happy people sharing the wealth of the planet versus tens of billions starving struggling fighting people.  Let's start focusing on improving the quality of the lives that are here versus racing each other to see how many more we can make...
author: farmerboybill

text:
Overpopulation might technically not be a direct problem, but it is a major contributing factor since it basically acts as a multiplier. Even if everyone changed their living standards, there always will exist a limit for how many people with those standards the Earth can sustain. The limit is higher on moderate standards, and much lower on extravagant ones.




Earth receives certain amount of energy from the Sun. Photosynthesizers convert this to useful form of energy, which in turns virtually all other life. Let's say X is the amount of this energy that humans can take advantage of. Let's also say every human needs Z amount of energy. Using maths we could technically calculate how much is the upper limit.


For most of history, when the X had changed due to climate change, erosion and destruction of previously arable land or by overhunting of some animal, the nature would do the regulation of populations. On good years the populations would rise, and on bad ones go down.




At the moment were having a major good time, and one could attribute that to many factors, such as the neck breakingly fast technological advancement, the very effective fertilizers we've come up with and agricultural industrialization. All of which are true, but I think most importantly it's because of cheap energy. 



Let's take oil for the example. Oil is basically the energy of the old Sun, which has been forming beneath the earth for many many years. Production of that oil required no effort from our part, only digging it up and refining it for use. The amount of energy you get from this is extremely high compared to the amount one needs to invest in order to get it. This has enabled us to use the machines we use on food productions, fly to other continents and use for personal mobility without second thought.


Cheap energy is what runs the modern world. It's used to run the machines that produce the food cheaply, transport that food, other goods and us cheaply, heat our homes cheaply, generate the energy and whatsnot. Energy use has been on the rise on tandem with growing populations and growing living standards, and increasingly continues to be. The obvious unfortunate thing about that is the fact we are running out of those cheap sources.


That's only the energy department, not to speak of the lost arable soil due to too intense acgricultural practises, over-use of fertilizers and pollution.




CONCLUSION: I get why people tread the subject of population growth with such care, since quite many other people, many with racist and scetchy eugenic agenda, argue for population growth control (or maybe more precisely, they argue for control of certain populations). At the same time, I'm kind of disappointed how swiftly it is dismissed if brought up and how little people discussing these things take it into an account. 



The documentary folk from 19:33 to 19:50 don't mention the word overpopulation - they state that the growth and the consequent overconsuming are and will be problematic down the line. I don't know where the Knowing Better -person gets the idea they strictly mean the growth of some 'third world countries', rather than the human population as a whole.


TLDR; Population is an important aspect of the equation, and discussion about its impact shouldn't be repressed and stigmatized.

text:
¬†@Beatles Foxman¬† You know, there are a few points why you are talking complete shit there:
1: Nuclear is so much more expensive that even if we threw half of our power output away renewables would still be cheaper by a landslide. Ie we could overuse wind to a laughable degree and its still the better option.
2: Nuclear has unsolved problems and risks involved which nobody still right in their mind is willing to tolerate.

4: Building a new nuclear power plant takes a decade. Thats the time it theoretically takes us to go full green (a very ideal case tho). So, assuming we got our shit together for once, even that is simply not an argument pro nuclear.
5: Renewable tech is sufficiently complete. It is already the best we have, and storage tech is widely available. Some of it can still be optimized, but it has gone past the critical point we needed. All that is left is implementing.
author: Max Mustermann

text: Max Mustermann You‚Äôre working against yourself by playing your hand too far. Are renewable better: yes. Are renewable cheaper: mostly. Does nuclear need more storage: no. Have the renewable run on top of a nuclear baseline and use weather predictive services determine the renewable output for the next few days. This would replace LNG and coal powerplantd as baselines and provide a nice cushion for transition to full renewables over 30 years. Also, nuclear is not inherently more expensive when land and transportation is factored in. Next generation nuclear powerplants are also relatively safe, having built in failsafes to prevent problems such as Chernobyl. Lastly, the problem of storing nuclear waste, which I assume is one thing you reference when you talk about ‚Äúunsolved problems and risks‚Äù is largely about overcoming fear. Nuclear is a promising technology which should absolutely be pursued,. Many of its flaws may be fixed if similar funding to renewable were put into it again. That said, I do agree that pure renewables is always a better option where practicable‚Äîthat just isn‚Äôt everywhere.
