author: Huddy o2

text:
So you just trash renewables without presenting any evidence to support it and then say nuclear is the best without addressing any of the biggest problems with it? Okay, "knowing better." Guess I'm still being lied to about it. What is this nonsense about solar farms only lasting a few years? Solar farms can theoretically last many decades with only one or two key components needed to be replaced every 10-20 years or so. Solar panels offset the amount of energy it takes to build and set them up in less than 6 months.  Yes, solar and wind use rare earth metals. No, rare earth metals are not rare. There is low demand for them, so production is correspondingly low, but could be ramped up to meet renewable needs. It is true that renewables could not power 100% of needed energy with current technology, but they don't have to. As long as they met about ~80% or so of energy needs, which they can with current technology, the remaining amount could be met by other sources like nuclear or carbon neutral fossil fuels, and that would be enough to account for the unreliable aspects of solar and wind generation. Speaking of nuclear, now there's a technology that could never be scaled up to meet the world's energy needs. There's a million and one issues with it, but some of the biggest are cost and uranium supply. Simply put, any more efficient types of reactors (like fast breeders for example) are too expensive to justify right now compared to traditional reactors. Uranium would have to get so rare before the price was jacked up high enough to make efficient reactors economically feasible that there wouldn't be enough left to power the world for much longer anyway. And don't forget that many of the proposed technologies to make nuclear viable simply do not exist! There are no commerical thorium reactors. There is no commercial uranium seawater extraction. It's currently in the realm of science fiction and may stay like that forever. We may be "close" for years, and that's not good enough. Even if we had it now, it takes way too long to construct new nuclear plants. By the time we would get them up and running it would be too late to be useful. And those have to be replaced too. If you built enough nuclear power plants to power the world you would have to build and deconstruct a new plant somewhere in the world every single day, give or take. And these are massive, expensive projects that take years to construct and have very specific land requirements. Nuclear is fine where it is right now. Investing our resources in trying to scale it up would be a dangerous mistake. Renewables can be scaled up right now. We have the technology. We have the resources. We just don't have the investment. Please, don't mislead your audience on a channel called "knowing better."


Otherwise though, great video. I especially liked the points you made about "not all countries at the same starting line for industrialization." I never really thought about that but it's so true.

author: Scott Shepard

text:
Hi, I know you did your research for this video, but my degree is literally in the energy side of this subject. Because of this, I will just chime in with a little bit of extra context and a few corrections. I am going to start off by explaining a couple of Political Science concepts, and then move into explaining the context using certain countries as examples. This is a very complicated subject and I want to explain it without really mentioning the partisan politics aspect. 

Firstly, there are 2 main Political Science concepts that must be understood. These are Sovereignty and the Prisoner‚Äôs Dilemma. Sovereignty is the idea that there is no higher power above the states. Depending on what school of Political Science you come from, this can mean very different things. However, the 3 main schools of thought are variations of Realists, Liberals, and Constructivists. But generally (and take this with a deep understanding that the theories do differ tremendously) this means that states (as in governments) are the primary actors in the international realm. Some of these schools (Liberals and Constructivists in particular) accept non-state actors, but to what extent varies greatly.

As for the Prisoner‚Äôs dilemma, this is the idea that even though the theoretical best results would be gained by working together, the uncertainty of not knowing the other actor‚Äôs intentions will lead to the actual best result to be defecting. You can find lots of material on this, so I will just leave it as is for now.

Now, when looking at the various agreements, these 2 theories need to be considered. This is why these agreements always have opt-out clauses. Getting any country to agree to an agreement with massive penalties would be incredibly difficult. However, having an agreement is the best way of getting around the Prisoner‚Äôs Dilemma. So, this generally leads to weak treaties with little enforcement ability. 

As for the argument about developing countries, this false into a fallacy of assuming that there is only 1 way to develop. Take phones for example. Cell phones ownership in Africa has skyrocketed in the last decade. This is despite landlines never really catching on. Technological advancement allows you to skip parts of development. So, the assumption that developing countries need coal plants because it is the only path to development is just wrong. The truth here is that coal prices are just really low in comparison to the cost to develop the type of grids necessary to have a large renewable network. 

Even countries like Japan, who have promised to have massive investment (and is in their best interest as they import 85% of their energy) in renewables, are only using it to off set their normal energy sources. This is because the storage is extremely expensive, and it is cheaper to use renewables when it is available but use fossil fuels to make up the difference. For example, Japan has massive solar investments going on, but these new facilities will only function during the day. However, that overlaps with peak energy demand, and may cover ~60% of energy use. 

As for the argument about nuclear energy. It is largely very good. However, you ignored the refurbishment costs. Nuclear reactors need tens of millions of dollars of refurbishments every couple of decades. This is why many of them have been closing in Europe in the last couple of years. The price to keep them open mixed with the political cost has proven to great in many areas. Of course, nuclear is generally extremely safe, but there are reasons why it has been decreasing in recent years.

text:
Nuclear weapons and nuclear reactor fuel are not, in fact, equivalent. Nuclear weapons require either the use of plutonium or of uranium composed primarily of a rare isotope (uranium-235); nuclear fuel requires relatively little uranium-235, and it's actually fairly easy to tell when countries are creating the kind of highly-enriched uranium that can be used for nuclear weapons.


Fear of proliferation is not a good reason to oppose nuclear power.

I was about to give you an upvote, and then you started communicating misinformation. You're parroting inaccurate info from Michael Moore's terrible, harmful movie. That movie was full of blatant falsehoods about renewables.

text: Before I watch this video I‚Äôm going to state my very basic opinions about nuclear and see if they change after. Basically, I like nuclear, I see it as an important transitional step towards completely renewable energy. My one and only real problem is that the US itself still lacks a dedicated storage site for its nuclear waste, much of it is just piled up on storage sites at the plants themselves and each plant obviously can‚Äôt  just do that forever. And frankly, I do not see any ‚Äúconservative‚Äù or ‚Äúliberal‚Äù administration being willing to fund a federal storage facility, because it hasn‚Äôt happened already, despite a potential site having being found over 50 years ago. So while I will not speak out against nuclear power, I will also not speak in favor of it‚Äôs expansion until we have a more long-term solution for the very long term problem that nuclear waste entails.

text:
I don't know if I agree with the sentiment that Cap and Trade would be ineffective.  
Bringing to mind the idea of "Carbon Credits", this means that after reaching the "Cap" areas which use more will end up investing in areas that do not need as much as they Trade.

From here; based off what you set the Cap at, couldn't you choose a Cap where which if everywhere follows this rule overall, it keeps the overall emissions down?  As an oversimplified example; 
- 1)  Assume each State in US has 5 Carbon Credits, for a total of 250 Credits.  
- 2)  Assume the Total Emission of 250 Credits worth to be within an acceptable range of emissions.  (Or at least the current goal for the year or decade, if we need to make baby steps)

Assuming these two rules, wealthier areas are in a way 'privileged' to more emissions than others.  But only by investing money into less wealthy areas. 

But wouldn't the high value resource in 'Carbon Credits' incentivize investments into less emissive energy forms in order to be more conservative with the way one spends the Credits they have access to?  Thus creating an organic way for those playing by the rules to be pursuing more green energy over time without oppressive measures taken?

_ _

That said, while I do think it is one of multiple potential tools that could and perhaps should be implemented that has its benefits.  I do have my own reservations in such a system; specifically, less in terms of it's inefficiency, but more in terms of the usual risks associated with iterative trading systems.  

If poorly regulated, one area or group of areas could potentially monopolize all the Carbon Credits.  So measures would need to be taken against that, such as heavy taxes for Emissive companies that are operating within areas that "own" more Carbon Credits as per each Tier.  (I.E.  An area with 6+ Credits Pays a notable sum, one with 11+ pays more, etc.)

This would hopefully incentivize businesses that make use of Carbon Credits to expand into other areas that have both a workforce and Carbon Credits available; such as developing areas that would otherwise have suffered limited development by trading away their Carbon Credits for quick paychecks.  

_ _

Perhaps more importantly however, is the intuitive nature of Cap and Trade breaks the complex issue into a simple form, allowing a complex issue that is scientific in nature with a lot of broad statistics to be understood with small numbers and effectively criticized without heavy research.  

Overall; i think that paired with some comprehensive supporting rules, a well balanced system integrating Cap and Trade could be a potent strategy, as well as intuitive enough for people to understand.

text: California is in a unique situation here, In which it has neighbors like Nevada, Oregon, and Washington that have massive export-only hydropower projects, and about 2GW of unused and built geothermal capacity, allowing the state to reach 60% Renewable without too much work. The state also has 1.4GW of Geothermal projects under construction or in final planning stages. It also has 2.6GW of hydro under construction, or entering new 50 year transmission contracts with the state. This will allow the state to reach 75-80% Renewables in the next 5-10  years. The state is then only short about 4GW in capacity, about 3GW can be met with new hydro-storage projects. The other 1GW can be met through the state's untapped geothermal resources in the imperial basin. Unlike some places *Germany cough cough* CA has a plan to phase out nuclear. Whether you think Geo and Hydro are worse than nuclear is a diffrent question, but they do have a plan.

author: dimitri jordania

text:
¬†@dimitri jordania¬† You are incorrect, CO and CO2 are poisonous to animals.  CO2 is a metabolic waste product, and our circulatory system and respiratory system have both evolved to remove CO2 from our body.  Inhaling significant concentrations of CO or CO2 are immediately life-threatening, both molecules displace oxygen in the hemoglobin within red blood cells. 


CO2 levels have been higher in the past.  That is not an argument denying the danger of modern climate change.  Humans did not exist the last time CO2 levels were this high, and given that Solar irradiance ON AVERAGE increases linearly with time, far more solar radiation is entering the atmosphere now than the last time CO2 concentration was this high.  I'm going to need your source for CO2 concentration being higher during the time of the Roman Empire.  Was this really a global phenomenon like modern CO2 concentration, or was this a local phenomenon like the Medieval Warming Period?

            
"automatically keep the PH balanced, no matter how much physical acid you even dumped into the ocean" citation needed given that you've confused buffers with bases.  A buffer is an acid-base pair that resists pH change, a base can balance a low pH, but does not AUTOMATICALLY balance pH like buffers do.
Why should people trust what you say given your very limited grasp of basic chemistry and biology?

text: I spent time in the DOD,DOE high secure Commodities  transportation Business in the 90's. and 00's We do not have a viable long term storage plan or even a clue as to where to begin. The sites we have are inadequate for long term storage of radioactive material .The WHIPP project handles variety of radioactive material as well as spent fuel rods and it is only a temporary solution. Building more Nuclear Power plants will add to our storage problems Maintain the number we have or less would be fine for the time being..  I cant go into  the security details there may  be an NDA still in effect  but at one point I was told to not talk to anyone that looked Middle eastern  about security (This came from the FBI). This was  a couple of years before 9/11 . After 9/11 the FBI said they believed that Terrorist had a plot to High jack one or two of our trucks. If it was just an explosive truck then the Target would have been the Hoover Dam . If it was a Nuclear waste and an explosive truck then they could have been turned into the worlds biggest dirty bomb.( I hope the NSA doesn't flag me) and set it off in Las Vegas. Bikini Island in the Pacific was used  for nuclear testing  was caped. It is now deteriorating and starting to leak . As sea levels rise  it will end up  leaking to the sea adding to the leaking radioactive  water from Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster ( They though it was earthquake proof ) that is still leaking . The Technology for long term Solar, wind ,wave and even Biomass (other thing other then wood can be used )  is improving . There are a few other forms of energy production in the experiment phase that can  be helpful. None of these can do it all on their own. author: Ag silver Radio

text:
Was with you until you said that renewables would likely never meet energy demands. What is your basis for this? You also say that they usually need to be supplemented by coal or natural gas. Why do you think this? Due to the intermittency i.e. lack of energy storage? Or just lack of installed capacity? Because both of these are issues that already have clear solutions but just need time and investment. I strongly disagree that these issues can't be solved within the near future. My own country (Scotland) already has enough installed wind power capacity that we produce more energy from wind alone than we need on many days of the year.

I do agree with your conclusions about biomass, yes it's not viable solution. I think this is becoming consensus in the scientific community already, and I doubt you will find many scientists who will go to bat for biomass as the saviour.

To be clear, I am pro-nuclear, I think countries like France, Belgium, Slovakia have benefitted enormously from their nuclear programmes. And yes, the issue of nuclear waste has been massively blown out of proportion of decades. Where I think you got this wrong though was glossing of Chernobyl, and only mentioning Fukushima in passing. Okay, more people have likely died as a result of fossil fuels, but how many people have been struck by a wind turbine blade? Maybe some of the processes involved in refining materials for solar panels, collectors, and turbines produce air pollution. But I nuclear power has killed more, of that I'm sure. The 'propaganda number' for deaths due to nuclear sits wrong with me as well. No one can know how many people have been killed by nuclear, in the same way you can't know how many have died of fossil fuels. Personally, my girlfriend and many of her friends have thyroid problems as a direct result of Chernobyl (born in Poland 1986). Nuclear disasters effect vast vast numbers of people, and it's not something that ended with Chernobyl, and it won't end with Fukashima.

I think there is a general American bias towards nuclear power emerging. Many people are just realising all lies that they've been told about it, and now believe it to be the saviour. While in Europe (many countries intend to phase out the reactors), and soon probably in Japan (most of there reactors have been shut down for now), where we have felt the effects of nuclear disasters first hand, there is a more nuanced understanding that Nuclear power is deeply deeply flawed.

Still enjoyed the video thought. I love South Park, but climate change is one issue they've been dead wrong on. :)

text: Judging by your rhetoric and spelling this will probably go over your head, but he already explained why countries like China currently have such a large carbon footprint: they are going through their industrial revolution just like we did a long time ago. Our industrial revolution happened from the 1760's to around the 1830's. Industrialization in China didn't start until the 1950's. They pollute more than us (and per capita they don't, Americans make up less than 5% of the global population yet produce 20% of all greenhouse gases) not because they're authoritarian, but because they're farther back on the tech tree. If we actually helped them out instead of treating them like enemies we could both reach a position where we're polluting less, but tribalism is more important that rationality.
author: Crowe3717

text:
Yah, it would have been nice if he had explained the bit about renewables not  meeting energy demands. The current problem is intermittency. Heavy reliance on these forms of power generation means you need more peaker plants (power plants design to be rapidly "turned on and off"), which are usually relatively inefficient fossil-fuel fuel based plants, unless you have the geography required to do something like pumped hydro. This can actually lead to an increase in CO‚ÇÇ emissions compared to something more stable like nuclear.

(Edit)
Biomass is kind of a joke, coming from someone who used to work at one of these stations. The only place it make any sense is if your biomass power plant is on-site, producing power to drive a process using the waste from that same process. (i.e. a pulp mill burning the stripped bark to run a good portion of the mill.) Anything off-site just leads to a pile of extra emissions due to all the transportation.

author: Hai Long nguyen

text:
I don't see how "it's deeply deeply flawed" is a more nuanced position; modern controls around Nuclear and new nuclear technologies significantly reduce the risk of an accident, and more importantly massively reduce the extent of damage if an accident does occur. This can even be seen between Chernobyl and Fukushima, no airborne contamination plume, limited ground pollution and the molten core was contained within the main reactor building, to name just a few.

As fellow European I also question the blanket statement, France is one of the world leaders in Nuclear tech, and is also has one of the lowest rates of CO2 emissions per capita in Europe; we certainly plan for modern nuclear plants, as there are several ongoing build projects as well as the ITER nuclear fusion reactor.

I agree he went overboard about renewables, but their shorter lifespan and intermittency is a big issue. To supply a moderately sized European countries energy needs with storage, we would need Terrawatt sized battery banks, able to consistently put out GigaWatt hours of energy to completely wean off gas and oil. Especially as with electrification of heating and transport will lead to higher and higher energy demands.

A large amount of renewable power supported by storage, but with a small base of Nuclear providing that stability could save building millions of battery banks, and increase material efficiency considerably. (Ie using less materials and current emissions to accomplish the same net emission target)

text:
¬†@Hannah B¬† Yes Fukushima was certainly less severe than Chernobyl, but there are still many operating RBMK reactors of the type form Chernobyl. And the simple fact that despite modern technology and engineering, a power plant still went into meltdown is a very high rate of catastrophic failure considering the number of nuclear power plants world wide.

I'm not sure what statement you're questioning in your next point, but yes I totally agree with your point about France, I think i mentioned it in my first comment. But no countries are really planning to emulate Frances success. Yes a few reactors are being built here and there, but countries like Germany and Belgium intend to begin phasing out Nuclear entirely in the next two years. I don't really agree that the fact that we're building an experimental fusion reactor for research purposes signals that Europe wants to build more fission reactors. 

And honestly I agree a lot with your last statements. A small Nuclear baseload is a good idea, but that small baseload is already there for most western european countries. I also do think people underestimate battery storage quite a lot new techs like nickle metal hydride batteries, and the constant reduction of battery manufacture costs being driven by Panasonic and Tesla points to batteries becoming a very good solution in the very near future. With many of my colleagues agreeing that energy storage and production is becoming more holistic and decentralised, and that this is the future. Rather than the thinking about 20 years ago which was that a central nuclear grid supplemented with centralised renewables was on the horizon.

author: Hai Long nguyen

text:
¬†@Hai Long nguyen¬† My mistake, you said that nuclear costs as much as renewables. I still disagree with this, it is more expensive in terms of direct cost per kW. In terms of the simplicity of solar and wind (which I think you're giving as your argument why renewables are over a hundred years away from viability). Are you suggesting that nuclear power is simpler? I assure you it isn't, nuclear power is very very difficult. It is resource, time, and cost intensive at first because a country needs a highly specialised workforce, as well as significant infrastructure to import and enrich uranium. In contrast renewable have a much lower bar of entry, it is insanely easy for anyone to wack a solar panel or wind turbine in their back garden, and this level of difficulty doesn't increase much with district sized energy production.

I think are key disagreement here is that you just think nuclear will work sooner, and better. I agree that we need to eliminate fossil fuels as fast as possible, I'm not asking us to delay that period to wait around for renewables, but nuclear isn't as easy as I think you think it is. The technology is already there for a total global energy production from renewables, I'm not asking you to just believe that, it's a fact, there are countries (as i mentioned in my first comment) that already produce more renewable energy than they need on good days.

I don't follow your final point on water energy. What are you talking about specifically? Pumped hydro storage? Tidal? Wave? One thing very few people seem to be talking about as well is that at current rates we'll run out of uranium in 80 years, if the whole world decides to go with nuclear, we'll run out much sooner. Solar and wind are true renewable, there is no reasonably accepted reason that one day we won't be able to use them.

So perhaps people ought to start thinking about the generation after them, because all we do by focusing totally on nuclear is what our parents did to us with their focus on fossil fuels. Which is lumber us with another short term solution with a long term problem (in this case the very expensive process of nuclear decommissioning, coupled with the dwindling resources available to keep the power flowing)

text: What about the problem of nuclear plants not being financially viable without the use of public funds? Also, I grew up near a nuclear waste storage site, and they did occasionally have to fix leaks into the river, where we swam and fished, but they didn't fix the leaks very quickly, and they didn't tell us it happened until way after. I'm trying to research if they are still dumping the cooling water from the Fukushima disaster or if they figured out another solution. What do you think about the current ability at containing nuclear waste successfully, for the duration of the time it needs to be contained? I understand that every power generation method has drawbacks. If nuclear waste can be contained well in theory, what is preventing it from being contained well in practice? It seems like your video is saying there is no other option, but what about the painful "taking responsibility" option? There are ways to use less carbon per person, although they do take more work. An example is a chest-freezer shaped fridge (that doesn't dump out the cold when you open the door.) Another is if you look into super- effeciant woodstoves, they have some that can burn hot enough to burn their own smoke and use less wood (maybe a tenth?) with drastically reduced smoke/carbon emissions. (Heat is a major energy use in the US. Fridges are not but it made a good physical example of inconvenience.) I feel like if we are talking to someone who has a money spending problem, and we are trying to tell them that they need to spend a lot less- and they keep saying "how about credit cards? What about a bank loan? Private money lending? Can I sell my organs?" When what they need is to actually spend less- for us, I'm talking carbon per person in developed nations. That would be a great way to lead the world. I would like to have the goal be how to make carbon friendly be comfortable and fun, like skylights, veggie gardens, and walkable neighborhoods, and how to focus on using carbon emissions on what's important to the country, rather than on how to keep the carbon spending high. Isn't it possible that we could do a lot of what we do now, some of it more luxuriously, using less carbon? An uncle of mine has to fly constantly for work, but it is really not as fun as it may sound. If we could develop better conferencing software (or methods?) perhaps some of that could be avoided and give him a happier job, too. It would be wonderful to have clean enough energy, and maintain or increase our use- but wouldn't it be more responsible to use less until that time that it has been developed and implemented? Sorry that this is a long comment! Thank you for your videos, I love your work, and that you are having these conversations. :) I do have trouble finding unbiased, professional discussion of nuclear energy issues, so if you have helpful links I would love to read more.

author: GaslitWorld f. Melissa B

text:
Interesting video but I feel you go over the alternatives too fast.


Natural gas is around 50% cleaner than coal, replacing coal with natural gas absolutely makes sense, especially in developing countries where if we can switch the building of coal to natural gas plants we at least stem the tide of industrialisation. In the West this has already occurred, since most Western countries have switched from coal to natural gas as their main energy source. If we can at least push countries such as China and India into using natural gas over coal, we are making huge energy savings.


Cap and trade can work precisely because the government can effectively set climate goals. You're right that if we start with 10 units of carbon,  everybody gets 5 and one guy sells 4 to somebody who will use them, the problem will remain. However the government hands 2 or 3 carbon tokens to each person, you have dropped carbon production by 20-40%. Whilst it doesn't directly solve the problem, it gives the government a means of acting which it currently does not have.


As for Nuclear Power you missed the elephant in the room. The anti-nuclear lobby has indeed spewed out misinformation, but nuclear isn't currently viable because it's so ridiculously expensive to build nuclear power plants. The cost of producing electricity using nuclear costs roughly double what it would for coal and natural gas. So unless everybody is happy to double their monthly energy bills, it isn't likely to become a major energy source. Either we subsidise the entire industry to phase out non-nuclear and renewable energy sources, or we find some way of producing cheap nuclear energy, as right now it just isn't an economically viable option.

text:
Those cycles happen because of changes in earth's orbit over time, and are called milankovitch cycles. The direction milankovitch cycles predict our climate should be going in, and the direction our climate is currently going in, are not the same. According to the milankovitch cycles, we should be heading into an ice age right now.
The only reason Earth's climate is even affected by these cycles is due to the currently low concentration of CO‚ÇÇ in the atmosphere. If CO‚ÇÇ concentration rises high enough, it completely prevents ice ages from happening at all, barring a dramatic shift that pulls all of the CO‚ÇÇ back out of the atmosphere.

author: Matt G

text:
There is something very important about wind and solar power that very few people advocating them as a viable replacement for nuclear power seem to understand. Replacing nuclear power plants with wind and solar will actually increase your carbon emissions. Yes, I said increase.

This is because, barring a preposterously large investment in batteries, they require you to install power plants which can be rapidly brought online and taken offline to make up for the variation in power production from these sources. Solar is particularly bad for this, since output drops off at basically the same time as you typically expect a sudden increase in demand (right around when many people are arriving home work, cooking supper, that sort of thing.)  The types of power plants that can be onlined and offlined at the speed necessary are almost all less efficient fossil-fuel based sources. The options that aren't fossil fuel based are either prohibitively expensive, or require very specific geography.

text:
Many horizontal axis wind turbines, placed in areas where wind is abundant have their estimated lifespan significantly reduced; the wear and tear from environmental exposure is significant and even after one year turbine efficiency is reduced. They aren't destroyed after a decade; they would take the 25 years it says on the box; but the efficiency reduction and general wear and tear makes it more effective to replace turbines at a higher frequency, like every 10 years; even if you keep them running and don't replace them, you still need to make up the power loss from wear somewhere along the line.

A similar story is true for solar; but I don't have experience working with those plants, I know that heat exposure steadily degrades photovoltaic cells; I think they have a longer effective life than wind turbines but still not what it says on the tin.

Not that these plants are bad, I think KB still misrepresented them in the video; vertical axis turbines and solar heat farms, suffer these effects a lot less, but also have less gains overall. It's just that nothing as complex as this is as simple as it first seems. Renewables are certainly the answer, but we need to be realistic about the requirements they will entail on our production and maintenance projects.

text:
In fucking MIDDLE SCHOOL (the mid-2000's), I had a course called "Energy, Power, and Transportation" that gave me a project about comparing energy sources and writing a report on it. This opened my eyes to the potential for nuclear power, and how it, in conjunction with hydroelectric power, could supply way more energy for the US than it produced at the time, for way less cost and environmental impact over the power plants' lifetimes. The big blockade is public opinion, having been lied to regarding the severity of the effects of said impact, mostly thanks to the Cold War and how generations overlap, preventing a smart choice because of a bunch of bigoted old farts stuck in their ways and too stubborn to listen to reason.

Hell, even as a young teenager, I took the idea of "radioactive waste generates heat" and the need for water to cool it, applying that to the water cycle and how that water would evaporate over time, thus leading to my idea of merging hydroelectric dams into the infrastructure to get an added bonus of harvesting gravity from all the rain we'd get from extra evaporation. For fuck's sake, even now I consider the ability to take in seawater for cooling of coastal nuclear energy plants, allowing extraction of sea salt in the brine remainder as the coolant pools evaporate and become more saline. Yet another bonus, and we'd drive rainfall, leading to more freshwater!

Saying that radioactive waste is little and can be safely stored, is untrue. We in Germany have massive problems because of it. Originally we thought that we could store it under the earth with salt oder granite shielding the environment from the radiation. That failed spectacularly. And the waste is going to be there for millions of years. For longer than humanity has existed. 
And stacking all the fuel rods in one football field is impressive but meaningless. 
While it is true that nuclear accidents have killed less people than air pollution, it's still not 'safe'. In my opinion we should use nuclear energy now to get rid of fossil fuels but ultimately we should aim for producing our energy without it.

text:
So glad to catch this particular video early, since it's my specialty! Glad to see you approach this from a useful place; "It's a thing, how do we deal with it?" Because that's the discussion which needs to happen and has so much more depth.

I've studied this subject since 2011, and I feel like you're pretty spot on for most of these issues. While certainly not a critique, I'd like to put in a word on Carbon Taxes vs Cap and Trade, and the Environmental Economist arguments. Cap and Trade can be effective, if there is a provision to decrease the cap (Side note: Excellent expansion of the analogy to international agreements, that's a connection I've not heard in 9 years of study!), but it depends on perfect knowledge of exactly how to efficiently bring down those emissions. Should we cut by 3% a year? 10%? Just a non-percentage value, like 100 megatonnes? 

Taxes simplify this by letting the markets work out the exact amount we cut down, (economically ideal solution, not necessarily environmentally ideal, tradeoffs :/ ) but require some idea of how much damage 1 ton of CO2 does. Does it "hurt" the world $10? $100? $10,000? (We call this the "Social Cost of Carbon")

I'm rambling, and could go on about long-term discounting, or low-probability high-damages economics, but I'll stop! Despite the frequent setbacks, I remain optimistic that we can overcome this challenge. Thank you for your always excellent content, and for bringing an informed and consistent voice to a subject I can contribute to!

text:
¬†@shifted programs¬† Eh.............not quite.  You see, much like coal, radioactive materials are already in the ground.  The difference is that burning coal puts the ash into the air and water and everywhere else you don't want it.  Also, mining coal wreaks the environment around the mines.  Is mining uranium any better? Probably not.
But! Mining uranium turns a dangerous natural substance into useful work, whereas burning coal turns a mostly benign natural substance into dangerous pollution.  There are problems with nuclear energy, problems that can be researched and mitigated (heat pollution from cooling towers, etc), but the matter of waste products is a red herring.  The fuel was radioactive before we ever touched it, there are plenty of holes in the ground, just put it back where it came from.
author: Lawrence

text: shifted programs Technology has come a long way. Nuclear waste disposal and storage is not as big an issue as you may think. Lots of nuclear waste can actually be recycled! Using chemistry you can actually separate the small percentage of waste product from remaining uranium fuel rods. This is still an emerging science, but with government funding and public support the science will only get better and better! And the amount produced is negligible when compared to other industries. Plus, we have ways of safely containing this waste. I‚Äôm the future, launching nuclear waste into space could even be an option, perhaps using nuclear powered rockets! Really, the possibilities are endless. Unlike coal and some renewables, which just keep leading to dead ends.

author: Philip Freeman

text:
I love your channel and always eagerly await new quality content.
That said there was a rather unfortunate turn in this video.

On nuclear power and how big of a role it should play in our future energy production I disagree with your conclusion but that I dont mind.
Just to expand on that a little: Is Nuclear power better than fossil fuels in pretty much all regards? Yes, obviously it is and if we have to rely on some nuclear power for the foreseeable future until we hopefully find better solutions, so be it. However in my humble opinion it is not a sustainable long-term solution to all our energy-needs - at least not at the scales we are talking about. But okay we can disagree if Nuclear power should play more of a major or minor role going forward.

I think what we can agree on is: There is not just gonna be one magic solution to all our problems connected to climate change. In the end, if we ever are going to find a working solution it will be a mix of a lot of things hopefully working together and contributing to a shared goal: Reduction of greenhouse-gases to Net-Zero (and beyond) - ideally eventually leading to a circular economy that is not based on the exploitation of limited resources.


Which brings me to my actual issue with this video: The maybe badly named concept of "overpopulation" which is thus swiftly dismissed
To be fair I havent seen the Michael Moore film you referred to but for now I will just trust you, that your portayal of it is rather faithful to the original context.
Further I will go with the assumption that population growth will plateau rather soon at 10 Billion people - Not much more (about 25%) than our current population.
So admittedly according to your portrayal the film kinda missed the point in that regard but you just picked out that one flaw in one arbitrary presentation (said film) to dismiss the whole concept and left it at that.

So the issue here is: The West is living on a rather luxurious standard of living - one that is rather wasteful at that without much concern for the environment. (Tbc: That is referring to incentives and mechanics of our economic systems not individual people and their choices).
Now if the rest of the world wants to catch up to our standard of living we need the resources of 3-5 earths (including energy). Our way of living is just not sustainable.
Of course the solution also cannot be to kill off 80% of the world population and implement a cap at 2 billion so we can maintain our wastefull standard of living but rather finding a better way.
Whatever composition of solutions - with Nuclear power or without - we may employ: A big part of that has to be a massive reduction of [energy] consumption and waste. And remember we are not talking about the situation right now which is bad enough but about a world where the vast majority of population is trying to catch up to our wasteful standard of living. They may not grow much in numbers as you said - but are justifiably starting to demand their fair share of the limited resources. We have to start taking a good hard look how we can do that while lowering our footprint on the planet and where we have to take steps back. That may include reducing air travels to when it is absolutely nessessary - ending individual mobility (incl electric cars) and replacing it with efficient mass transportation, massively reducing meat consumption and so on. We have to be able to at least honestly talk about and discuss these things. Where can we reduce waste without sacrificing comfort and where might we have to make cuts and if so what of those things are so important to us that we rather take further steps in other areas?

I get that you have to limit yourself to get a point across in a concise way that isnt boring everyone to death - unlike me incoherently rambling on forever.
So ofcourse you are not obligated to be the one to talk about all that in detail.
I just find it a bit disturbing that you did dance around those points and then kinda dismissed all that by making up a strawman in form of that Michael Moore film without at least outlining the core problem here: Find a better descryption if you dont want to call it "overpopulation". That in a video for "adults talking" about Climate Policy.

So in conclusion: I was left a bit disappointed because I hold this channel in very high regards and thus apply much higher standards than usual (based on your past content). I am still looking forward to more excellent videos and maybe I get lucky and you do a follow-up to this one (So an even more Complete Moderate's Guide?)
Obviously I am rather passionate about this particular topic. I hope it didnt come across too harsh. :)


Edit: Also seeing that Footballfield with Nuclear waste is really disheartening. That is pure misinformation and shouldnt be in any well-researched video. That is talking only about spent fuel which obviously you cant pack that tightly (that is obvious right?). Spent nuclear fuel still is highly radioactivem, emitts heat and thus has to be maintained properly. You cannot just throw it on a football field and be done with it.
However that completely omitts the MUCH higher numbers in mid- to low-level nuclear waste - like cooling fluid and all the other stuff that inevitably comes into contact with nuclear material - all the way from mining to enrichment, nuclear reactors, maintanaince and eventually storage of waste. On top of that is lots of contaminated environment (water and soil). Wether or not that has any impact on your concern for nuclear waste doesnt matter. You shouldnt employ such deliberate misinformation to make it look like waste barely exists at all.

author: swanpride

text:
¬†@swanpride¬† In case you actually care about the answer:
No, that's not from the first year.  The nuclear waste quantity described is the sum total  waste product of commercial nuclear power running 20% of our power grid for the last 40 years.  Which is to say, you'd produce that much 'waste' every 8 years if we went to 100% nuclear and continue stored that waste as we currently do.
I put 'waste' in quotation because of what goes into counting as 'waste'.  That is the mass of the spent nuclear fuel - which is the better term for it.  It is the better term because about 94% of what comes out of the reactor is the same as what went into the reactor.  The remaining 6% is about 2% plutonium and other trans-uranics, and about 4% burnt up uranium (and fissioned plutonium).  That 4% that was burned up is what gave us the energy.  
Which means that those 'spent' fuel rods contain about 24x the amount of energy inside them that we have extracted so far. Without mining another gram of uranium, we could run the entire US grid for around 200 years.   But more on that in a second.
That 4% burnt stuff produces radioactive fission products that are very hot, and thus burn up and become non-radioactive very fast.  The more radioactive things are, the faster they decay and thus the sooner they stabilize and STOP being radioactive.  This can be anywhere from hours or days of stability, to years or decades depending on which isotopes in question you're looking at.  The longest-lived radioactive isotopes of this part of the fuel are cesium-137 and strontium-90, which have half-lives of <30 years and thus become 'safe' (less radioactive than the ore we originally got the uranium from) in about 10 half-lives, or 300 years.  Not the shortest timespan, but also not terribly long -  it's quite a manageable duration, considering the concrete storage casks last for 70-100 years.  You can go up and hug those things, and a train, plane, or automobile crashing into them won't rupture them (they tested that to make sure transport would be safe).  So we just have to let them sit on a glorified parking lot for a couple repackaging cycles and they're done.
The other 2% is plutonium and americium mostly.  These are the things with half-lives measured in thousands or tens of thousands of years.  First, this means they're so non-radioactive that you  can tolerate being around them without too much issue.  As long as you don't EAT them you wouldn't suffer much damage from limited exposure.  Still, it'd be better to do away with these somehow.  For instance, we can bury it in a salt mine that's stayed dry and geologically stable for the last 2 million years, and probably will remain so for the next 10,000.  That's a viable option.
So the actual waste to power the country for 8 years doesn't fit in the area of a football field - it fits in just the endzone.  Of that endzone volume, 2/3rds of  it needs light attention for a few centuries - not ideal but nothing beyond our capability - and 1/3rd needs some kind of additional effort.
One other option than burying a fraction of the waste, or all of it, is to make breeder reactors.  Ie. Reactors with efficient enough neutron production that they can burn up ALL of the Uranium and Plutonium.  You would toss spent fuel into these reactors, and burn it ALL up. into those short-lived waste products to get energy.  That's where the 24x energy comes from.  No more long-lived plutonium needing to be stored - the plutonium would similarly be broken down into the <300 year stuff.   Now we don't need to bury things (though, we still could if we want to).  And the volume that we get every year is quite small.
So, to summarize - that football sized area illustrated is from running the entire country's electrical grid for 8 years (equivalently).  Only 4% of that is actual waste, and the remaining 96% could be used as fuel in a properly configured reactor to power our entire country for the next two centuries. (That 96% would, over time that, turn into the same stuff as that 4% and need to be watched for 300 years after production).  
So basically, our overall volume for waste is going to be 300 years worth of production - as at that time waste will be produced at the same rate it can just be tossed back into nature no more dangerous than when it was dug up.   So, take that football sized area 3 meters high, add +1.5 meters (50%) to move us from 200 years to 300 years of electricity, and then multiply that by 5 for good measure in terms of random inefficiency, expansion of electrical grid to cover transportation, increasing energy usage of society, etc.  And you've got a volume the area of a football field around 20 to 30 meters high.  And that's the final, steady-state volume of all of the nuclear waste to run the country perpetually.
Where oh where will we EVER find the space to store all of that in a tiny country the size of the USA?

Personally, from the limited research I've done and the one college class I've taken on the topic (Which yes I know doesn't make me an expert) I believe that nuclear can be used alongside energy sources such as solar and wind, using nuclear as a means of transition from one primary source of our energy being fossil fuels to an array of renewable energy sources that, as time goes on, subplants the infrastructure we have in place. Obviously we seriously need to do something NOW about emissions, but you still have to transfer our infrastructure from being based on gas and coal to one where renewable/sustainable (or at least more sustainable and way less harmful to the atmosphere) is widespread and nuclear energy can act as a clean, efficient and more widespread form of energy as that transition is made over probably at least the next decade and a half even if things go right for us and people can just pull their thumb out of their ass for a sec so we don't ruin the earth forever. 
I truly do believe there is some reason to be optimistic about some of the potential growth and changes can be as we make a transition to I guess you could say "greener" energy and so on, and I think nuclear is one of the most sustainable especially when compared to what we have in place now. People seriously need to see how far we have come in nuclear plants and nuclear energy technology, it's so much more efficient and safe that most people have any clue of and I think it would get a lot more widespread support if people advocated for it more. I suggest anyone interested to go ahead and see the new advancements we have made in nuclear reactors since the 70's and even just a decade ago.

text:
You can be a skeptic and still be environmentalist. Skeptics understand that science is very often politicized. Nobody objects to lower emissions, cleaning up the rivers and reducing waste; but politicians screaming "THE END IS NIGH!" for the past 100 years about this and how only sweeping, authoritarian legislation can save us is dealt with suspicion and rightfully so.

I was hoping you'd bring an actual objective view to the subject of pollution and the third world, but you just slapped the race card on it and called it a day. Completely disingenuous, and China is about as trustworthy as North Korea when it comes to dealing with international organizations because they know the UN, et al, will do nothing. A single family home using incandescent lightbulbs, or a factory in Ohio not up to code, is literally nothing compared to how much China and India produce and I would not call them pre-industrial nations.

I don't even understand how you can't see that a pollution credit system is an incredibly bad idea, not to mention a lot of the ways the Green New Deal would have to be implemented to be effective. You admit politicians and science outlets lie about nuclear energy, and how they've fucked up their singular task of dealing with a global pandemic, but believe them wholeheartedly about what's needed to deal with climate change. How they've dealt with the coal industry and the populations that relied on it was horrendous. Solar energy initiatives were a scam at the tax payer's expense and much of the GND would be aswell.

Addressing population and birth rates: That's not true either. Africa's birth rates are skyrocketing but they're not having an industrial revolution. China/India show no signs of slowing down and indeed had their baby boom after WW2: their populations grew roughly 3-5x to a total 2.9 billion people in 100 years. Aswell, later generations of migrants into industrialized countries maintain higher-than-average birth rates. Right-wingers are talking about how the birthrate of native populations of Europe is falling well below sustainable rates and have mostly become minorities in their own countries.

author: M J

text:
You need to go deeper on nuclear.


The Big Problem (TM) with selling nuclear power to the general population is permanence. Saying "people live in Pripyat" is misleading. A few people brave the exclusion zone, but there is still a ton of dangerous radiation around. The tours people go on are guided to keep them away from the worst of the radiation. TMI-2 was slated to finally be dismantled after TMI-1 was shut down...in 2019. The Fukushima disaster is almost a decade old, and cleaning up the area around it will take decades more.


Even on the better, safer designs from Japan and the US, nuclear accidents create virtually eternal problems. If you want people to get onboard with that, you need better reactors. You need a full campaign to show how safe and controlled current reactors are, and how *UN*likely accidents are. You need to issue big, fat grants to universities to develop a new generation of cheaper, more efficient, and safer nuclear reactors that can be deployed everywhere.

Even though it's been around for decades (technically) nuclear energy is a New Thing (TM) that triggers the NIMBY response. People understand coal. They understand natural gas (which burns a bit cleaner and can be turned on and off to meet power demands). People do not understand the full scope of what nuclear energy looks like, nor what it needs to improve. All they see are the accidents...which are real. I'm in favor of nuclear power, but we need a deeper, more meaningful argument than "just go nuclear".

author: AeroMatter

text:
Lately I've been wondering what role infrastructure has played in climate change. It is a fact that concrete and asphalt trap more heat than trees and forests, and rapid urbanization has happened around the same time as we began pumping carbon into the atmosphere. As a result, this causes cities to be as much as 2.2 degrees C warmer than the surrounding nature. So, could a part of the rise in the global average temperature be explained by this? Clearly it wouldn't explain the whole of the warming, but it could explain some.


Speaking from personal experience, in high school my youth group would volunteer in urban areas like Royal Oak and Eastpointe, MI, and stay at a retreat house about 45 minutes away in the country. I remember the worksites we would go to were sweltering, but once we got back to the retreat house the temperature could be as much as five degrees lower. The one exception being when we were harvesting collared greens to send to Flint and it was over 90 F on the farm, and that was deep in a rural area.

text:
Virtually all current policy "issues" in the United States were agreed on up until the 80s and 90s when conservatives politicized them to win elections by lying.

The key thing you have to understand about conservatism is that it has virtually never been right about anything, ever, and so it has to keep moving the rhetorical goalposts over time because all of its arguments ultimately prove to be somewhere between "a pack of lies" and "actually evil." It's like playing whac-a-mole with public policy.

Take a hard look at the list of policies supported by conservatives in 1920-- white supremacy, denying the vote to women, child labor, unlimited pollution, opposition to the income tax-- it's a laundry list of mind-boggling stupidity, supported for no better reason than mindless status quo bias. Then think about what the conservative policies of 2020 are going to look like a few decades from now.

¬†@Emperor Palpatine¬† 
Almost all sources of energy that we use, even biomass and hydroelectric, require cooling. The steam used to move the turbines has to condense at some point. You don't create electricity out of nothing.

The cost to build the nuclear power plants will be eventually paid off by the tremendous amount of energy it can produce. It's an investment. A lot of renewables have a quick return but it's never going to be enough to supply 300 millions plus people. The sun is not on at night when people come home to cook dinner and watch TV. And it's not windy everywhere. And we have not perfected an efficient battery system.

As for water management, we use a whole lot in agriculture, drinking and municipal services. It's the reason why states like Florida and California experience shortages in water supply. I live in Florida and no matter how many storms we get, we use up all that precipitation. From what I understand, the water used industrially is trumped by water used in agriculture. I don't think it would be an issue allocating enough water to harness energy.

I think people need to redefine the term carbon free. Everything on this plant is either releasing or converting carbon. There is simply no zero emission. I think people want to do "net zero" emissions in which whatever amount is produced, there has to a mechanism in sequestering all of it. And I'm sure the technology is out there.

author: Clayton

text:
‚Äã¬†@Clayton¬† The far left is just as irrational as the far right.  The difference (in the US at least) is that the whole country is so far to the right that they don't really remember what true "far left" actually is, and they use the term to describe people and ideas that are very firmly in the center by any non-American (or even historical American) measure.
And of course that's somewhat by design.  People on average tend to shy away from both "extremes."  But as they redefine "extreme left" more and more toward center, the new "center" also moves right.  At some point (if trends continue) we'll start defining moderate right as "extreme left" and over time the difference between the redefined extremes approaches zero and everyone ends up very near the extreme right.  I'm sure that sounds like paradise to those who are already on the extreme right but everyone else is sitting there shaking their heads at that statement as if I was insane.
Yet its been happening.  And continues to happen.  Reagan's policies for example were far more similar to Obama's than they were to Trump or even Bush2.  And its not because Reagan was a dirty communist leftie.  Its because Obama is actually center or even slightly center-right by any normal definition, but the media has simply changed the definition to portray Obama as "far left" and in doing so shifts the whole (perceived) spectrum to the right.  The likes of Trump would have been seen as drooling craziness even by the right under America's own standards a mere 50 or so years ago.

text: NOPE you missed the whole point CFC were USED for REFRIGERATION. HFC replaced them FOR REFRIGERATION. How does refrigeration =  emissions of a green house gas? If I intentionally leak CFC or HFC out an HVAC system it is a huge fine and I will lose my liscense. Most aerosol propellents are propane or co2 based. Yes some LARGE industrial HVAC systems are allowed to have minor leaks that mean that eventually they will need to be filled with refrigerant but it is NOTHING compared to other "green house" gases. A home HVAC unit has a charge of a dozen pound that will often last the lifetime of the system, some systems may need a top off after 10 years of a couple of pounds. Compare this to the methane off gassing of the muddy pond or wetland area behinds someone's house and we have a negligible effect. Some people hear green house gas and freak out. Well guess what swamps and wetlands produce methane which is one of strongest green house gases, should we get rid of those? What about the very worst green house gas(water)? Water molecules in the air are the number one green house gas should we stop the sun from hitting the ocean? Wait don't trees convert co2 to oxygen and water? For every acre of rainforest we cut down 20,000 gallons per year do not get out into the atmosphere. Should we cut down all of the rainforest?

text:
Nuclear power plants last 50-60 years. The average age of an American nuclear power plant is 39 years. 

They're starting to close now and we're not building them any more (The two newest reactors opened in 2016 and 1996 respectively). They currently provide about 20% of electricity in the US, the reactors are closing, and none are opening. 

Over 80% of the electricity in France is from nuclear power. Nuclear is expensive and it certainly isn't just a silver bullet to completely solve climate change, but it is the only technology that currently exists that could power the USA emission free. 

The price of climate change is far higher than the price of clean energy. It will be rather costly when Miami and New Orleans are uninhabitable.

text:
This is a really dishonest way of describing Cap&Trade, which is actually a reliable way of reducing emissions.
The entire point is that you set limits on emissions below what a country would normally use - thus, creating demand for carbon credits, and driving their price up. This puts CO2 emitters in a position of choice - they either limit their emissions and make  money selling credits, or pay a lot to continue their old ways.
And since these limits shrink over time, emitters have to eventually adapt, or go out of business.

text:
¬†@Jose Garcia¬† I'd argue that, especially in the US, a cap and trade program is going to be much easier to get passed into law than a carbon tax would be. And cap and trade systems are proven to be effective. He mentions the elimination of acid rain, but completely neglected to point out that that's DUE TO CAP AND TRADE. Literally the most successful emission regulation we've ever had and he writes it off as "colonialism".



And he acts like a global cap and trade program is the only possible form. In fact, in practice, it's the sort of thing that would much more likely be implemented by a nation within its own borders (like the program that ended acid rain). Also, even in a global cap and trade program, it's certainly possible to account for the fact that developing nations will always produce more carbon in how the program is structured (e.g. giving developing nations more carbon credits).

author: Departed Reflections

text: I‚Äôm sorry as someone have dealt with ‚Äúcapping‚Äù in international politics, I can assure you it is not that easy. The hardest part is actually determining the ‚Äúcap‚Äù of the policy  itself. A developed country with its advanced industry and research could easily say ‚Äúoh we need X tons of carbon emission per square area/population of a country‚Äù and then China and India as the world most populous country still driving pollution like crazy because as developing country they haven‚Äôt reach that arbitrary cap number yet. Meanwhile other less populous/smaller developing country as they have reached this theorethical cap, are forced to stagnate. This is the problem with capping. The next problem with trading, how much could you put a ‚Äúvalue‚Äù on this carbon exchange? A developing country with huge rainforest such as Indonesia would love to get paid it Trillions of dollar, but those who are forced to pay this, would want to pay as little as possible. There‚Äôs also the problem of non-existent trade as the developed country is already under the cap and doesn‚Äôt need to pay (especially because they have the tech to do so) while developing country with older dirtier tech have no funds (as no one bought their carbon licenses) and even forced to pay because they are over the cap. Capping only benefit developed countries and harm developing country. Therefore, carbon colonialism.
author: Marcus Daniel

author: Nastronomical

text:
¬†@FrobozzElectric¬† It's not that it's bad if implemented poorly, it's that it was implemented poorly and that makes it bad.  The bit about carbon colonialism is true in that a poorer (person, company, country) might sell you their carbon credits to make a little money, but that hampers their own industrial abilities.  Think about a country that should be investing in power plants to meet the energy demands of a growing populace, or in manufacturing so that they can properly enter the global marketplace, and instead their leadership has sold all the carbon credits and agreed to allow the dumping of trash and/or hazardous waste in exchange for short term payments. 
Now you could say that "that's capitalism," and you wouldn't be wrong to say so, but it's also DEFINITELY taking advantage of the ignorance and/or poverty of those less fortunate, and that IS wrong. How any (person, political party, nation) can claim to be Christian and still support such activity under the guise of "free trade" is beyond me.

text:
Reduce the amount of energy used in total. There is an amount of energy that we need. Along side this is an amount of energy we want. We need to decide our wants over needs. Basic budgeting.
Once you know your budget you have the information you need to decide what your power generation mix will be. 
Example of needs would include heating and cooling, food production, industrial capacity, transport of goods.
Example of wants would include huge overpowered cars, the fashion cycle, new phone cycle, toys, bad diets.
If you reduce your energy use by good budgeting, then climate targets are easier to meet, and you need less generation capacity.

text:
I like the video but I think you are being too dismissive of the issue of overpopulation. You said yourself that we grew enough food for everyone. That is a huge problem. Animal agriculture is a massive contributor to greenhouse gas emissions and they exist because there are so many mouths to feed that expect a steady consistent level of meat. I think that overpopulation is an enormous issue that can't be talked about because our economic system is based on infinite growth and a declining population would tank the "economy". There is no way that the earth can "sustain" 10 or 12 billion people without accelerating our impact on the climate. Personally I think we need to start preparing to gradually reduce our (developed countries (highest per capita emissions)) standard of living and should seriously consider a replacement level child policy.
I know that's considered sacrilege by most people because "freedom" but there is no infinite growth on a finite planet and we either gradually reduce our population or the climate will cull us instead. Humans weren't meant to live the ages we lived and people had more children in the past because of high child mortality rates and because childbirth was often fatal. We outsmarted our natural form with medicine and by creating our supply chains meaning we don't have to hunt for food or make possessions. So while having children is "natural" and people feel they have the right to pump out as many as they want, they are doing so in a world that we have created to prevent "natural" events from occurring. 

But hey, all of this is hypothetical because convincing the average person to vote for a party to reduce their standard of living is laughable so I guess nuclear energy right?

text:
I feel like the rationale behind Cap and Trade has been presented a little "unfairly":
First of all, it is a system designed to set incentives to reduce your emissions. Some firms have cheaper options than others for reducing their carbon footprint. By being able to trade the "carbon credits", a market price forms and "determines" which firms will sell their credits and which will buy some, namely those will sell who can reduce, say, 1 unit of emissions for cheaper than that market price of credit. Therefore, those firms with cheap reduction opportunities reduce first. The trick here is to set the amount of "carbon credit" just so that reduction HAS to happen: if you just hand out as much credit as your economy happens to blow out, nothing will happen obviously.

Second, if nothing changed after that, the situation would not become better, of course. However, the amount of carbon credit is reduced every period by the government. This could happen through simple collection of some of that credit, or (what would be more popular with most industries and therefore politically more viable) via the government buying credit back at market prices (or lower, if that could be enforced...): Point is, without the government regularly and rapidly reducing the amount of available carbon credit, this system would just be like you presented it: not doing anything! However, if a government would follow through with the system, this could contribute to the reduction of emissions.
Of course, there are flaws with this approach: The actual production of emissions would have to be measured and non-compliance would have to be punished, which would add costs for enforcement. But honestly, so does every regulation. Also, the fact that by buying back carbon credit, you give those firms financial aid which have the hardest time reducing their carbon footprint, might in practice lead to financial support for the worst offenders when it comes to climate change, which might not sit right with activists. Also, when looking at actual real world attempts at introducing such a system like in the EU's case, the system failed because the amount of certificates ("credit") were not reduced over time. After every cheap measurement had been implemented, the amount of certified pollution and actual emissions about matched, which let their market price plummet. ALSO, the system contained legal loopholes, allowing firms to buy certificates and then write them off as lost profit and receive a tax cut WHICH OBVIOUSLY SHOULDN'T HAPPEN. Take-away here is, that it might be quite tricky to actually implement such a system.
This is also why I put "unfairly" in the first sentence: In theory, Cap and Trade can contribute a lot, in practice though it has not proved itself useful yet as far as I know.

So, yeah, long story short, I know that you cannot attribute a huge part of your video to such a minor detail, but I think, as I was here anyway, I could contribute my two cents to it. Cheers whoever actually read through this! Feel free to correct me on anything, I wrote mostly from memory and what I've learned in several courses over the years.

P.S.: What I didn't mention: Such a system of course requires also harsh financial punishments for firms which do not comply with their carbon limits. These fines would have to be costly enough to make reductions worth it (in the long run). Otherwise, why reduce your emissions when the penalty is cheaper?

text:
But solar and wind are cheaper than nuclear:

The economics of the nuclear industry worsened after Fukushima, according to a January report by the International Energy Agency and the OECD‚Äôs Nuclear Energy Agency. The report estimates that equipment costs have risen 20 percent since 2010, in part because of heightened safety requirements‚Äîeven as low-carbon wind and solar power got cheaper.

A 2014 analysis by the financial advisory firm Lazard captures the economics holding back nuclear expansion. Lazard pegs the cost of building nuclear capacity in the United States at $5.4 million to $8.4 million per megawatt. Adding operating, maintenance, and fuel costs yields an average lifetime cost of $92 to $132 for every megawatt-hour generated. That is far above the unsubsidized costs of utility-scale solar power ($72 to $86 per megawatt-hour) and onshore wind ($37 to $81 per megawatt-hour).

text:
Trouble is it rewards large companies (and countries) to the detriment of the smaller ones (and taken to an extreme, could even be used to stifle competition.  Say for example Tesla buys up all of the carbon credits they can find.  Perhaps that pushes people to shift toward electric vehicles and battery-backed renewable farms.  Conveniently exactly the products Tesla sells.  (Not that Tesla is really large enough to do that on a significant scale, but just as an example.  And there are companies that are large enough to do so.)
I'm more in favor of the carbon tax idea myself.  It certainly has problems as well, but its a much more balanced system (in the sense that companies know exactly how much they will pay per ton of CO2 whereas the C&T system makes it an open and therefore unpredictable market.)  The biggest problem though is that it doesn't actually cap carbon emissions -- companies can continue polluting as much as they want as long as they're willing to pay for it (which in turn just means passing the cost onto consumers.)  In the short term, the extra cost will drive companies to try and minimize carbon usage (so that they can keep prices lower than their competitors) but once that hits a new equilibrium point, a carbon tax just becomes another consumption tax and no longer has much environmental benefit.  Still, as the problem continues to creep up on us and we continue to ignore it, eventually short-term solutions are going to be the only remaining solutions because there will no longer be a long-term to worry about.

text: you aren't taking into account that solar/wind power counts cost by capacity *installed*, and not by what the actual capacity of a installed solar/wind averages out to. (usually less than 30%, whereas a nuclear plant will normally run around 90% capacity) on top of that what is usually not included is storage costs, which gets extremely expensive very quickly (we don't really have many great ways of storing electricity) but is absolutely necessary since renewables do not deliver their energy in a predictable way. you should check out real engineering's video on this topic for more detail (California's Renewable Energy Problem)

on top of all of this, we haven't even addressed the massive amount of waste and mining that need to go into renewables. there are dozens of toxic metals inside solar panels, and they are very difficult/energy intensive to recycle (and have thusfar just been disposed of). the mining process for many of these materials, but lithium especially creates toxic lakes of brine that can often poison local waterways. That kind of mining already has a huge environmental impact, but it will need to be scaled up exponentially if we mean to use renewables for our primary source of electricity (also for the expected increase in electric cars). it's not even clear if there is enough easily accessible lithium on earth to do a transition like what is needed. like obviously solar and wind are going to be big parts of our energy future, no one is denying that. but we cannot bury our heads in the sand to the extremely real costs to this technology and keep ignoring the most energy dense and safe energy source currently available if we mean to have an in any way adequate response to climate change.

text:
You're definitely underrating solar energy. Solar power is now so cheap it's profitable to build solar farms in Scotland of all places, and only getting cheaper over time - whereas the cost of nuclear plants is pretty static and there isn't any political willpower to massively expand capacity. Nuclear is good for providing a baseline, sure, but solar is so cheap that it's almost enevitable to take over the grid just because of the economics of it. I also think you rushed over Cap and Trade - sure, the amount of carbon remains the same, but now polluters have to pay more to pollute which would drive energy companies to renewables if fossil fuels would not be profitable enough to offset the cost of buying the credits, which is what would happen since coal plants are barely profitable in the first place. Plus, the government would reduce the Cap over time if they wanted to reduce overall emissions. A carbon tax (which is just a different way to implement Cap and Trade) in the UK has caused the share of fossil fuels in the national grid to plummet.

Pretty good video though - Pandora's Promise is an excellent documentary. Props for calling out the implicitly pro-genocide overpopulation weirdos. I just feel that everyone's perception of renewables is lagging behind 10 years, and it's fustrating still seeing solar energy not being taken seriously even from well-meaning pro-climate people like you. A stance like yours still implicitly plays into the false premise of decarbonising being some sort of worthwhile sacrifice, when in reality who wants to build a new coal plant when solar is ¬£0.25 per kWh and carbon tax free?

text:
Fun facts about Nuclear accidents:

1) The Three Mile Island accident had more to do with vague light and button settings, leading to confusion from the engineers as to wether indicator lights signified a meltdown or not. If you look at a picture of Pres Carter walking through the control room, every vertical surface and computer hub is crammed with buttons and switches that do God Knows What. TMI is now used as a classic example of how NOT to design buttons in Human-Computer Interaction courses.

2) Chernobyl was originally designed to be a nuclear weapons production facility and was meant to deal with Nuclear Fusion rather than Fission, which are the main function of Reactors.

We now have a better understanding of what works and what doesn‚Äôt when implementing Nuclear engineering, not to mention that our technology has come a LONG way in harnessing Nuclear Fission since the 1960s.

yeah so what about nuclear? kinda went over that quite quickly. 
Maybe because it's dumb to produce energy in a way that is able to causes the biggest possible disasters in human history. 
More nuclear plants only increase the chance of that happening again. 
Despite that, the only way fuel rods are currently disposed of is by throwing them into glorified landfills where it's only a matter of time (less than 1000 years for sure) until nuclear waste will seep into the ground water.
Also fuel rods can't be stacked into those sites as the video suggests, would be nice if you mentioned how much space they needed, packaged in the containers in which they get disposed of.

Even if we would recycle fuel rods, which is currently done in France for example, and fill up sites with fuel rods drawn out to the least bit of energy they'd still have to be kept away for at least 500 years, meaning we'd have to build thousands of those sites because they'll fill up very quickly. 
Imagine a society building hundreds of nuclear plants, mostly ignoring coal, solar, wind and other sources and slowly noticing they run out of available space that is fitting for the disposal of nuclear waste. Only a matter of time until we sell off our nuclear waste to 3rd world countries, like everything else we don't wanna bother to deal with ourselves, and cause massive humanitarian crises/enable foreign governments to stack up on nuclear material, just because we are too dumb or lazy to come up with a sustainable longterm solution to our energy problem.
Doesn't make any sense to me how people make an argument about replacing the one evil with another just because > I won't be the one having to deal with its aftermath ...
