author: Lukas

text:
The big issue you have with the renewables vs. nuclear comparison is scalability. Wind and solar simply do not put out the amount of electricity needed to serve as a base load supply. The largest solar farm in the USA at the moment is the 579MW Solar Star plant in California. The new largest one, which has just had its environmental impact study approved, will be 690MW in NV. It's going to take up 7100 acres of land. This behemoth will produce less electricity than one of the nuclear reactors at the recently closed San Onofre nuclear generating station, a plant with its current reactors that were built 30 years ago. And there were two of those reactors at San Onofre (SONGS) and they ran for 30+ years until shutdown, well before their 40 year operating license. 
While the 7100 acres part doesn't really matter because the Western USA has lots of empty space, we do have that issue of not getting much electricity from such a large investment. Sure its cheaper than a nuclear plant, but you get so much less with it. 

It's like choosing a pickup truck over a freight train. Sure the pickup is cheaper, but you're never going to haul near the freight you can with a freight train.

Therefore, the best option is to use the heat that is coming from the sun which currently is going to "waste" by heating up the planet directly. Better to intercept it, and use it to produce electricity, and then it will eventually be absorbed into the planet. But it was anyway going to be absorbed, so it's not as big of a problem. author: Michael Cheng

text:
¬†@Michael Cheng¬† ‚Äã Ah, now we are getting to the tricky questions. Since all energy usage is eventually waste heat (2nd law), we compare the effects.
Fossil fuels: greenhouse gas. Rejected.
Natural gas: greenhouse gas. Rejected.
Wind: birds, local climate effects, non-baseload. Rejected.
Solar: night, clouds, non-baseload. Rejected.
Nuclear: local marine/climate effects, very salty water. Plausible in the short term.
Hydro: few locations, fish. Plausible for some places. (Also, this is technically a type of solar plant, since the sun evaporates the water, but much better.)
Geothermal: possible local depletion, (low) greenhouse gas, large cost. Rejected.
Everything seems to be problematic.
In my opinion, solar combined with storage is the way to go, but we are not there yet. In places where hydro (a type of solar) is feasible, do it. Other than that, direct solar, but energy storage is the problem. Elon musk is working on batteries for this, and installed a nice system in Australia. Also, water can be pumped uphill during peak hours (a type of energy storage, but inefficient). Also, flywheels. Also pressure chambers (inefficient bc of lost heat from Gay-Lussac's law).
Yes, they all have issues, but intercepting the energy before it hits the earth seems to me the way to go, whether in hydro, or sunlight. This way you block it from reaching us, and then put it to use before it has a chance to integrate into the environment.
Japan is working on a solar panel in space. This would be the way to go.
Dyson sphere is the final goal of civilization.
Edited: Gay-Lussac's law, not Boyle's law.

author: Stefan Joeres

text:
¬†@Jeroen Bouhuis¬† How many tonnes of rock do you need to dig up to get the uranium stock to run a gigawatt nuclear plant for 100 years? How much simply for the aluminum that the blades of a wind farm that is the same capacity is made from?


I'll give you a hint, aluminum mining is roughly as polluting than uranium mining per weight of material, and a single wind turbine blade weighs as much as 2 years of uranium for a gigawatt plant, and it takes 333 wind turbines to make a gigawatt of capacity (which runs less than half the time, so you still have less usable power than a nuclear plant of the same capacity), and 3 blades per turbine means we're back to 1000, divided by 2 we have 500 times as much waste, just for the blades of the turbine vs the nuclear fuel for 100 years. Too bad the turbine won't last that long, making that 500 times worse obviously a very low estimate.


You get something similar with solar. Hydroelectric is very solid when we're talking about large scale dams, not so much when smaller systems. So yes, build the 2 more dams America has room for (it requires very specific geography, most places of which are already taken) while we're at it, but it won't be enough on it's own.


They're not safer. Hydro, if we ignore the several major accidents in China, maybe, but solar and wind both kill a few dozen people per year, verses the one person every few years of nuclear, and that's while nuclear is providing much more power than solar or wind.


Solar and wind also have the problem of, when being used as the primary generation method, requiring absolutely shockingly high excess installed capacity's to keep up with demand when they're in a slump. This means look at the amount of power you think you need, factor of 10 it, then at least another times 4. That's what you actually need.


Also note, recycling creates a very large amount of waste. 1 gram of aluminum creates 6 grams of toxic waste during recycling, for example, and the rare metals in solar cells are radically worse still, which creates either a titanic consumption to maintain the replacement rate on solar/wind, or a titanic waste stream, which actually directly rivals coal in waste and pollution, which frankly is horrifying, because coal is diabolically bad. Interestingly, this actually means solar specifically creates more radioactive waste than nuclear by a factor of over 10,000, just like coal (if you didn't already know, in addition to every other problem, coal creates massive radioactive waste streams) for a given capacity.


It's not that solar makes that much radioactive waste, it's that people massively over predict how much nuclear makes. It's literally grams per year.


Short recap: hydro, is very good, definitely make as much large scale dams as we can. Nuclear, literally the best in every way except hydro slightly edging it out in cost and safety (ignoring China's bizarrely bad track record of dam collapses killing thousands).


Solar, produces thousands of times as much radioactive waste for a given capacity vs nuclear, and remember, you actually need 4 times + as much capacity of solar because it's down more than half the time, so even this crazy ratio is still not fair to nuclear. It also creates a large toxic waste stream if recycling is used, or requires a massive mining stream to replace the panels. Still, it is arguably better for small projects of limited scope, do to low initial costs, but it suffers badly in long term cost effectiveness, and it suffers catastrophically if it is depended on as the primary power source.


Wind, basically the same as solar but with noticeably larger mining requirements, meaning more long term pollution, with the sole benefit being no radioactive waste. Is more expensive to set up, much more limited area's to be constructed in, but could still be argued to be better for medium term medium sized projects vs nuclear.


Long term power generation, nuclear wins by literally hundreds of times over in pollution, dozens of times in safety, and less than half the cost. It's very expensive in the short term, but once you factor in having to replace the solar/wind setup more than five times over the lifetime of the nuclear plant, literally outright multiplying their costs by 5, nuclear takes it easily. Long term, nuclear wins big, with the sole exception of large scale hydro, which as explained above, is strategically hard capped by geography.

author: tbarry12

text:
Isaac Sherman: you got an important point there. It's what they're doing in France, and an overwhelming majority of their waste is recycled (in a special plant in the town of La Hague), and then re-used. The only things they have left are actinids and other such waste products, which are a very very small volume of waste to deal with. They're currently digging a deep-storage site for it, which is a pretty impressive feat. 

They could actually recycle the waste a THIRD time, and they know how to do it, but because of political pressure their program was dropped, sadly. The fact is that nuclear waste is a problem that can be dealt with rather "easily", with enough investment of course. Now I say "easily", it's not /that/ simple of course :P But it's easier to do than inventing a new magical battery, since it's technology that is already known and used in Europe. 

But there are indeed many misconceptions about nuclear power yep. Such as "it will remain dangerous for millenia!", which isn't entirely true. It will remain radioactive for millenia, but many people don't realize that radioactivity drops over time, and rather quickly. A "fresh" batch of minor actinids will be dangerous and kill you if you stand 10 feet away from it. The same batch after 100 years, your only chance of being sick would be to actually grab it with your naked hands. The same batch after 500 years, you'd need to swallow it, to have a problem. But everyone imagines glowing, green barrels. =/

text:
IIRC Three Mile Island was the result of a system in which a button closed a valve and lit a lamp.  Except the valve didn't close, but the light still lit because it is operated by the switch, not an apparatus attached to the valve.  This sort of system has been eliminated in favor of a system that provides actual feedback.  The reason why it took so long to discover is because the panel SAID everything was configured as it should be, but there was a valve (open or closed) that shouldn't have been. 
For the record, rows of buttons and indicators are how the US Government and the 70s do things.  You should see literally any military equipment, those 387 light bulbs probably net someone $1M/yr just to keep all these panels lit up.

text:
I consider myself right-wing but I don't watch nor do I care for PragerU. In fact I don't watch a lot of right-wing content on Youtube. But in my opinion, disproving PragerU isn't necessarily helpful. Yes there are more people watching them then I am comfortable with, even people I know. But PragerU is like the Fox News of Youtube, I'd say. Disproving them probably doesn't reach the people who normally watch it, assuming they tend to be older viewers, and I'd argue that their reputation as a politically driven, hack channel is well known. In the same way that people don't take CNN and Fox seriously, I don't believe most people take Steven Crowder, TYT, or PragerU seriously. I think finding more genuine content that just so happens to be right-wing would be better. Not channels necessarily pushing an agenda but channels approaching the issue from a conservative perspective who happen to be people trying to address the issue in a meaningful way. Even if they're wrong, if you can see them trying to approach the issue in good faith, wanting to help people, then I think they would be a good source to debate. In this way I hope we could heal some of this toxic outrage that always surfaces when people with different opinions find each other in the comments section. We should set an example by respecting each other, not demeaning one side because of their fools. Attacking PragerU is easy. Approaching most controversial issues from a nuanced perspective is not.

I am with you when you say you've been lied and misled about it your whole life and you think it should be considered a viable option. I agree. I hear most of France's power comes from nuclear energy. I'd like to see more information on that being brought up in the future.
author: Matthew Lee

text:
Devil‚Äôs advocate:

If the Green New Deal tasks the federal government with creating millions of well-paying jobs, wouldn‚Äôt the simplest way to do that be to raise the federal minimum wage? I would argue the answer is yes. (Not something I oppose, btw. $15 is $31,000/yr for a full-time employee.)

Raising the minimum wage does have a trade-off, insofar as companies will raise prices to compensate. So while it‚Äôs dishonest of Rick Scott to say that ‚Äútaxpayers‚Äù would be on the hook, he‚Äôs not exactly wrong. He just wants you to draw the wrong conclusion, i.e. that your taxes will go up as a direct result of that minimum wage increase.

Then again, other taxes might increase slightly to compensate for depressed demand and reduced sales-tax revenue caused by price increases. It‚Äôs a balancing act. The only way to prevent possible price increases in the face of a minimum wage hike, is for the feds to outlaw them- a dubious prospect if there ever was one. Another option is for the feds to step up and pay the difference between the state minimum wage and the federal minimum wage, which would mean a tax increase at the federal level in order to prevent inflation or tax increases at state level.

I only bring this up because all too often we say ‚Äújust raise minimum wage!‚Äù without acknowledging that companies can and will raise prices. There is a cost to everything you do in regards to prices, wages, etc.

The ten-year time-frame seems arbitrary, but it‚Äôs a good round number that most people can understand.

The healthcare comments are indefensible though. We need single-payer healthcare already.

I can‚Äôt get on board with your comments regarding wind and solar. Solar panels are designed to last between 20-30 years, and there are wind farms all over my state, and outside of the yokels down south complaining that wind turbines can read their dreams and are making them nauseous, there seems to be little reason not to use them. If the ‚Äúwaste‚Äù you‚Äôre talking about is from burning fossil fuels in the manufacture of solar panels and wind turbines, sure, but those processes will improve and change over time. Using these methods to generate power does not create any waste. The initial ‚Äúinvestment‚Äù of fossil fuels burned to power the manufacture of these devices is fairly quickly recouped over their lifespan.

Nuclear power is fantastically dangerous if the waste is not handled properly. Where are we going to put the stuff? It‚Äôs just another kind of landfill! Do you want it outside of your town, leaching radioactivity into your groundwater?

text:
The U.S. stimulus package this year is going to be around $3 trillion. Annual US electrical power generation is ~4 trillion kWh and is already ~20% nuclear and ~17% renewable. A 1 GW nuclear power plant costs around $7 billion and produces ~8 billion kWh per year. So we would need to build 4000*(1-.2-.17)/8 = 315 new nuclear plants at a cost of 315*$7 billion = $2.2 trillion if we wanted to transition our entire electrical grid off of fossil fuels. 
This is just a rough estimate (check my math) but it seems like it should be possible to transition to nuclear over 20 years if there was political will and financial incentives to do so.

text:
Great piece, I have always loved well researched pieces like this, and I thoroughly believe that the best way to fight climate change is to get the US to follow the (rest) of the developed world. I don't know a lot about economics, but only will-fully ignorant people would argue that leading in any technology field is a goldmine, and that any country with the means to research emissions reductions.


See, I work for one of the seven sisters (what used to be the 7 largest westernised oil companies). I work with amongst other things to reduce CO2 emissions, as well as CO2 trading under the EU Emissions Trading Scheme. So I feel I could help make two clarifications.


First off, Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS, or CCSU if you utilize it as well), is normally not one next to a factory as the CO2 concentration in the air is only like 0.04%. It's normally done on stacks (chimneys) themselves, as it is a lot more efficient, as the concantration is a lot higher.


Second off, cap and trade can easily be done in a way to reduce the overall CO2 emissions of a country/area. For instance in the EU in EU ETS Phase 3 (2013-2020) the emissions allowances are reduces about 22%, at least on all the refineries and oil fields I have worked with. So you apply for allowance allocation and based on your historic through put/emissions you get a certain allocation. Then every year you get fewer and fewer allowances. Which mean you have to buy more and more if you dont reduce your emissions. This will be more and more expensive, as allowances can only be bought from other companies so there is only a finite amount available. In the EU this meant that from 2013 to 2020 (before the corona virus) the price for emitting one ton of CO2 rose from about 5‚Ç¨/t to 25‚Ç¨/t. And if you at the end of a year dont have enough allowances you pay a fine of 10+ times the allowance price (or something like that, I forget exactly how it works right now). But the company still has to make up for any missed allowances the next year. 
This means if you can reduce your emissions for let's say 40‚Ç¨/ton it's not going be done, but you will have to buy more allowances. But if someone else can reduce their emissions for 10‚Ç¨/ton then they will, and sell the abated emission allowances. If there are not enough available, the market price of allowances go up, and more projects will be viable, due to the cost of fines/allowances.
Of course the corner stone of doing the cap and trade method, is to make surethe cap is set low enough to actually make a difference.


I would also advocate for an addition CO2 tax, among other things.


All the money the EU make off the EU ETS goes into the Green Innovation fund (I think is the name, at least it is in Danish) which will at the end of 2020 start to more aggresively fund green research. Last I checked this account had 672B ‚Ç¨ in it. Thats enough for quite a lot of research grants.


Also, Nuclear is a very good idea, however, I, as so many others, would like it to not be placed near my house.


I hope this helped understanding these two concepts.


Making this comment made me think, it would be interesting to see a video about parts where you (KnowingBetter) has either changed your opinion on something you said in a video or simply been mistaken on a fact or otherwise. :)

text:
Pressurized water U-235 fission reactors, like the majority of those used in the US, are inherently stable and fully contained and designed to be safe even with a catastrophic failure.

Fukushima and Chernobyl were boiling water reactors that require meticulous observation and control to maintain them in a safe condition.  Companies like GE will try to convince us that they have extensive automated controls in place to prevent incidents - you know, like the Boeing 737 Max has.  When a reactor design is more efficient, it usually comes at a cost.  Even if pressurized water reactors may not be as efficient as other reactor designs, they have an extensive history of safety all over the world by the US Navy where, aside from 1-2 years of Navy training, the officer may only have a degree in music or art and the operators only need a GED or high school diploma.

text:
¬†@Leon Smuk¬† " mean it is the waste that poses the longest lasting risk to life on earth far beyond anything humans ever produced."

I am guessing you are unaware that we produce a lot of chemicals far more dangerous and longer lasting than radioactive waste?

Like I think a lot of people forget 3 things.  

One, is that radioactive waste decays.
Two, the longer the halflife, the less radiation it produces.
Three, the natural world is also radioactive; how the hell do you think we mined it?


Or to some it up, highly radioactive waste that produces a lot of radiation can be stored in temporary storage long enough for the most radioactive isotopes to decay.

Afterwards, the remaining isotopes are a whole lot less radioactive, and can generally be secured in dry casts; casts that you can touch all day with no chance of radiation sickness.  And then after a while, lets just say civilization collapse for some reason; you merely have something as radioactive as natural ore sitting around underground like natural ore.

If somehow is the "longest lasting risk to life on earth far beyond anything humans ever produced"; then I am surprised that we somehow survived the natural radioactive ores on the planet.

Also I feel like informing you of an interesting official unit of radiation dose.  The BED, the Banana Equivalent Dose.  It is equal to about 0.1 microSieverts.

text:
¬†@Leon Smuk¬† 
Q.) How is the waste disposed of? A.) It is put deep underground and surrounded by lots of concrete.
Q.) Are dump sites made for mandatory storage time? A.) Yes, but we don't know how well they will work because we haven't been able to study the dump sites for thousands of years yet. We currently use archaeological data to generate inferences about what will last long enough--due to the unknown element we overcompensate and build the sites to last much longer than necessary.
Q.) How much waste can we store before we run out of adequate storage space? A.) We'll run out of nuclear fuel before we run out of waste space.
Q.) To what degree would that allow us to power our lives with nuclear power? A.) At our current global energy consumption, probably anywhere from ten to a hundred thousand years.

Why would you be more against it as you look more into it? The data clearly shows that nuclear power is by far the best energy option at our current tech level.

Not exactly apples to apples, there.

text:
¬†@Leon Smuk¬† An important thing that people refuse to learn: the longer an isotopes half life, the less radioactive it is. Take two masses if isotopes. 1 has a short half-life of arohbd a month, 2 has a long one of 200 years, and they both have the same amount of energy.

Isotope 1 is very radioactive initially as it lets out half of it's energy in 1 month. But then half of it is gone, and the next month its output is half as much. Within 12 months, if it started at 200 times the background dose (a concerning level) , it will have dropped to less than half a percent of that initail dosage. So it drops the background radiation level very quickly. 

Now look at sample 2. Because its Halflife is 200 years, it emits that same dosage over 200 years. Meaning from the start it will have a dosages of 1%. And immediately it sits at just above back-ground. So literally harmless from the start. 

In nuclear energy you either start off deadly and quickly become harmless, or you start off mostly harmless and stay that way long term. If nuclear could be super dangerous for long term it would be the perfect energy source, as what makes it dangerous is how much energy it has in it.

text: It's my understanding that nuclear waste is first cooled down before being stored in water tight containers buried underground, typically in the Yucca Mountain Nuclear Waste Repository in Nevada. This means that there is very little human or animal activity in the area, with plenty of signage to prevent people from stumbling upon it in the future. These facilities could take much more waste than we could produce in the near future, while storing it safely for thousands of years. Furthermore, we would hopefully be able to shift away from this pollution farther down the line. For example I've heard that it may be possible to continue use these 'spent' nuclear cores on less efficient but longer lasting nuclear power facilities. Keep in mind the impacts that the 'business as usual' burning of fossil fuels is having on biodiversity and quality of life.

text: I studied environemntal science and there are a few  problems with nuclear energy, starting that it's that is not cost effective. Another issue is that it takes up to decades to build one powerplant (takes longer to take one down), also accounting for the money and infrastructure to make the structure safe and deliver the energy. The main concern is how to transport and safely dispose of nuclear waste. I undertand that using other forms of nuclear material, other than uranium, can improve nuclear energy, but in a large scale it doesn't change much) The key to a sustainable future is utilizing various renewable resources, and implementing them in our daily lives, and establishing a network of co-dependence instead of a single powerplant delivering all the energy (which would also protect the US from an attack to our energy structure). Such implementations are also related to the geographical conditions of the place, how in the Midwest like in Wyoming wind power is better, and in Iceland the hydrogen produced by geothermal is widely used. The hydrogen collected can also be used as an alternative fuel for cars (Toyota made a car model using hydrogen, it's pretty cool how it works, you could go check that out)

text:
¬†@Susan McManaway¬† We already know how to recycle 96% of spent fuel rods into new fuel. The 4% of remaining ultimate waste (actinids) can be mixed with melted glass, then encased in steel and concrete containers before being stored in geologically safe strata with self-filling properties. The whole thing takes less space than one oil field.
No other energy production ever puts the necessary effort to clean up their far more toxic mess. But keep going. Burning coal alone kills 7 million people each year by causing respiratory diseases. And that's normal use, with years old data. Who knows how much more people die now? Same remark for natural gas and biomass.
As for solar and wind, mining and production alone is very toxic and destructive, due to needed rare elements. That stuff is chemically toxic on its own and can't be recycled. It's bound to pollute the environment, forever. Nuclear waste decays, not stable and chemically toxic materials used in solar panels and the likes. And it takes so many more of that stuff to produce the same amount of electricity. It's like you're comparing the dangerosity of a landmine buried too deep somewhere to hit anyone, with a massive stockpile of arsenic left unchecked on the surface.

I do think nuclear waste should be "rebranded" though and we should start calling it nuclear fuel. Most people think nuclear waste is useless and needs to be buried in the ground where it will remain radioactive for thousands of year, therefore posing a significant threat to the environment. Most people don't know nuclear waste, or "nuclear fuel" can be recycled and reused.

If I remember correctly the amount of nuclear waste/fuel in the U.S could be used to power the entire country for 100 years.

text: This is another brilliant video, but I can't help but disagree with your point on cap and trade. The EU has an emissions trading system that means these credits are counted into the price mechanism a company faces. So having to buy those credits will put them at a disadvantage, from a cost POV, from companies that are selling their allowances through successfully 'greening' their production. I think it's a great use of the price mechanism to incentivise cleaner production methods, which btw are often more expensive and this trading system allows for a way to raise funds to this end and continue innovating in the field. It should and must be part of the answer.

i don't know kw's perspective but i think that overpopulation is a terrible perspective. the only way to solve overpopulation is to, as the word itself implies, change the population. how can we change the population? we can change the birth rate or we can change the current population. we can lower the birth rate by doing something like china's one child policy or we can change the current population by killing people. both options are terrible. the former is proven to be awful in china and the latter is genocide.


i like your equation but focusing on the population and centering any solution on only the population number would lead to genocide or tyrannical birth control. our only option is managing how much each person impacts nature. thanos is the villain for a good reason.
author: Purple Dick

text:
¬†@Purple Dick¬† Thanks for the reply.
Firstly, you're forgetting that most countries still actively encourage and support people having children, for example with financial support. That should stop.
However, even if that is not enough, I don't agree that having a "fewer children" policy (China's approach may not have been the best precedent here) is "terrible".

Simply put: if we ecologically just CANNOT afford to have more humans on this planet, then we CANNOT allow people to freely fulfill their desire to have more children. That's not to be cruel, but if you're broke, you can't afford a new TV. If the environment is broke, you can't afford more children. And if you're looking at climate change, deforestation and mass extincting, we're already getting deep into dept and it will catch up with us soon.
Sorry to say, but fulfilling your desires to have many children is just as selfish as fulfilling your desires to have a gas-guzzling SUV and eat beef all day.

text: Why should we not be worried about overpopulation? We have finite resources on our planet and our current economic system requires infinite growth through a steadily increasing supply of people to buy and consume things. Do you think that the planet can sustain 10+ billion people now, let alone in 30 years when we have millions of climate refugees? All of these people need food, most people like meat so that's an increase in agricultural emissions. I made a longer comment elsewhere in the thread, but if the concept of overpopulation is so contentious we are in serious trouble. Medicine has let us live far longer than we would have previously; humans in their natural state did not live this long and had more children due to survival and infant mortality. I think that the shock about overpopulation has to come from an economic viewpoint because limiting ourselves to replacement level birthrates would do our future generations a lot of good.

text:
¬†@TheBrodsterBoy¬† I did watch the video. You've ignored my point. Agricultural practices contributing to feeding those billions are the problem. Cattle emissions are a massive part of global emissions. Now unless you are advocating everyone in the world go vegan which would be incredibly unlikely but very helpful, just feeding the people alone contributes to this climate change. And just because we produce enough food doesn't mean it is spread equally with access for everyone. We need distribution networks, supply chains that all rely on power and supply and demand principles to continue. You can see this right now with the excess potatos in Idaho now, where thousands of tons of potatos are being left to rot due to supply line issues (restaurant industry is declining due to the closures while retail industry is experiencing shortages in some places).


I'm trying to engage with the topic a little more than one line responses.

text: ¬†@Roan the Delphox¬† I can't answer that, I was just giving my interpretation of the end of that particular South Park episode. However I will say why does that matter? When you have the information that if you continue down the road you're on it is sure destruction, do you continue down the comfortable path that requires no change or do you do what is necessary to avoid destruction? Or do you say the sacrifice is difficult, maybe I'll only give up half the required amount- delaying the still assured destruction? Once you start asking things like "Yeah but what will I have to give up to save the planet that all foreseeable future generations will be trapped on?" (We're not going to be living on mars any time soon) you have to realize that you're part of the problem. It just doesn't matter when the stakes are that high. I think the real problem is mistrust for authority, "How do I know I'm not being asked to give up more than necessary?" Or something along those lines, idk, but if we have to all start living like the amish in order to save our planet, are you not willing? You would condemn the entire human race to destruction because of your comfort and unwillingness to change? That honestly is the question and the stakes.

author: Max Mustermann

text:
Amazing good video! As a French with a different education/philosophy, I agree with like 95% of the content, the only point I disagree is overpopulation.
-I think that overpopulation is a thing, not because we are simply too many, but because we consume too much, and if we want to come back to a sustainable level, even with all our current technology, we have to lose too much comfort to be "acceptable" by the mass (such as democracy as we know it, but it is another debate ^^).
-I believe you think that overpopulation is not a thing because you make the archaic assumption that "infinite growth" is a thing, and if it is the case I can only advise you to read the book "The limits to growth" (or the Meadows curve).
-In any case, overpopulation is not our 1st problem today, and our current ethics prevent a "management", and I am fine with that.
-About nuclear power, I 100% agree on this point, just, I will add that "dangerous nuclear wastes" only stay on earth about 300 years, whereas CO2 stays in the air for thousands of years, and in opposition to nuclear wastes that we can safely store on a specific location, CO2 cannot be extracted from the atmosphere, which means the 1.5 ¬∞C objective is already lost, and won't be recovered during the 21st century, or even the 25th.
Thanks you ^^

text: The intro reminds me of one of my all-time favorite Shaun (skull) quotes: "Here in the 'Free Marketplace of Ideas,' I will debate any idea with you - so long as it's debatable." Basically, he says he's not going to argue over a provable, black-and-white factual statement like 2+2=5, because someone who has looked at the evidence and has come to that conclusion isn't properly equipped to understand why it's wrong (and it's not worth having someone so embarrassingly inept at factual discourse on your side anyway). He broadened his example to whether everyone deserves human rights, because he was discussing the many problems of white nationalism, but it applies here, too: if someone has looked at climate data and is willing to argue that climate change is not happening, they're not properly equipped to deal with this discussion yet and it's not worth trying to convince them that they're wrong.

text:
Australia being green in regards to the Kyoto Protocol is a bit of a furphy. Firstly, it took ten years and a change of government for us to sign it, and even then, we pushed for ridiculous land clearing loopholes to keep our numbers down- basically, we get points for not clearing land that we were going to clear, and we use those points to offset our greenhouse gas emissions. So we aren‚Äôt planting more trees, and our emissions are still going up. 

So we aren‚Äôt actually doing anything, it just looks like we are if you only take into account some very creative accounting. And we did this for the Paris Agreement too. Oh, and we are still clearing land at a pretty big rate too. 

You‚Äôd think that as the developed country that is the first to be hit by climate change in a very noticeable way, we‚Äôd care a bit more. I mean- we cared about the Ozone layer, because it‚Äôs rather close to where we are, it affects us. But climate change? Apparently not. But hey- we gotta make that number go up on the computer! That‚Äôs what really matters! üôÑ

Also, the US is not the only country that has the debate- plenty of climate denial it‚Äôs in Australia as well. Don‚Äôt forget, we are the largest coal exporter in the world. A lot of jobs, and even more money, is riding on certain people being able to pull the wool over the eyes of at least some citizens. So Australia absolutely has plenty of climate change denial- again, even though we are the first developed country to really feel it.

text: The main argument is the degree, or extent that climate change is taking place. The first thing to note is that the only legitimate way to make the comparison is to discuss the issue in terms of absolute temperature averages, not in celcius or farenheit. You must use Kelvin or Rankine. For example, since 1880, according to NASA, the temperature has risen from 287 K to 288 K. Something else that is rarely discussed is that the agricultural production per acre of land is dramatically increasing due to the CO2 in the atmosphere. I know many geologists who explain how CO2 will end up in the oceans as calcium carbonate after dissolving in the water. I used to have some apprehension about the global warming, but am far less alarmed. I have no issue with the use of fossil fuels as long as it is used in measured and efficient ways.

text: Okay, so here is the thing. I am with you in principle. Climate change is real and we need to take action to combat it. Even if it was not real I think we would all benefit from keeping the planet cleaner. Your breakdown of the green new deal though was way too defensive of it. Its the very fact that it was not a serious proposal that makes it so aggravating. It was just virtue signaling at best. Its stated goals really were outrageous and impossible and they only reason it was created is to frame anyone who disagreed with it as climate change deniers and selfish people who don't care about the future of the planet. I don't think we should defend virtue signaling or political posturing with this issue. The actual writer of the bill (or at least biggest influencer) acknowledged that its actual main focus was to "restructure the economy". It had more about economic and social reform with a few unfeasible ideas about battling climate change. It is in no way worth defending. It also lacked common-sense reforms that actually would be good for climate change, for example, the best tool we have to remove carbon emissions is nuclear power, which the green new deal excluded as solution. Nuclear waste is minuscule and very easy to deal with compared to climate change, its also far more economically feasible. The green new deal put way too much of a focus on things like solar and wind power which actually have major issues with them. Whenever those sources stop procuring power they have to rely on coal or natural gas to pick up the slack. France increased their carbon emissions by trying to move from nuclear to solar and wind. In conclusion, as someone who normally likes what you have to say and someone who is not a climate change denier, you should be attacking things like that. Insincere, virtue signaling and political posturing like the green new deal make actual politically and economically feasible change look much less attractive.

text:
My suggestion is to find a way to take advantage of it, rather than trying to prevent it.  Mine the air instead of the ground for fossil fuels.  Find ways to use the excess heat to generate energy.  Wear fewer clothes.  Build towers on low lying islands to take advantage of the eventual excess living space and oceanographic research when lower floors with windows go underwater.    Raise trees to remove pollutants from the air and soak up carbon.  

Nuclear is a very, very, very good option.  And it needs to be a part of the solution.  But there is another solution that is being utterly ignored, and it's the solution to overpopulation, pandemics, climate change, and globalization:  Decentralized production (including nuclear- a radiothermal battery with adequate shielding is no bigger than a hot water heater and buying ONE will produce enough electricity for your entire household for 1,600 years before it is recycled).  Transitioning will still be difficult and expensive, but the end result will be spreading out our population, reducing the chances of pandemics, and local food production that can support more people instead of building cities on top of the best farm and fishing grounds.

Oh, and please, no more seawalls.  If your damn city *NEEDS * to be where it is, and it is sure to get flooded out by climate change, you have two MUCH better options than miles of seawall:  1.  Build large buildings higher and lower floors watertight, with a design that is easy to close off floors as the sea level rises.  2.  Seasteading- build your suburbs on the water out of houseboats to begin with.

Also, do you mean the first law of thermodynamics? So, since energy is neither created nor destroyed, then we can't possibly heat up the earth??
The issue is that we are ALREADY heating up the earth. It doesn't matter to the earth where the extra heat comes from. Right now, it's coming from thermal energy trapped by greenhouse gas, with only a small percentage coming from direct energy usage. author: super shluffy

text:
¬†@super shluffy¬† You need to stop.  You seem to lack a lot of understanding here.  I'm certainly not an expert, but my degree is in engineering so take that with a grain of salt if you must.  Nuclear energy has a phenomenal track record, despite three HIGHLY publicized incidents, one of which was contained (Chernobyl) and a second created no lasting damage at all (TMI).  Chernobyl wasn't destroyed or shut down, the other reactor on site produced power for something like 30 years since the incident.  Even a melting reactor isn't an atomic bomb, it's not like TV.  
All energy production puts heat into the environment.  All energy transfer puts heat into the environment.  When you put food into your refrigerator it relocates the heat into your kitchen via the coils on the backside.  When you put dog poop and glass clippings into a mulch pile they create heat as they decompose.  Charging your cell phone, laptop, or electric car releases a bunch of heat from the battery and cables.  Driving a gasoline car releases a bunch more heat as a result of the inherent inefficiencies of that engine.  Converting the DC from solar into 60 Hz AC (50 for you weirdos ;p ) creates heat from the inversion process.  Friction from your tires on the road, from your shoes on the floor, from an airplane pushing through the air, they all create heat.  Simply having concrete or asphalt roads traps heat because it just re-radiates locally and creates "heat island" effects. 
Elsewhere someone mentioned the aluminum needed for wind turbines - aluminum requires immense energy to refine from ore, more than most other materials.  That's the reason that it's so heavily recycled despite being very abundant in nature (bauxite). A real comparison, if you'd like to work the numbers for me and educate the rest of us, would be to compare the energy released as heat per energy released as electricity.  You can format your answer as J/J or J/kWh or whatever you prefer. I'm sure you'll find that the thermal emissions aren't quite as bad as you were imagining.
author: Lawrence

text:
‚Äã¬†@Lawrence¬† Such a long comment for someone who appears not to have read my comment.
I never mentioned disaster potential, and I clearly said "It doesn't matter to the earth where the extra heat comes from." It's not about nuclear specifically. And then you went on to give examples of the 2nd law.
Since my last 3 comments were blocked, I'll attempt to make this comment short.
Currently, we are trapping an extra 5million TWh per year from greenhouse gases. This is what is causing the issue in the first place. Once civilization is using that much energy, it won't matter that it's not due to greenhouse gases. It will still be added to the environment. A low estimate for this to start happening is in about 100 years.

text:
Those agreements were not as friendly as you make them seem.  
Dismissing any opposition as "climate-deniers", is not accurate. The loud, dumb ones, may be deniers. But most of those who oppose the agreements, that I know, do so because they are really bad deals. They place a significant financial burden entirely on the western nations, who also have to pay for the developing nations improvements. A double hit on the west, but no restrictions on the developing nations from continuing to ramp up coal and other negative practices, while collecting the environmental aid from the west.  
They were very expensive, and deeply flawed plans, that left many believing they were doomed to fail at everything except consuming revenue, and stifling growth in the west. 
What we need is a better deal, for all. 
This idea that since the west started industrialization sooner, we should just let everyone else have a turn, and shut-up while being the only responsible ones, is backwards. 
We all live on the same planet, and share the same global climate. We need to work together. And all do our part.

text:
¬†@I came; I saw; I cringed¬† 1. Did you even watch the video?
2. Most waste can actually be recycled, though we admittedly haven't been doing that. And even then, those "mountains" of waste are more like a single molehill. 
3. An unpredictable climate is only more incentive to fully nuclearize, because wind, solar, and hydro become even more unreliable.
4. The science has already improved to the point that we are already at safe nuclear. Every accident you listed has been with a Gen II design. We're currently on Gen III, many of which physically cannot meltdown. We could've been building more Gen III reactors decades ago if not for NIMBYism. Hell, we could be building Gen IV reactors right now, and they provide even greater efficiency, waste reduction, and accident reduction than Gen III.
author: Sam Ferguson

text: THORIUM AND FUSION REVOLUTION!
author: Captain Chair

text:
¬†@Ian billgates¬† What plant in Japan are you talking about? There was a company called  International Thorium Energy & Molten-Salt Technology who were going to build one, but they ran out of funds. Most of their R&D was taken over by another company (Thorium Tech Solution) but even they haven't built a reactor yet. In fact, while there is a lot of interest around the world in developing a working commercial Thorium MSR reactor and there have been plenty of plans developed, to the best of my knowledge there's no working modern Thorium MSR in existence - not even a prototype. 



That's not to say it can't or won't happen, just that these plants DO NOT exist right now and there may still be unsolved technical issues that need to be resolved before they can be used commercially. Personally, I believe that Thorium MSRs may well become the solution for our long term energy needs and I fully support the idea of doing more research into that field and actually building more prototypes so solutions to the technical issues can be proven, but unless you're from the future, please don't talk as if all that's been resolved already.


In terms of Uranium reactors, there's effectively unlimited fuel available, but using current extraction methods there's only about 250 years worth of supply available in an economically viable way - at current consumption levels. If we were to ramp up nuclear power generation, that would also increase the amount of fuel used. For example, it's estimated the world's viable supply of Uranium would be consumed in just 50 years if only half of the world's electricity were supplied by uranium fueled plants. That means nuclear fission reactors may be a good medium term solution to our power needs, but they won't work for the long term unless significantly more efficient ways to extract Uranium can be found.

author: Nathan Johnson

text:
¬†@Nathan Johnson¬† For now, you are correct. But you should think more long term. The future needs of society will be many times higher than they are now. If we all push toward nuclear now, then this will lead to a path where the whole world builds more and more nuclear plants because of how cheap it will become. And when fusion technology comes, people will flock to that even faster, and there will be no stopping it. By being so cheap, nuclear energy will end up producing a significant percentage of the sun's rays.
Also, the hot water added into the oceans are already killing huge swaths of marine biology, and this imbalance to the marine habitat will have an even more devastating impact on the environment. I'm just saying we should push toward a solution that has no chance of backfiring down the road.
To be clear, I'm not saying we should avoid nuclear (if we can prevent marine habitats from being destroyed). I'm saying that we should treat it as a transition technology, rather than the endpoint, so that when other technologies become available, they won't be ignored the way nuclear is now.

author: Tyler Kapteyn

text:
¬†@Praise The Sun¬† 

1. Plutonium is the only way to make nuclear weapons if you'd like them to be effective nuclear weapons. You can make them with Uranium, but you need to do the same amount of separation, if not more, and you need a lot more of it. There is a reason nobody builds Uranium gun weapons these days. The USA did it once and everyone who figured it out afterwards, didn't bother with that method. Even India, who used Uranium 233, didn't bother with another one. And commercial nuclear power plants produce the wrong kind of Plutonium to make effective nuclear weapons. Pu-240 is too unstable and spontaneously fissions. You need Pu-239 which is stable enough to be stored for use in a bomb, but doesn't exist for very long in the core of a commercial reactor. You would need to run the reactor for a short period, then extract most of the fuel (the reactor is offline for this) and insert new fuel, then repeat this process every few months, to extract the Pu-239 before it decays or transmutes into something else. Since nuclear power plants have uptimes measured in years, this simply doesn't happen. The benefit of nuclear power is that it stays online longer than anything else.

2. The refining process for nuclear power - uranium enrichment - does not make those kinds of nuclear weapons possible. The reason being, is that you do not enrich uranium to anywhere near the level you need for a nuclear weapon. In terms of efficiency, nuclear weapons suck. Most of the nuclear fuel is actually blasted away before it ever has a chance to fission. So you need lots of it, which means you need a lot of Uranium which means everybody in the world who produces Uranium in the amounts needed, knows  what you're doing. This isn't The Avengers where Hydra is conjuring up high tech R&D labs in former Soviet Bloc states. You would be stopped before you ever got close.
Nuclear power in and of itself, IS a deterrent to proliferation.

3. Dirty bombs are a hypothetical possibility that really has very little chance of happening in the USA or anywhere else. The reason we store nuclear waste in large concrete and steel casks weighing 50 tons or more, is primarily to contain the radiation. But it has the secondary effect of making it very difficult to move. 50 tons is 10 tons more than the max you're going to get on a semi truck without special permits. Meaning, if you have to pull permits to even get the DOT to let you put such a heavy thing on the road, you are damn sure not going to smash into a nuclear power plant, drop one of these things onto the trailer of a big rig (don't forget the giant crane you'd need to pick it up) and drive it down the road, evading every cop in the area and the national guard, who will be called out. It's a suicide run. Not happening. Also, the effectiveness of a dirty bomb follows the same sort of pattern we'd see in an accident like Chernobyl, just much smaller in scale. Sure you might poison a lot of people if you detonated it in Los Angeles or New York, but because you're not going to get much high level waste without killing yourself and because disbursing it is very hard to do, you're going to watch the bomb go off, poison several thousand people and then the effects fall off very quickly. If you detonated it in Los Angeles, by the time the fallout cloud hit Irvine, it would have largely dissipated. Nobody else is getting sick. 

Stop dude. Just stop. Your understanding of radiation sucks and your talking points are garbage.
author: Mike McKeen

text: Nuclear is safe if you do everything right. If you screw it up even a little then it is very not safe. Sure, not many people actually died from Chernobyl and the data shows that cancer incidence didn't actually increase that much. But that is after the USSR bankrupted itself managing the .. ahem .. fallout. And Ukraine still has a gigantic debt burden of continuously managing the site. That is why the death rate was so low. Comparing to the current crisis, saying nuclear is safe cause few people died from Chernobyl is similar to saying that Coronavirus isn't serious because so few people died in a country that enforced severe restrictions. The USSR thankfully chose to buy the health and safety of the people near the reactor with a gigantic pile of money. Exactly the same with Fukishima. Barely anyone died, cancer incidence didn't increase but once again, gigantic pile of money used to mitigate the damage. What happens when we decide nuclear energy will save us all and force it on countries without a gigantic pile of money? What about the bottom hundred economies instead of the top five?

author: Findecanor

text:
¬†@Lu√≠s Filipe Andrade¬† Sure. Although I should point out that Xi Jinping was also elected by electors. I'm not arguing the man wasn't elected. I'm arguing the election fell somewhat short of democratic ideals, seemingly by design. 



Also, the comparison to the senate isn't really helping. Nor would a comparison to Congress. This might come as a shock to you, but the US isn't exactly the beacon of democracy it claims to be. All its electoral systems use outdated models with known severe flaws, and the politicians are bought so openly and excessively that they'd be... arrested, I think?... in most European countries. Certainly they'd be in flagrant violation of all kinds of laws meant to prevent corruption. And it shows in the laws that get passed, which track billionaire opinion way better than they track the opinion of the average voter. After all, the billionaires bought both sides, so what choice does that average voter have?


You can point out that it's the system, but "this is the system" doesn't work as a defence of that system. I know it's the system, that's the problem. Nor does it shield events emblematic of the flaws in that system from criticism. Things don't become less bad by being structural flaws rather than isolated incidents.

text: Look at how bad these pandemic models are.  Climate is a far more chaotic system, with far less experience, making predictions far further out.  Yes- CO2 warms things up, but the doomsday scenerios rely on climate sensitivity being about 300% of what the CO2 would produce, and also ignore the benefits like increased plant growth.  This is one of the lowest CO2 periods in Earth's history, and life has FLOURISHED through most of that history, so it's a bit extreme to believe that this is some kind of knife-edge balance point.  That said, there are plenty of other pollution-related reasons to get off fossil fuels.  We need to go nuclear.

text: The heck with storing it, split it into oxygen and carbon. Use the carbon to make advanced materials (carbon nanotubes), or combine with hydrogen and nitrogen to make synthetic hydrocarbons to replace oil and use that to replace fossil sources to make plastics . Use solar for energy. That way you have a renewable resource and you reduce  carbon dioxide on the atmosphere. Then you can start to address methane emissions (cow farts), as that's anthropogenic in itself and a much more potent greenhouse gas than CO. Downside is, you need a LOT of energy. The upside is, hopefully you prevent the release of methane from arctic tundra and the bottom of the oceans. Regardless of the technology used we need to get cracking before this becomes irreversible.

author: Freggle

text:
¬†@Felix B¬† And by the time the nuclear plant enters operation, the solar and wind is due to be replaced. As for the numbers for replacables... I used to have those handy, though I forget the details. I do remember I got a bit pessimistic after doing the calculations.

The summary was that while we can easily scale up wind, wind shadow means that you hit diminishing returns quite quickly in any single location, and in densely populated areas (I was calculating for the Netherlands), you run out of wind before you've provided everyone with energy (or come close iirc). Conversely, while there is easily enough sunlight to power even densely populated dimly-lit countries like the Netherlands, solar cells are made of way more high-tech materials than windmills, and you're going to need on the order of thousands of square kilometres of the stuff worldwide, replaced every 20 years. 

That means about a tenfold increase in dedicated high-tech production capacity, assuming global energy demand doesn't grow (it will, and must, for developing nations to reach our level of prosperity). In addition to that, those high-tech cells will turn into high-tech waste, contaminated with heavy metals, which will need but likely often not receive reprocessing. 

Then, regarding the time to build a nuclear plant... yes, they take a long time to build, but what takes even longer is getting through the people saying they're a bad solution. Al Gore lost in 2000. Any plants we'd have started planning then would be operational now. And in 2040, this problem still won't be solved, and the argument against nuclear will still be it takes too long. "It will take too long" is a terrible reason not to start, as any self-aware procrastinator can confirm.

Finally, while renewables promise to maybe, in the best case scenario, promise to eventually slow carbon emissions to a halt, nuclear (and afaik only nuclear) promises such an abundance of energy that we should be able to afford the energy-intensive process of extracting CO2 from the atmosphere, not just stopping global warming but reversing it, which means that even if it takes longer, it might leave us with less CO2 in the end.


Edit: paragraph spacing.
author: Sal Wolffs

text: Metal Organic Frameworks.  Promising.
author: bjkarana

text:
¬†@d.¬† The thing is... nothing is going to get us there in the next 10-15 years. We'll be lucky to make it in 25, and on that timescale, nuclear suddenly becomes one of the faster options, because while it has high latency (i.e. delay between planning and operation), it has great throughput: those reactors that take so long to build produce such tremendous amounts of energy that the moment they come online, they immediately overtake all the renewables that have been coming online every year during their construction.


That said, we should probably be doing both, because even if renewables can't completely free us from fossil in time, they can help us stretch what carbon budget we have left until new nuclear reactors can be completed in sufficient quantity to finally solve the issue.

text: I somewhat accept the skeptic label, though I'm not a denier.  I fully accept that there is climate change and that human activity impacts that change.  There is too much theory and evidence behind the concept to deny either.  There are two parts to that - climate change itself (which happened dramatically long before humans even existed) and the human impact on it.  I accept both and believe we need to take action, balanced against costs.  What I remain skeptical about are specific predictions about dates, direction (less so this one), and magnitudes.  I don't have full faith in the models being used on which these predictions are based.

text: Government is not the same as legislature
author: Bugi

text:
To add to what Sampat said, the US government is designed to work via Committee and Consensus. Parliamentary Systems accept partisanship as a reality of politics and are thus structured to give a majority party as much power as possible (without being too dangerous) to enact their vision of policy for the next four or five years. Presidential Systems, though, are structured so that parties must come to agreements or compromises on issues. Committees are created when people have ideas, consisting of members from both parties, who explore an issue and policy, then present their findings to both of their party leaders, stating they have the support of members of the other party who are on this committee, and so the bill proceeds to more formal debate in the floor of congress. Bills formed this way succeed far more often than not, and the Clean Water Act was one such bill-by-committee. When these agreements can't be attained, dealmaking is another option. Trading agricultural subsidies for tariffs.


So when that polarization hits, these committees aren't created or aren't as successful, and the Presidential System breaks down. France avoids this by having constitutional measures designed to prevent party polarization, so they can still have a Presidential System that's effective. Perhaps the saddest example of the death of Committe and Consensus Government was the 1990s immigration reform. This was several years in the making, and was led by one of the greatest statecrafters of the modern age, Representative Barbara Jordan. It intended to completely overhaul visa distribution, streamline asylum application, tighten security, and support the immigration courts, all to make legal immigration easier and more permissive, while at the same time resting fears of illegal immigration without resorting to police state tactics. It fell through, though. Expanding legal immigration was smeared as a plot to depress wages or import mexico wholesale. The immigration reform collapsed and the committee disbanded in 1996. Those fears went uncalmed. The issue went unresolved. The immigration courts remained strained and unfair. Exactly 20 years later, Donald Trump would be elected on a mandate to curb illegal immigration.
